lead_paragraph: Although considerable excitement exists among the firemen in relation to the passage of the Paid Fire Department Bill, the majority of them appear disposed to submit quietly to the law, continuing to exercise their functions only until such time as the ultimate action of the authorities may be made known. Yesterday a number of prominent firemen called on the Mayor and requested him to issue such a notice as might have the effect of allaying the excitement existing among the members of the department, and quieting any fears that might have arisen in the public mind. abstract: The funeral of Mr. JACOB LITTLE, the well-known broker and financier, took place at Grace Church yesterday. A large number of the friends of the deceased, including the officers and several prominent members of the Board of Brokers, assembled during the afternoon at his late residence, in Union-square, and accompanied the remains to the church. The following gentlemen acted as pall-bearers: Benjamin R. Winthrop, John Warren, Jesse Hoyt, Edward Prime, David Clarkson, Wm. Wheeler Deforrest, William Lawlor and John Alstyne. The coffin bore the following inscription: "JACOB LITTLE, born March 17, 1794. Died March 28, 1865." The services were performed by Rev. Dr. TAYLOR, Mr. GEORGE W. MORGAN officiated as organist, and played the following pieces: Chant -- "Lord, let me know my end." Hymn -- "When those we love are snatched away, by Death's relentless hand." Anthem -- "I heard a voice." The services were closed by the solemn music of a "Dead March."

abstract: Sayre, Dr. New Health Bill; Health Bill; Dr. Sayre. >amp;c.; Bribery Charge of Refuted by Vote
snippet: Sayre, Dr. New Health Bill; Health Bill; Dr. Sayre. >amp;c.; Bribery Charge of Refuted by Vote
lead_paragraph: In passing the Paid Fire Department Bill by so large a vote, the Sate Assembly has given the most practical reply possible to the scandalous imputations so widely bruited against its character. It has come to be part of the settled strategy of the lobby to charge bribery and corruption upon the opponents of any measure of importance. It is hoped in this way, apparently, to drive members into taking the action desired. On the Fire Bill both sides were remarkably industrious in this mode of argument. Possibly each side may have had some grounds for believing that the other was willing to purchase votes if any should prove to be in the market. The Assembly silenced all this clamor by passing the bill.

abstract: It is announced that the officers and members of the Fire Department are to meet tonight, to decide what course they shall pursue in regard to the law establishing a Paid Fire Department in place of the one now existing.
lead_paragraph: It is announced that the officers and members of the Fire Department are to meet tonight, to decide what course they shall pursue in regard to the law establishing a Paid Fire Department in place of the one now existing. There is but one course which they can pursue with any regard to their own character -- and that is to accept the change, tender their services until the new department is in working order, and then turn over all their apparatus to the new authorities created by the new law. If they are what they have claimed to be, orderly and respectable citizens -- aiming only at the promotion of the public interests -- they will take this course. Any other would simply demonstrate what their most bitter opponents have asserted, that their organization was merely a cover for selfish and dishonest practices.

abstract: Rebels do not credit; Loss of Confidence in Rebel Leaders; Cry; The Rebels don't believe in
snippet: Rebels do not credit; Loss of Confidence in Rebel Leaders; Cry; The Rebels don't believe in
lead_paragraph: Either the leaders are known to be liars or the led are proved to be cowards. The Fortress Monroe conference was no sooner closed than the rebel chiefs raised the cry that President LINCOLN had insisted upon a most degrading submission of the South -- a vassalage that would be eternal infamy to accept, and that was an intolerable insult to propose. The darkest colors were used to paint the shame, the misery, the ruin which would overspread the South if the Lincoln policy were suffered to prevail. Every manly sentiment in the human breast was appealed to in order to stir anew the spirit of resistance, and cause a universal rally to the flag. At the mass meeting in Richmond, Senator HUNTER asked if it were possible to present higher motives to engage zeal or rouse activity; and Senator BENJAMIN declared, that the failure of the conference would be the signal for a grand uprising of the people.

abstract: Peace Letter to the President (Niagara Falls); Greeley's Peace Letter
snippet: Peace Letter to the President (Niagara Falls); Greeley's Peace Letter
lead_paragraph: We copied from an English paper a day or two since a letter written last Summer by Mr. GREELEY to President LINCOLN, urging him to take steps which should either lead to the conclusion of peace with the rebels of the South, or satisfy the people of the whole country that it was not his fault if the war was to be continued. It is pretty generally understood in political circles that this letter, as well as the entire series of which it forms a part, would have been published last Fall but for the President's unwillingness to have certain expressions which it contains, concerning the inability or unwillingness of the country to prolong the struggle, go to the world under the sanction of a name so influential as that of Mr. GREELEY, -- and for Mr. GREELEY's unwillingness, on the other hand, to have it published in a mutilated form. The time has probably passed when Mr. LINCOLN's objections could have any special importance, as the determination of the country to conquer the rebellion has, since that time, been too distinctly pronounced to leave doubt in any quarter upon the subject. We see no possibility of harm being done by the publication, though we agree with the Tribune in not seeing the necessity of sending it to England for the purpose. This, however, was probably a matter of "enterprise" on the part of the correspondent.
headline: {'main': "Mr. Greeley's Peace Letter.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Mr. Greeley's Peace Letter.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: All except two corps of the Army of the Potomac started early on Wednesday morning for a demonstration toward the Southside Railroad. SHERIDAN, with a heavy force of cavalry, took the advance, and early on that day was at Dinwiddie Court-house. Our advices represent no fighting of consequence up to Wednesday evening.
lead_paragraph: All except two corps of the Army of the Potomac started early on Wednesday morning for a demonstration toward the Southside Railroad. SHERIDAN, with a heavy force of cavalry, took the advance, and early on that day was at Dinwiddie Court-house. Our advices represent no fighting of consequence up to Wednesday evening. The infantry crossed Hatcher's Run without opposition, and kept on until 3 in the afternoon, when the Fifth Corps had a pretty sharp encounter with the enemy on the Quaker Road, but lost in the affair less than 300 men, and drove the rebels nearly a mile, with loss to them, and captured a number of prisoners. At City Point, on Thursday, heavy cannonading was heard from 10 A.M. until 1 1/2 P.M., but the reason thereof was unknown. It was guessed, however, that the rebels were making an attempt to break our lines near Fort Steadman. Our last dispatches this morning bring a rumor of the evacuation of Petersburgh.

abstract: Prof. EBEN, the celebrated flutist, gives a concert this evening at Irving Hall, which has more than the ordinary claims to public favor. Beside being one of the most accomplished and distinguished of living performers, Prof. EBEN has been always ready to volunteer his services for every concert given in aid of any benevolent object, and has thus sacrificed a great deal of valuable time and strength in aid of others. As a gentleman he is universally respected and esteemed. Beside his own share in the performances, his programme for this evening presents a strong array of distinguished performers; and on every account the concert will be one of the most attractive of the season.

snippet: Haverhill, N.H.; Page's Farm, Stock, >amp;c.; 1864 product; Vermont Central; Train off Track
lead_paragraph: Several intelligent Georgians visited the Philadelphia Inquirer office on Wednesday evening. They say that the desertions from LEE'S army average over a hundred every day. The whole rebel force in front of GRANT cannot, in their opinion, exceed forty thousand men, and if it should continue to be depleted at the rate mentioned, cannot long be available for evil. They say that STEPHENS left for the South immediately on his return from the late Peace Conference, and refused to have anything more to do with the Confederacy.

abstract: Drafting in this district for the Tenth Ward was resumed yesterday morning. The quota of this ward has undergone a reduction of 32 since the draft commenced, and, if money be forthcoming, will be still further reduced before notifications are sent to the conscripts. The deficiency of the ward is 680 -- and the per centage added 1,360 -- a reduction of 64, compared with Tuesday last, on the whole number.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was offered to repair damage to canals, caused by recent floods. A bill was reported to allow the New-York Central Railroad to charge two and a half cents per mile on way fares. Bills were reported to consolidate Brooklyn Railroad Companies; to amend the Excise Law by reducing the rate of license; for another Police Court in New-York; also a dozen or more bills incorporating companies. The bill to provide for the erection of a new capital was passed; also the bill to regulate storage of Petroleum in cities. The evening session was devoted to discussion of the amended Registry Act.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was offered to repair damage to canals, caused by recent floods. abstract: Within the past ten days orders for our national gold-bearing bonds from buyers for permanent investment, have been executed in this city to an amount exceeding twelve millions dollars leading to the permanent withdrawal of unusually large lots of the U.S. Sixes, ...
lead_paragraph: Within the past ten days orders for our national gold-bearing bonds from buyers for permanent investment, have been executed in this city to an amount exceeding twelve millions dollars -- leading to the permanent withdrawal of unusually large lots of the U.S. Sixes, as well as of the 10-40s, from the market. Thrifty people have a very decided partiality for the stable Government Securities, in these times of violently fluctuating commercial values, especially when U.S. Six cent. Bonds of 1881 (with a three months' coin interest on, equal to $2 25 in currency with gold at 150) can be purchased at 105@105 1/4, as against 112@113 1/2 this day a year ago; U.S. 5-20s (with five months' coin interest, on equal at present to $3 75 in currency) at 105 3/8@105 1/2, as against 110@111 this time last year; and U.S. 10-40s yielding a five cent, annum coin interest, equal to $7 50 in currency at prevailing rates for gold) at 91 1/2, or 8 1/2 cent. under par. These most secure and desirable investments cannot long remain depressed to these low figures, in view of the encouraging military prospect, and the proximate close of the war -- so vastly ahead of anything of this nature that could have been even reasonably hoped for in the Spring of 1864. Prudent people, therefore, merely take advantage of the present rare opportunity to buy them freely.

abstract: At the anniversary Sunday-School meeting, to-morrow evening, announced for Rev. Dr. THOMPSON's church, Broadway and Thirty-fourth-street, Rev. H.C. TRUMBULL, chaplain of the Tenth Connecticut Volunteers, Rev. ALEXANDER R. THOMPSON, and Rev. ABBOTT E. KITTREDGE are expected to speak. Rev. Mr. TRUMBULL has just returned from the Army of the James, and will advocate the cause of Sunday-School instruction, drawing his illustrations from experiences in army life. From the reputation of all the speakers, the meeting cannot fail to be interesting.

abstract: Consecrated
snippet: Consecrated
lead_paragraph: The new Synagogue of the Congregation Shaar Hashomajim, (Gate of Heaven), in Rivington-street, between Ludlow and Orchard, was formally consecrated on Friday afternoon. The building, which was erected in 1835, was occupied by a Presbyterian congregation until last November, when it was sold to its presents occupants. It has been thoroughly refitted and is finished within in good style, with polycromatic decorations, the chief masses of color being blue, neutral tint and yellow. The Ark, where the Sephorim or scrolls of the Law is kept, is covered with a rich maroon velvet curtain or antependium, heavily fringed and ornamented with gold. On the walls are painted sentences from the Scriptures.

abstract: A dispatch from President LINCOLN, dated at City Point, March 31, to the Secretary of War, conveys the intelligence of very hard fighting on Friday near the Dabney House. At first the enemy drove back our left from that point toward the Boyd on plank-road. Our forces afterward rallied, drove the enemy in turn, and took the White Oak road, occupying the ground held by the rebels in the morning. Four rebel flags were captured during the day.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a concurrent resolution was adopted fixing Tuesday next for the election by the two Houses of a Superintendent of Public Instruction. Bills were passed incorporating the Yonkers Water Company; relative to evidence in actions on promissory notes, bills of exchange and bank cheeks. Incorporating the Permanent Committee of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church. Authorizing the consolidation of the Atlantic and Great Western Railroad Company in New-York with the Buffalo extension of the Great Western and Atlantic Railroad Company. To amend the Excise Law prohibiting the sale of liquor on Sunday. The bill amending the charter of the Manhattan Gas Light Company was amended so as to allow the company to charge $3 50 per thousand feet, instead of $2 50, and was then ordered to a third reading.

abstract: A considerable number of officers and members of the Volunteer Fire Companies met last evening at Firemen's Hall, in Mercer-street, between Prince and Houston, under an informal call. Chief Engineer DECKER took the chair, and Mr. CONNELLY, of No. 38 Hose, was appointed Secretary, Mr. DECKER stated to the meeting that he had caused a communication to be sent to the Common Council ...
lead_paragraph: A considerable number of officers and members of the Volunteer Fire Companies met last evening at Firemen's Hall, in Mercer-street, between Prince and Houston, under an informal call. Chief Engineer DECKER took the chair, and Mr. CONNELLY, of No. 38 Hose, was appointed Secretary, Mr. DECKER stated to the meeting that he had caused a communication to be sent to the Common Council and Board of Aldermen, (printed, with the substance of the replies, in yesterday's TIMES.) requesting them to take such action as they should think fit respecting the paid Fire Department Law, and communicate the same to the Volunteer Department through him; but that owing to an adjournment of the Council, only the response from the Aldermen had reached him.

abstract: Mr Gladstone's Scheme; Insurance of the Poor
snippet: Mr Gladstone's Scheme; Insurance of the Poor
lead_paragraph: We doubt whether many of our readers have had the inclination, amid the turmoil of the war, to follow a very ingenious and important experiment which Mr. GLADSTONE is making in behalf of the working classes of England. This Minister of State and classical scholar has been interesting himself in a project for insuring the lives of the laborers, servants, governesses and poor people of the Kingdom. His objects are to enable persons with low wages, but some small savings, to provide against future pauperism, and to assist men with good wages, but no capital, to purchase an annuity for old age; and more than this, to protect a family against the ruin which often follows on the death of the father or mother.
headline: {'main': "Mr. Gladstone's Insurance of the Poor.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Mr. Gladstone's Insurance of the Poor.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- At Covington, directly opposite our city, reside the parents and sisters of our Lieutenant-General. They were among our earliest Western friends, and have shown us many kind attentions. Week before last we were called to officiate at the funeral of Miss CLARA, one of the sisters, who early fell a victim to consumption, but has left to her friends the unquestioned assurance of being crowned with the glory, and honor, and immortality that she sought. The family are members of the Greenup-street Methodist Episcopal Church, and family altar and closets often have the name of Ulysses whispered to the Father of spirits. It would be wrong, of course, to betray the confidence of the family, or give to the public what a dutiful son only meant for a parent's eye. From a recent letter of Gen. GRANT, however, we presume to snatch a single paragraph that distinctly unfolds our national prospects as they appear to the writer. He says: "We are now having fine weather, and I think will be able to wind up matters about Richmond soon. I am anxious to have LEE hold on where he is a short time longer, so that I can get him into a position where he must lose a great portion of his army. The rebellion has lost its vitality, and if I am not much mistaken there will be no rebel army of any great dimensions a few weeks hence. Any great catastrophe to any one of our armies would, of course, revive the enemy for a short time, but I expect no such thing to happen. I am in excellent health, but would enjoy a little respite from duty wonderfully. I hope it will come soon. I shall expect to make you a visit the coming Summer. -- The Christian Advocate.

abstract: Lee wants Men and Provisions
snippet: Lee wants Men and Provisions
lead_paragraph: That portion of Virginia which lies south of the James River is the destined theatre of the opening campaign. GRANT has completed his combinations, and, from all quarters he is moving his concurring columns. SHERIDAN, after committing what passing destruction he might, has crossed to the Southside to strengthen GRANT's cavalry arm. SHERMAN, defeated of his enterprise upon Raleigh, it is supposed, will now attempt to move from Goldsboro (77 miles) to Weldon, at which latter point he would be within 64 miles of Petersburgh. THOMAS, having collected a considerable force in East Tennessee, threatens Charlotte and Salisbury with a cavalry expedition, while his main column is to move upon Lynchburgh, and thence upon Richmond from the west.

abstract: From Warrensburgh the road bed is graded to Kingville, and the track will be laid to Holden, nine miles from Warrensburgh, before the end of next month. All the iron spikes, ties, culvert timbers have been bought, and are now ready for use. About eight hundred laborers are employed on the grading, and were it not for recent wet weather, this part of the work would have been finished as far as Pleasant Hill. Additional laborers are going forward every day. Fifty teams and carts were sent up the road on Thursday morning, and from all the information in our possession we are happy to assure our readers, that the progress of the road toward its final completion is entirely satisfactory. Unless some unforeseen accident or interference should occur, which cannot be provided against, the company confidently expect that the road will be completed its entire length to Kansas City by the middle of July.

abstract: The Struggle between Emperor and Aristocracy
snippet: The Struggle between Emperor and Aristocracy
lead_paragraph: The great contest between the Russian Emperor and the aristocracy still continues. We called attention, in a recent issue, to the address put forth by the Moscow Diet, urging a representation of the nobility in a new Imperial Parliament for all Russia. This address, and the debate accompanying it, were published, without permission, in a St. Petersburgh journal, and thus made public to Europe. The Emperor, indignant at such a divulging of the internal conflicts of the empire, has suppressed the journal and imprisoned the editor. The excitement over the contest between the Crown and the noblesse is intense through the country. The nobility denounce the ingenious expedient of the Czar for weakening their power, in allowing the lower rank of landholders to enter the Moscow Diet, but the Imperial Government is firm, though their course is surrounded with difficulties. The peasantry, a vast and powerful class, are grateful to the Czar for his act of emancipation, and would stand by him in emergencies, but they have their own grievances in the settlement of their properties and rights, and as yet are not so organized as to act with the Emperor in his great struggle. The middle class -- as in Poland or our own South -- is very small, and possesses scarcely any political power or experience.

abstract: -- A correspondent writes as follows: "In passing through Mott-street yesterday, (29th,) a scene presented itself, which, if not associated with death, would afford an admirable subject for the pencil of an American Cruikshank. A corpse was being conveyed from one of those human breeding-cages, called tenement-houses, situated in No. 213 Mott-street -- another morsel thrown to the insatiable Moloch, who has long since made that section of New-York his altar -- but as the filth in front of the premises is piled nearly four feet high, forming a continuous breastwork, an almost insuperable difficulty here presented itself. The driver could not back the hearse up, and the bearers dare not climb the Alpine steeps of the muck heap. After long conference, and much engineering, however, they finally got through. Our City Inspector, as appears from his evidence before the Senate Investigating Committee, is waiting on Providence to soften the filth before it can be removed." Our correspondent asks if we can inform him whether this is the same Providence who assisted Mr. BOOLE on Sunday, March 5, to clear the whole line of procession.

abstract: Eleventh-avenue; Bowery--Together $3,000
snippet: Eleventh-avenue; Bowery--Together $3,000
lead_paragraph: THIEVES' DEN IN THE SIXTEENTH WARD -- ARREST OF A MOTHER AND HER TWO CHILDREN. -- Officers LAWSON and TILTON, of the Sixteenth Ward, apprehended ELWOOD and ELIZABETH PLOOMER, children of 15 and 13 years, respectively, and various Eighth-avenue merchants accused the youthful prisoners of theft. The children, on being pressed to make a revelation, disclosed the fact, that under their mother's instruction they had for six months or more made it their business to go together, ostensibly shopping, but really thieving, and that wherever they saw any article which they desired, one engaged a clerk in conversation, while the other committed the larceny. On searching the abode of their mother, Mrs. FANNIE BANSATA, the officers found goods enough to stock a small dry goods-store, which the children had stolen. Mrs. BANSATA also was arrested, and the three were committed by Justice LEDWITH. The products of the children's pilfering are to be taken to the office of the Metropolitan Police Property Clerk, to-day, and may there be seen and claimed by the owners.

abstract: THE MCCLASKY CASE IN THE BROOKLYN COURT. -- The case of HANNAH BIRDSALL against ISAAC D. MCCLASKY, which has been on trial in the City Court for several days past, and which has created a considerable amount of interest, was brought to a close yesterday, the jury rendering a verdict for plaintiff in the amount of $1,000. The suit was brought for $10,000 damages for injuries alleged to have been received by plaintiff in her own parlor in October last, while defendant was attempting to commit personal violence. The evidence in this case was of a most contradictory character, the witnesses for the defendant flatly contradicting those of the plaintiff.

abstract: Pursuant to orders received from Major-Gen. DODGE, Capt. WAGNER proceeded to enforce the draft in this district yesterday, the Eleventh Ward ballots, some nine thousand in number, being placed in the wheel. From the fact that recruits were constantly coming in, the business transacted was comparatively limited. At half-past nine o'clock, eight recruits had been mustered in, and 324 names drawn, when Capt. WAGNER declared further proceedings postponed until Monday, at 9:30 o'clock.

lead_paragraph: The Coos (N.H.) Republican gives the following account of a patriotic family in Randolph, Coos County: "The father, CLOVIS LOW, served eighteen months with his son, Prof. LOW, the well-known aeronaut, who held the grade of Colonel; another son occupied the same rank in the Quartermaster Department of the Western armies; another rose to a Lieutenancy from the ranks of the Fighting Fifth, and three remaining sons are in the service. The entire family, father and six sons, were engaged at once and in the same cause."

abstract: University; Junior Exhibition

lead_paragraph: The Junior Exhibition of the New-York Universtiy took place on Friday in the large chapel of the institution, in the presence of a large and select audience. Chancellor FERRIS presided. The platform was occupied by Professors JOHNSON, COPELY, MARTIN and BAIRD. HELMSMULLER'S orchestra band was in attendance and performed several beautiful selections.

abstract: His Honor held the Court open yesterday morning for the purpose of disposing of the case of Eliza Ploss, an interesting young girl, convicted last week upon an indictment for grand larceny. The evidence in this case showed that on the 13th of January last, the prisoner picked up a purse containing $270, the property of a poor woman. Besides the money, the purse contained a receipt for rent, containing the full name and address of the owner of the money. It was also advertised extensively, and the advertisement brought to the notice of the prisoner and her mother. The money was finally traced to the prisoner, and the woman who had lost the money called on her and begged her to return it, but the prisoner's mother said that the description given of the purse was incorrect: the one found by her daughter being a new one, and not containing any rent receipt. After her arrest, the prisoner confessed that she had thrown the original pocket-book away, and substituted a new one, of a different shape, for the purpose of deceiving the owner. She also stated that her brother had taken the money away from her and gone off to the army. After her conviction. His Honor postponed sentence for a week, stating that if restitution was made to the loser of the money he would impose a light sentence, but as the money was not refunded she was yesterday brought up for sentence. Judge RUSSEL said to the prisoner that he would still give her an opportunity to reform and escape severe punishment, provided her friends would restore the money. He should therefore send her to the House of Refuge, where she would be kept for seven years, until she was twenty-one, unless in the meantime the money was returned, when he would have her released. The prisoner probably did not realize, until her sentence was pronounced, that she had committed a grave crime deserving of severe punishment. She burst into tears, and clung screaming to her mother, begging her not to leave her, and to save her from prison. Her case should be a warning and a reminder that honesty is the best policy.

abstract: The revised Internal Revenue Law went into operation yesterday. It imposes a large increase of taxation on every taxable interest, in response to the wants and claims of the National Treasury. It will add at least twenty-five per cent, to the income of the government from this source, and will afford great pacuniary relief to the National ...
lead_paragraph: The revised Internal Revenue Law went into operation yesterday. It imposes a large increase of taxation on every taxable interest, in response to the wants and claims of the National Treasury. It will add at least twenty-five per cent, to the income of the government from this source, and will afford great pacuniary relief to the National Treasury, by rendering the latter less dependent on loans, and measurably precluding all necessity for any further inflation of the currency. In this way the new law must vastly improve and promote the public credit, both at home and abroad. Under the administration of the accomplished Secretary of the Treasury, and the able vigilant Commissioner of Internal Revenue, its prompt and rigid enforcement -- in obedience to the peremptory demands of the public interest -- is assured.

abstract: Bounty-jumper Shot in Street; Curious Bill
snippet: Bounty-jumper Shot in Street; Curious Bill
lead_paragraph: JAMES TAYLOR, from Manchester, England, was, on Thursday evening, mustered in at the Provost-Marshal's office, Ninth District, as a substitute for SAMUEL G. CORLIES, of the Twenty-second Ward, who had been drafted. As there was no place in the office for the men to get their meals, this substitute, with others, was marched to a restaurant about two hours afterward, to get supper. While supper was in course of preparation, TAYLOR, the substitute, watched his opportunity and ran off; but one of the guard, JOHN D. SWENTON by name, who had him in charge, was too quick for him, and discharged a pistol, wounding him in the wrist. The bullet then entered the coal-yard No. 682 Eighth-avenue, breaking a chair, tearing a dress coat, &c. The deserter was taken to the United States General Hospital, on Lexington-avenue and Fifty-first-street, and it is understood he will lose his arm. Capt. DUNNING thanked the soldier for his vigilance and promptness, and reminded the guard that, as substitutes were frequently professional deserters, it would be well to keep an eye on them hereafter. Yesterday morning the following curious bill was sent in to Capt. DUNNING:

abstract: Lamb,Roger,in Tombs Under Sentence; Walters, C H,in Tombs Under Sentence; Ferrero, Frank, in Tombs under Sentence; Tombs, the; The Four Murderers in
snippet: Lamb,Roger,in Tombs Under Sentence; Walters, C H,in Tombs Under Sentence; Ferrero, Frank, in Tombs under Sentence; Tombs, the; The Four Murderers in
lead_paragraph: On a damp, drizzly day the exterior of the Tombs is by no means inviting. Sitting squat in one of the dirtiest parts of this exceedingly filthy city, it is suggestive of sin and misery, squalor and vice, and remains year in and year out a terrible exponent of the punishment which awaits the transgressors of our laws. It is doubtful if any city in the country can furnish a specimen of architectural folly at all comparable to this Egyptian abortion, which serves New-York and vicinity as a jail for temporary detentions, and has on several occasions been the theatre of tragedies, public and private, that have been the nine-days' wonder of the town. The warden, Mr. CHARLES SUTTON, has been the responsible head of the institution for many years, and we have yet to hear a complaint of any sort in regard to his management. Under him are four keepers in the male prison, while Miss FOSTER, a very worthy and efficient official, superintends the female department. There are also clerks, watchmen and other assistants, making altogether a very large and well-disciplined force. The medical department is under charge of Drs. HODGMAN and SIMMONS, both of whom are well known in their profession as men of ability and culture.

abstract: end with Rebel Military Overthrow; Conquest of the South Means its Armies; Destruction of, The President's Object
snippet: end with Rebel Military Overthrow; Conquest of the South Means its Armies; Destruction of, The President's Object
lead_paragraph: The standing argument of such pro-rebel organs as the London Times, that the States which have been overrun by our armies cannot be, and are not to-day, held in subjection to the authority of the National Government, finds no echo even in the most rabid of DAVIS' home organs. It is a theory, however which meets a cordial response from the rebel mouthpiece here. Texas, Louisiana, Arkansas, and all the trans-Mississippi region of the South are said to be practically still in the hands of the Confederates; Missouri alone being excepted. East of the Mississippi, it is urged, the main points recovered from DAVIS' dominion, have been abandoned; and even "in Kentucky, and in Eastern Middle Tennessee conquest has paused, foiled by the immensity of the work in its front."

abstract: GEORGE N. STUART, Esq., of Philadelphia, Chairman of the Christian Commission, made a statement at an informal meeting of merchants yesterday, in the rooms of the Assistant Treasurer, of the immediate need of funds by the organization. Its field machinery is in working order -- delegates, coffee wagons, &c. -- but there are no stores for distribution. Of the efficiency of the commission no person who has witnessed its operations in the field entertains a doubt, and it is much to be regretted that its usefulness is temporarily suspended for lack of means. Twenty thousand dollars were subscribed by the few persons present at the meeting, and from the spirit evinced it is pretty certain that the sum of $100,000, which the commission needs, will soon be obtained.

abstract: Yelverton Marriage Case, The
snippet: Yelverton Marriage Case, The
lead_paragraph: That peculiar proceeding in the Yelverton marriage case, to which we adverted some time since, by which Miss LONGWORTH applied to have the question whether she was married to Major YELVERTON referred to his own oath, has terminated in the refusal of the court to order the reference prayed for. All the judges agreed that the court had power to make the reference, and that whether they should do so or not was a matter of discretion, but they did not agree as to what should be the action of the court in exercising that discretion, three of them holding that the application should be refused, while one thought it should be granted.

abstract: Substitute for; Guacoyol, of Mexico
snippet: Substitute for; Guacoyol, of Mexico
lead_paragraph: -Efforts have been making for some time past to induce the War Department to allow persons who wish to save a relative or friend from the draft to volunteer in his stead, and not be classed as a substitute, who are usually strictly guarded, and are allowed few of the privileges of volunteers. If the head of a family is drafted, a son will find it more convenient to the family to go in his father's place, and brothers having no families are willing to go in the place of those who have. Dr. SAUNDERS last week visited Washington, and obtained the consent of the Department to allow such persons to be classed among the volunteers, receiving from the Bounty Fund Commission a certificate to that effect. By this means a better class of men are obtained for the Government than the substitutes who usually present themselves, and whose only object is to get the highest amount of pay. Those who are willing to make sacrifices for their family or friends are prompted by a good motive, and will faithfully perform their obligations. With this privilege, a number of volunteer substitutes will doubtless be added to the army, and as the service is willingly entered into, they will make the best kind of soldiers. -- Philadelphia Ledger, March 20.

abstract: -- In the Executive office at Columbia, S.C., was found a letter from D.M. SEYMOUR, of Hartford, to Gov. GIST, dated Nov. 30, 1860, and inclosing $1,000, which Mr. SEYMOUR begged the Governor to invest in South Carolina six per cent. stock, with which the State was raising funds to oppose the General Government. Mr. SEYMOUR writes at some length in defence of the position of South Carolina, and expressly states that he sends his money for the express purpose of aiding the State in her effort "to defend her rights."
lead_paragraph: -- In the Executive office at Columbia, S.C., was found a letter from D.M. SEYMOUR, of Hartford, to Gov. GIST, dated Nov. 30, 1860, and inclosing $1,000, which Mr. SEYMOUR begged the Governor to invest in South Carolina six per cent. stock, with which the State was raising funds to oppose the General Government. Mr. SEYMOUR writes at some length in defence of the position of South Carolina, and expressly states that he sends his money for the express purpose of aiding the State in her effort "to defend her rights."

abstract: General Lyon, Transport, Burned; Great Loss of Life; Louisville Municipal Election; Tompert, Deo., Mayor
snippet: General Lyon, Transport, Burned; Great Loss of Life; Louisville Municipal Election; Tompert, Deo., Mayor
lead_paragraph: The steamer Gen. Sedgwick, which arrived at this port at noon yesterday, brought as passengers twenty-nine persons saved from the wreck of the transport steamer Gen. Lyon, which took fire off Cape Hatteras on the morning of Friday last, and was totally destroyed. The Gen. Lyon had on board from five hundred and fifty to six hundred souls. The twenty-nine who arrived here yesterday are believed to be all that was saved.

abstract: COUNTRYMAN SWINDLED.?Mr. KENDALL NORRIS, from one of the interior counties of New-York State, was yesterday swindled out of $200 by means of the patent safe game. NORRIS was about emigrating to California.

abstract: Celebration at, April 14
snippet: Celebration at, April 14
lead_paragraph: The formal re-hoisting of the old flag at Sumter, by Major-Gen. ANDERSON, on the anniversary of the day when it was there lowered, is calculated to give a new prestige to that emblem of our national unity and glory, and is in every way an excellent design. Perhaps it is well enough, moreover, though not wholly free from exception, that a citizen so full of patriotism and of oratorical power as HENRY WARD BEECHER -- one, too, who is so well accredited to speak for the anti-slavery sentiment and the religious faith which have done so much to secure the triumph -- should be selected to give the address on the occasion.

abstract: on Northwest Sanitary Fair; Florence Saloon, Broadway--$12,000
snippet: on Northwest Sanitary Fair; Florence Saloon, Broadway--$12,000
lead_paragraph: Preparations are in progress by the government to celebrate in a becoming spirit the restoration of Fort Sumter to the national authority. The day appropriately decided upon for the interesting event is the 14th inst., that being the fourth anniversary of the sorrowful time when the flag of the Union was lowered by the gallant ANDERSON and his brave band after a stout resistance to the overwhelming assaults of the misguided men of South Carolina. The identical flag which was shot away by the rebels, and afterward nailed to its staff amid the storm of shell by PETER HART, the heroic policeman, is again to be given to the breeze, thus vindicating, by poetic justice, the honor and integrity of the nation.

abstract: Rebel Losses at; Final Grand Attack
snippet: Rebel Losses at; Final Grand Attack
lead_paragraph: The grand movement of the Army of the Potomac, introduced as it is with gratifying tidings of success, naturally absorbs public attention to the exclusion of all other topics. The presence of Mr. LINCOLN with the army; his brief and modest telegrams; the knowledge that GRANT himself is at the front, supervising in person; that glorious PHIL. SHERIDAN leads our splendid cavalry; that THOMAS is already threatening Lynchburgh from the West; while SHERMAN, with an army flushed with six months of unvarying success, lies within striking distance in GRANT's rear, ready, if need be, to launch upon the enemy a power utterly irresistible; that the James River is clogged with our monitors and gunboats; that Mobile, if not already under fire, will soon be subjected to an ordeal that promises an early victory -- all these great facts necessarily fix the eyes of our whole country -- we may say of the world -- upon the stirring events of the hour. That the visit of the President to GRANT's headquarters, and the grand council of Generals held last week should be translated into action so soon, shows that there is a determination to make at least an effort to end the long protracted struggle, and by a blow so decisive that all hope of further organized resistance on the part of the leaders of the rebellion must be abandoned. Gen. GRANT's movements were begun by SHERIDAN, who, on Tuesday last, began to push his cavalry along the rear of our lines toward and beyond Ream's Station. The enemy quickly detected this movement, and their papers at once grew uneasy as they sounded the alarm. On Wednesday morning the Second and Fifth Corps moved from their works to follow and support SHERIDAN. There followed a rain-storm, as usual when the Potomac army moves, whereby movements on the next day (Thursday) were materially retarded. To return to Wednesday: Our infantry met very little opposition, receiving only here and there a sprinkle of musketry, until the First Division of the Fifth Corps had got to the junction of the Boydtown with the Quaker road, where they had a fight, which lasted about an hour and a half, and our loss was some three hundred and thirty, of which number about forty were killed and the rest wounded. The rebel loss was about two hundred and fifty in killed and wounded, and one hundred prisoners. The enemy was finally driven from his works, and retired to another line beyond the Boydtown road, and our troops of the First Division followed up and took a position with the left, about two miles north of the road. The entire losses of the First Division for the day were a little over 450. After the right here alluded to, the Second and Fifth Corps formed a junction and advanced slowly, driving back the rebel skirmishers, until darkness compelled a suspension of operations. This was ail the important fighting during Wednesday. The enemy, however, enlivened the night by a furious cannonade along the lines in front of our Ninth Corps, evidently in the hope of finding a weak spot; but they were disappointed. On Thursday the rain began very early, about midnight, and lasted until 4 P.M., rendering the roads impassible for artillery, and necessarily suspending active operations. A lively fire of artillery was kept up by the enemy and picket firing was rapid and continuous, but no serious damage was done. On Friday morning the enemy became fully awake to the danger threatening him; LEE himself, so prisoners say, was at the front and speedily began the day's work by a desperate rush upon our left, which he forced back upon their previous position on the Boydtown Road. Here our men rallied and in turn drove the enemy with considerable loss, over all the distance he had gained, taking possession of the White Oak road. At the same time the enemy made an attack upon the right flank of the Fifth Corps, but by a sudden and brilliant charge our men drove them a long distance, and strewed the ground with their dead and wounded. The result of the day's work was the capture of four battle-flags, about 1,000 prisoners, and a considerable advancement of our lines. It is thought that the enemy lost about 1,200 men during the day. Very soon after the attack on the Fifth Corps, the rebels attacked SHERIDAN, at a point about three miles from the South-side Railroad, with infantry and cavalry, and, as usual, gained a slight advantage for the moment; but all was quickly recovered, and something gained besides. Operations on both sides were heavy and difficult, on account of the muddy state of the roads. On Saturday the struggle became more general, and a furious fight raged apparently nearly all day. The net result was highly favorable to the Union arms. The position called the Five Forks was recaptured, and SHERIDAN on our left, carried everything before him, capturing a large number of prisoners and several batteries of artillery. But all this heavy and successful fighting was only the prelude to the grand effort of yesterday, when Gen. GRANT ordered, an attack along the whole line. At 8 o'clock the rebel lines had been broken and the battle was raging with desperate energy; SHERIDAN was sweeping down from the West; ORD was engaged and all appeared favorable. At 11 P.M. the President telegraphed: "All is going on finely. Gens PARKE, WRIGHT and ORD's lines are extending from the Appomattox to Hatcher's Run. They have all broken through the enemy's entrenched lines, taking some forts, guns and prisoners. SHERIDAN, with his own cavalry, the Fifth Corps, and part of the Second, is coming in from the west, on the enemy's flank, Wright is already tearing up the Southside Railroad." A few hours afterward we received another bulletin from GRANT, dated 10:45 A.M. Everything had been swept from the left of the Ninth Corps. The Sixth Corps had taken 3000 prisoners. The Second and Twenty-fourth had captured guns, forts and prisoners. The army was closing around the works enveloping Petersburg. Al looked well; SHERIDAN not heard from. Six hours later GRANT telegraphed that his men were all up in unbroken line, and in a few hours he entrenched from the Appomatox below Petersburg to the river above. Our entire captures were at least 12,000 men and 50 guns The dispatch closes thus; "All seems well with us and everything is quiet just now."

abstract: The United States steam transport Gen. Sedgwick, Capt STARKEY, arrived at this port at noon yesterday, with twenty-nine persons saved from the wreck of the transport steamer Gen. Lyon.
lead_paragraph: The United States steam transport Gen. Sedgwick, Capt STARKEY, arrived at this port at noon yesterday, with twenty-nine persons saved from the wreck of the transport steamer Gen. Lyon. The Gen. Lyon left Wilmington for Fortress Monroe on Wednesday morning last, with from five to six hundred souls on board, and when off Cape Hatteras, in lat. 35, long. 75 35, took fire and burned to the water's edge. Twenty-nine persons were picked up by the Gen. Sedgwick -- all the others are supposed to have perished. The sea was running so high at the time that only one boat succeeeded in reaching the Gen. Sedgwick. The passengers of the ill-fated steamer consisted of paroled and discharged soldiers and refugees, among whom were about thirty women and twenty-five small children. The fire is supposed to have originated in the engine-room, from the breaking of a bottle of oil. When the Gen. Sedgwick left, the burning steamer was drifting in toward the breakers off Cape Hatteras.

abstract: SOLDIERS ROBBED. -- PETER FORT and WILLIAM SHELDON, late privates in the First New-York Cavalry, were cheated by two confidence operators in the neighborhood of Thirty-first-street Railroad Station. The operators introduced themselves as travelers bound to Albany, and produced a $500 banknote, which they wished to break. SHELDON and FORT had only $270 between them, and this they loaned one of the operators, taking the $500 as collateral. Of course the swindler fled, and the banknote was spurious. Ascertaining which fact, the soldiers made their case known to Capt. WALLING, of the Twentieth Precinct, and subsequently Officers CLOW and IRVING apprehended JAMES WATSON, GEO. ENGLISH and HENRY GRIFFTH, and the latter was identified by both FORT and SHELDON, as one of the confidence operators who had defrauded them. The prisoners were committed by Justice LEDWITH.

abstract: Subscriptions to the 7-30 National Currency Loan continue on a comparatively liberal scale. During the week just closed they averaged $2,400,000 a day. The daily average number through the week -- one of unusual depression in business circles -- of orders for the smaller denominations of the notes ($50s and $100s) was 1,665. The number of such orders, direct from even the humblest of the loyal people, received by the General Subscription Agent in Philadelphia, during the month of February, was 52,033, or a daily average of 1,858, and during the month of March, just closed, 65,970, or a daily average of 2,128. These orders very distinctly demonstrate the generous and abiding confidence of the loyal masses in the stability and solvency of our government.

abstract: At no time since the Fall of Sumter has the City of New-York been so thoroughly excited as it was yesterday upon the announcement of the occupation of Richmond. The news in the morning journals was sufficient to arouse the most latent patriotism, and cause the hardest heart to beat with gratitude. Scarcely, however, had the people settled themselves at their various avocations when a strange whisper filled the air, penetrating to the counting-room, the workshop and the school, as if by magic, and long before the newspaper extras stamped the joyful news upon the public mind, it was everywhere known that great news had come to hand, and that victory was ours. An interested crowd gathered about the TIMES Bulletin, and as the cheering words were read again and again, great hearty cheers went up from the multitude, and joy beamed from every eye. Soon the nimble feet of the newsboys had sped with the official dispatch through-out the town, and what had been but an intuitive surmise became a patent truth. The manifestations of exhilaration were boundless; flags were flung to the breeze from innumerable stores and dwellings, making Broadway to shine with the Stars and Stripes, and casting a stream of glory upon the harbor. At the ferries, as soon as the announcement was formally made, an order was issued to deck the boats with bunting, and at once the several fleets of double-enders steamed across the river gay with the flutter of our flag. The down-town shipping houses, most of which are provided with staffs, ran up their colors, so that South-street and West-street, Broad-street and Beaver-street, with the neighboring marts of traffic, vied in patriotic display with the hotels of Broadway and the mansions of the upper end. The magnetism of delight was upon every man. Not a dismal face, not an averted eye, not a pursed-up mouth was seen, nor a croaking tongue heard. No one suggested an "if" or a "but," but every one accepted the glad tidings as truth from the pen of an "honest man." Hand grasped hand in places where "how much" and "how low," are the ordinary salutation; "glorious news" and "thank God" sprang from lips more accustomed to "buyer sixty" and "seller ten;" hard pebbled spectacles that have weathered the beatings of the world and the buffetings of care for sixty years without a moisture, were wet with tears of gratitude, and men estranged for months grasped each others willing palm, while their hearts beat in harmonious thanksgiving. In the public and private schools as much and as genuine enthusiasm was displayed as in the harsher schools of Wall and William streets. Appropriate addresses were made in several of them by the Principals, and the national hymns were sung with a gusto which only school boys and girls can give. One theme was upon every lip -- the boats, the cars, the restaurants, the stages, the streets were full of cheerful, happy, exulting, forgiving people, who waived all ceremony, all points of etiquette, and chatted busily each with his neighbor upon the one great occurrence of the day.

abstract: The County Committee on Volunteering commenced operations yesterday with $60,000 in hand. The announcement of the fall of Richmond gave an impetus to recruiting, and volunteers and substitutes presented themselves freely.
lead_paragraph: The County Committee on Volunteering commenced operations yesterday with $60,000 in hand. The announcement of the fall of Richmond gave an impetus to recruiting, and volunteers and substitutes presented themselves freely. Up to the close of business hours, 52 one-year men and five substitutes had taken the bounty, and a considerable number had been enlisted by the Provost-Marshals. On Saturday the committee received 36 substitutes and 29 volunteers. Of these 22 were enlisted in the Fourth District, 14 of whom were substitutes; and in the Sixth District 16 were enlisted, of whom 14 were substitutes. These facts show that the draft has acted as an effective stimulant in these Districts at least.

abstract: Brooklyn; Attempted with Oxalic Acid by Colored Help
snippet: Brooklyn; Attempted with Oxalic Acid by Colored Help
lead_paragraph: NARROW ESCAPE OF A FAMILY FROM BEING POISONED -- OXALIC ACID PUT INTO THEIR TEA BY A COLORED SERVANT. -- The family of Mr. GEORGE F. MAIN, residing No. 33 Bond-street. Brooklyn, had a narrow escape from being poisoned at the breakfast table yesterday morning. It appears that they have had employed in the family for some months past, a colored girl named ZOE YOUNG, a native of the Eastern shore of Maryland, who, although only 12 years of age, was very active and competent to do the light domestic work. A woman named MURPHY comes to the house every Monday to do the washing. Mrs. MURPHY had on a previous occasion offended the girl by complaining to MIS. MAIN of some dereliction of duty, or impudence. Mrs. MAIN talked to her sharply on account of it, and made her mind, therefore, to poison the washerwoman. With this object in view, she took a vial containing oxalic acid, and when making the tea poured a considerable quantity into the pot. The washerwoman sat down to the table with the family, consisting of five persons, including three small children, and tasting the tea, remarked its sour acid taste. Others tasted it and also found it unpalatable. The little girl was applied to for the cause, when, after some hesitation, she confessed that she had poured in some of the poisonous stuff for the purpose of killing Mrs. MURPHY. The vial was kept on the third shelf in the kitchen closet. Her attention had been called to its poisonous qualties on several occasions, in order to prevent her from handling it. It had been used in the house for cleaning brass, and she was told it would kill rats. She thought, she said, if it would kill rats it would kill the washerwoman, having no desire, seemingly, of injuring any one else. The girl was taken before Justice PERRY and committed for a further hearing.

abstract: New-York Lines of
snippet: New-York Lines of
lead_paragraph: As the mild weather becomes seasonable and navigation possible, our beautiful harbor and the confluent rivers are made the theatre of great activity and wonderful enterprise. Scores of mammoth steamers thunder through the waters, hundreds of well-modeled palaces glide swiftly on the wave, and thousands of smaller craft betoken by their presence the power and wealth and commerce of this great city. The exigences of the war, or rather of the War Department, came upon the government at a time when the Navy Department had no visible means of transportation and the Secretary was compelled to turn to the country for relief. Naturally, New-York was the centre of attraction, as here were owned vessels enough to float all the armies of the world and transport all the commissariat in creation. The agents of the government ransacked every steamboat office in the city, and at one time it appeared quite probable that all the steamers owned by our merchants would be turned into transports, while circumstances made it by no means impossible that sooner or later our Brooklyn and Jersey City friends would be compelled to resort to the most primitive modes of crossing the rivers, or be deprived of the innumerable blessings and privileges of metropolitan existence. The result of this tonnage raid was soon apparent. Very few steam vessels, except the ferry-boats and those belonging to regular lines, were to be seen about the harbor, and, save on government service, it was a rare thing to find any of our largest-sized steamships in this vicinity. Many of these vessels were bought outright, but the most of them were chartered for a specified time, with the privilege of purchase, or else chartered by the week at enormous rates. As the Spring approached, fortunately the necessities of the government relaxed, and hundreds of the boats which had vigorously steamed under the "regular" flag, are back again, and will be in readiness for the enormous traffic which all agree in anticipating during the coming Summer. Last year, travel was impeded and rendered very uncomfortable or impossible on very many routes, by reason of the dearth of vessels, and quite likely the same difficulty will be met now, but it will be greatly lessened by the expiration of the charters, as alluded to above.

lead_paragraph: Considering that it was only a patriotic surprise party, this gathering was remarkably large and enthusiastic, and it was above all one of those gay and hearty assemblages where the happiness of the audience mightily bears up the speakers by sympathetic encouragement. Several of the buildings around Union-square were handsomely illuminated; a cord with six large United States flags stretched across from the Maison Doree to the stand; and that structure itself was adorned with colossal half-lengths of GRANT and SHERMAN, and with sundry Chinese lanterns.

abstract: A large number of "poor whites" followed SHERMAN'S army as it swept through South Carolina. An eye-witness says of these people: "Many of the females in their appearance give unmistakeable signs of a parentage higher than the pure corn-cracker.
lead_paragraph: A large number of "poor whites" followed SHERMAN'S army as it swept through South Carolina. An eye-witness says of these people: "Many of the females in their appearance give unmistakeable signs of a parentage higher than the pure corn-cracker. Women with hands and eyes, and foreheads which an oil princess would give a moiety of her fortune to possess, turned their heads to take from their mouths cuds of tobacco of such size as to interfere with their enunciation. They all chew incessantly. Even little girls of eight years of age were chewing and spitting forth the tobacco-juice like old tars. They are utterly ignorant, have a confused idea of Christianity, and as to the war know nothing, save that "the Yankees is gwine to free the niggers," the accomplishment of which laudable endeavor they have been taught to regard as the greatest calamity that could possibly befall the human family."

abstract: In the Superior Court, yesterday, before Justice BARBOUR and a jury, a suit was tried involving the question as to whether or not it is negligence to leave a horse unfastened in the streets of this city. About the 1st of June last, Mr. DOMINICK HART, aged 60 years, while walking along one of the streets in the upper part of the city, was knocked down and run over by a runaway horse. His injuries were so serious that he died two days after. His widow brought an action against the owners of the horse to recover the sum of $5,000, as provided by statute. It was left to the jury as a question of fact whether the horse was properly secured when the defendants left it on the street, and if not so secured, whether it was negligence. The jury are to render a sealed verdict this morning.

abstract: The Gottschalk matinee, on Saturday, was a tremendous success. The Academy of Music, where it took place, was filled from pit to dome. Not even with the attraction of a complete opera troupe have we seen the house more fashionably attended. Mr. GOTTSCHALK may well remember the occasion with pride. It will furnish him with a substantial hint that his absence is not desired, and that he may return home again whenever the disposition comes upon him. Mr. GOTTSCHALK played superbly, and in the duos was admirably aided by Mr. HARRY SANDERSON. Miss LUCY SIMONS sang with grace and neat artistic finish, and the marches (from the "Tannhauser" and "Faust") were thundered forth by an army of pianists, led by GOTTSCHALK, SANDERSON and FRADEL. The troupe takes its departure to-day for California.
lead_paragraph: The Gottschalk matinee, on Saturday, was a tremendous success. The Academy of Music, where it took place, was filled from pit to dome. Not even with the attraction of a complete opera troupe have we seen the house more fashionably attended. Mr. GOTTSCHALK may well remember the occasion with pride. It will furnish him with a substantial hint that his absence is not desired, and that he may return home again whenever the disposition comes upon him. Mr. GOTTSCHALK played superbly, and in the duos was admirably aided by Mr. HARRY SANDERSON. Miss LUCY SIMONS sang with grace and neat artistic finish, and the marches (from the "Tannhauser" and "Faust") were thundered forth by an army of pianists, led by GOTTSCHALK, SANDERSON and FRADEL. The troupe takes its departure to-day for California.

abstract: Matches Announced
snippet: Matches Announced
lead_paragraph: The arrival of a distinguished French professional has created a marked sensation in billiard circles during the last few days. This gentleman, M. PIERRE CARME, was born at Bordaux, and is now about thirty years of age. He had long been known to be remarkably expert at billiards, and on coming to Paris, some three years since, at once assumed superiority by conquering BARTHOLEMEW, BERGER and others. Since the period last mentioned, he has stood in the very front rank of his profession in Paris and Versailles. After subjugating all France, he determined to "seek fresh fields and pastures new," and finally concluded to come to the United States. He arrived here about ten days since, and immediately sought Mr. PHELAN, and after an interview, exhibited to that gentleman and a few of his friends, his extraordinary powers. Although all the party bad often witnessed BERGER's seances, the masterly execution of M. CARME had such an electrical effect upon them, that they all readily admitted he possessed powers infinitely superior to anything ever before witnessed in this country. In the masse he manipulates with wonderful certainty and brilliancy; yet, all is accomplished with unusual grace of position, and the slightest physical effort. In regard to the strength of his game we have no means of estimating at the present time; but as his playing is not confined to the small balls used in France, and he is equally efficient with "two and three-eighths," he is undoubtedly, at the game of billiards, at least the equal of any man in this country. M. CARME will shortly give a series of public seances, at which he will be assisted by Mr. PHELAN, and in another month he will be probably one of the lions of the day.

abstract: INTERESTING TO THE LADIES. -- Our attention has been called to a newly patented self-adjusting hoop-skirt, which appears to possess the utility of the ordinary skirt without any of its objectionable qualities. This skirt, from its peculiar construction, accommodates itself to any exigency. On the removal of any pressure to which it may have been subjected it at once resumes its symmetrical form. When pressed on one side it does not rise in the usual unsightly manner on the other. It allows the wearer to pass through a narrow doorway, or seat herself in a crowded vehicle, or take position in a crowd, without being subjected to extraordinary annoyance. It can also be worn without difficulty on horseback. We have been assured by those who have tried it that it is fully entitled to the name of the "magic skirt," which the inventor has given it.

abstract: Visit to Richmond
snippet: Visit to Richmond
lead_paragraph: -- If President LINCOLN has "gone to the front," or entered Richmond, he has departed widely from the discretion and good judgment which have hitherto marked his conduct. We can readily understand his personal eagerness to witness events of such transcendent importance as the defeat of the rebel army and the capture of the rebel capital; but we deem it his duty to have subordinated all such personal predilections to the higher considerations of public duty which the case involves. Mr. LINCOLN's life may be of no special value to himself, and of no more value to others, considered merely in his personal relations, than that of any other man. But his official position makes it of special value to the country, and he has no right to put it at the mercy of any lingering desperado in Richmond, or of any stray ballet in the field, unless some special service can be rendered by his personal presence. It seems to as he might have left to Gen. GRANT the closing up of the great campaign which he has so wisely planned and so ably executed, -- and that his own share in the great transaction might have been as well performed at Washington as in front of Richmond. If nothing happens to him, this gratification of a very natural curiosity will be of little public consequence. But if he should happen to be singled out as a worthy mark for some reckless and desperate rebel sharpshooter, the country will scarcely approve the rashness which may have thrown its whole political organization into hopeless and needless confusion.

abstract: Until yesterday morning there was reasonable ground of doubt whether the Unionists could carry all the Congressional districts of Connecticut. GRANT, however, decided the case in our favor. Under the glorious exhiliration of the news printed by us yesterday, voting for a SEYMOUR or any of his ticket was not to be done. The only Democratic member of Congress, Mr. JAMES E. ENGLISH, who was chosen in 1861 by 1,004 majority, and in 1863 by 1,030 majority, is now displaced, and New-England will undoubtedly present in the coming Congress a delegation entirely unanimous for the right side. Mr. SWEAT was defeated in Maine, Mr. MARCY in New Hampshire, and now Mr. ENGLISH in Connecticut, gives place to a sound Republican and Unionist. The members already chosen to the Thirty-ninth Congress now stand: Union, 142; Democrat, 35; Rhode Island will elect two Union men to-morrow; and Kentucky, Tennessee, and perhaps other Southern States will swell the number. Last November, Mr. LINCOLN's majority in Connecticut was 2,406; last April BUCKINGHAM bad, for Governor, 5,658 over SEYMOUR. Now BUCKINGHAM has between 10,000 and 12,000 majority, all the Congressmen are Unionists, and all of the twenty-one Senators are of the same political faith. The House of Assembly is more than three-fourths Republican.

abstract: and his Counselors Outcasts and Outlaws; Examiner says Loss of Richmond Seals Doom of Confederacy; vain attempt to control Gold; and Confederacy, Fall of; Davis' Boasts
snippet: and his Counselors Outcasts and Outlaws; Examiner says Loss of Richmond Seals Doom of Confederacy; vain attempt to control Gold; and Confederacy, Fall of; Davis' Boasts
lead_paragraph: In the boastful message delivered by DAVIS to his Congress, at the close of last year, the chief of the rebel conspirators said there was no military success which could accomplish the destruction of the Southern Confederacy. "Not the fall," said he, "of Richmond, nor Wilmington, nor Charleston, nor Savannah, nor Mobile, nor of all combined, can affect the issue of the present contest."

abstract: Rise and Fall; Stevens' Bill
snippet: Rise and Fall; Stevens' Bill
lead_paragraph: Mr. THADDEUS STEVENS and his friends, who were so anxious to put down gold by acts of Congress, are, we hope, gratified by this time that they were not allowed to try the experiment. We have had for the last two or three years a large number of wiseacres who were firmly satisfied that all that was needed to keep gold down was to "punish the speculators," and that it was entirely owing to their evil machinations that it had reached the unconscionable height at which it sometimes figured. They got a chance to put their plan into execution, and carried a bill through for the purpose last year. Gold immediately rose to the highest point which it ever reached. The bill was immediately repealed -- but the mischief was done. The price of coin did not come down materially for nearly three months; and the worst of it was that the prices of all commodities had risen with it, and even in a still greater ratio, and, as usual, did not fall as it fell, and the burdens of the poor were thus greatly and suddenly increased. We venture to assert that the speculators have not in their whole career accomplished half as much mischief in the same space of time as this one piece of foolish and ignorant legislation. One good, however, resulted from it. It was thus fully, and, we believe, satisfactorily proved, that the price of gold could not be kept down, or, to speak more correctly, the price of paper kept up by penal enactments.

abstract: When our summary of war events closed yesterday, it was at the point where Gen. GRANT announced a temporary cessation of hostilities on Sunday evening. Up to that time our arms had met with almost unvarying success; save the little fillip of a reverse on the first advance beyond the Boydtown road, nothing had gone amiss.
lead_paragraph: When our summary of war events closed yesterday, it was at the point where Gen. GRANT announced a temporary cessation of hostilities on Sunday evening. Up to that time our arms had met with almost unvarying success; save the little fillip of a reverse on the first advance beyond the Boydtown road, nothing had gone amiss. The grand march was FORWARD; the stern resolve and unconquerable will of the "Northern horde', were in full activity; it was evident that our leaders had resolved to manifest our real strength -- that this was no mild reconnoissance, no holiday parade, but that every step and every manoeuvre mean: business. The hour and the man had come; the long-delayed and ardently prayed-for time was present; the day of doom for the rebellion had dawned. We have already briefly sketched the main features of the contest, from the commencement of GRANT's movement on Wednesday morning until the lull in the furious contest on Sunday afternoon. From that point the record is broken; results so grand and overwhelming as to dwarf all ordinary details, arrest the attention -- RICHMOND IS CAPTURED! The grand significance of this truth needs no interpretation -- the nation breathes freely -- the end draws nigh. This most important fact since the first gun was fired at Sumter, was announced early yesterday morning in an EXTRA TIMES, in the following brief telegram from the President: "This morning, Lieut.-Gen. GRANT reports Petersburgh evacuated, and he is confident that Richmond also is. He is pushing forward to cut off, it possible, the retreating rebel army." This glorious announcement was very soon followed by a note from the Secretary of War, which read: "It appears from a dispatch of Gen. WEITZEL, just received by this Department, that our forces under his command ARE IN RICHMOND, having taken it (Richmond) at 8 1/4 this morning." This was enough; all doubt was removed; the truth was manifest; the rebel stronghold was ours; the Libby prison, the accursed Belle Island, the capital of the arch-conspirator were under the bayonets of Union troops. The announcement was hailed with the wildest manifestations; such beaming faces, such cordial hand-shakings, and even embracings, such indifference to all other things, such haste to display some manifest token of loyalty never before occurred. All at once the city was radiant with "red, white and blue;" business was instantly suspended; even gold speculators forgot their peril, and sang and danced and made speeches, and gray-beards were boys again; Wall-street became a play-ground, and the most astonishing pranks were indulged in by staid old fogies, whose hearts for once triumphed over conventional dignity. While these astounding events were going on, a brief interruption was made -- at about 2:30 P.M. -- to read the following telegram, sent under the sanction of the War Department: "Gen. WEITZEL telegraphs as follows: 'We took Richmond at 8:15 this morning. I captured many guns. The enemy left in great haste. The city is on fire in one place. Am making every effort to put it out. The people receive us with enthusiastic expressions of joy. Gen. GRANT started early this morning with the army toward the Danville road, to cut off LEE's retreating army, if possible. President LINCOLN has gone to the front.'" This made "assurance doubly sure," and gloriously closed a day that will live with Bunker Hill and Yorktown. No such excitement has been seen in New-York since, almost four years ago, the sullen echoes of BEAUREGARD's fire upon Sumter startled the nation, and brought into the streets and marts of trade the pale faces and firm-set teeth of a betrayed and insulted people.

abstract: Almost Destroyed by Flood
snippet: Almost Destroyed by Flood
lead_paragraph: The village of New-Liberty, Ill., on the Ohio River, has been almost totally annihilated by the high water in that stream, aided by a severe gale that swept over that region on Sunday, the 12th instant. Houses were demolished, and the inhabitants driven out, until there were but two dwellings that had not been destroyed. Nearly all the houses were swept from their foundations. The damage in the town was estimated at $18,000, and in the surrounding country still greater damage was done.

abstract: and Victory
snippet: and Victory
lead_paragraph: The dawn of yesterday morning saw the solution of the mighty question which has for four years been under the discussion of the sword by the two greatest armies which have fought anywhere on the globe for the last fifty years. In the early hours of the resplendent day the flag of the Union was borne victoriously into the rebel capital and citadel which has so long withstood and defied the utmost power of our arms. The great rebel army had been driven from its works and trenches in front of Petersburgh, had been forced from the fortifications around Richmond, and was flying, in route and dismay, for the mountains and the plains, where it would but meet new and fresh forces prepared to effect its utter demolition. We may imagine from the feelings of the spectators at this distance, and all over the land, what were those of the actors on the spot -- with what enthusiasm the whole of the veteran Army of the Potomac saw that the long-sought prize was gained -- that their great struggle was crowned with success, and that the hour of final triumph and peace would soon be theirs and their country's.

abstract: Plans were matured long before Fall of Richmond
snippet: Plans were matured long before Fall of Richmond
lead_paragraph: -We have no doubt whatever that at the remarkable council at City Point last week, in which President LINCOLN, Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, and Gens. SHERMAN and SHERIDAN took part, the great movement which has resulted in the fall of Richmond was fully discussed. But we have the best of reasons for believing that the movement in nearly all its details was planned, and the time of its execution decided upon by the Lieutenant-General for weeks before the visit of Gen. SHERMAN to the James River -- indeed, before Gen. SHERMAN's army had emerged from the bogs of South Carolina. The time of its execution depended much more upon the completion of SHERIDAN's cavalry campaign from the Shenandoah Valley to Petersburgh, than upon the advance of the army of SHERMAN. Indeed, the cooperation of SHERIDAN was an essential part of the present operation; but so well assured was his success in his last campaign, and so precisely was the time of his arrival at GRANT's headquarters calculated upon, that everything was in readiness for his advent.
headline: {'main': "GRANT'S PLANS.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "GRANT'S PLANS.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Richmond
snippet: Richmond
lead_paragraph: -The City of Richmond was, after all, the last ditch. Charleston had succumbed. Wilmington and Savannah had succumbed, and every place from Norfolk to New-Orleans -- from Little Rock to Knoxville had succumbed. Now that the Confederacy has fought its last fight, in its last ditch, let it own up that it is dead.

abstract: Vallandigham Examined
snippet: Vallandigham Examined
lead_paragraph: I reside in Dayton, and am now practising law. I was a member of the Sons of Liberty. It was in Windsor, C.W., in the month of February, 1864, that this, my first connection with any secret political organization took place. Mr. GREEN and Dr. BARRETT, of whom mention has been made, in the testimony. They were on their way to New-York to attend the meeting of the Supreme Council of what was, as I understood, the American Knights. They stated there were to be some material changes, and desired I should become the chief officer of it. My answer was, that I had understood there was some such organization; that I had always declined having any connection with it, because I apprehended that it might have some connection with the Southern Government, o[???] place its members under some [???]ation with reference to that Government, inconsistent with the allegiance of a citizen of the United States, and that I would belong to none that directly or indirectly looked to any sort of connection with those who were in arms against the Federal authority. I expressed my conviction that whereas I had always opposed secret political organizations, as a member of the Democratic party, the time had come when they were useful and necessary, provided they were kept legitimate. Assurance was given me by those gentlemen that there was nothing of the king I apprehended in that Order; that a new arrangement of the organization was to be made, and that any objectionable features could be obviated: that it was only a political organization, having reference to affairs in the States that adhered to the Union and recognized the Federal Government and its authority. I accordingly consented, and investigated the principles, ceremonies and obligations of the Order. No part of any of them was read in full, but pamphlets were left with me. This was the extent to which I was a member of that Order.

lead_paragraph: Capitalists are again competing briskly with the people for the national securities, which, in view of recent "great events," and the bright prospects ahead, are regarded as the very best investments now available. The transactions in Government gold-bearing bonds at the Stock Exchange, yesterday, reached $1,423,000, including $1,320,000 worth of old and new 5-20s, which opened at 105 1/2, and closed firmly at 105 7/8. The bulk of this unusually large amount was bought for a single banking firm, whose agents likewise made very heavy purchases through the commission houses on the Street. At the close, the market for all classes of national securities was quite buoyant, with a strong upward tendency. The 7-30 Currency Loan, now open to subscription at par, is selling freely. The opening day's subscriptions this week were $2,108,300, including 1,473 orders for the $50 and $100 notes of the Loan. The subscriptions to the Loan last week reached an average of $2,381,360 per day, and the orders for the $50 and $100 notes of the Loan an average of 1,652 a day.
