abstract: The, and her Gentlemanly Captain; Waddel Capt. an "American Gentleman"
snippet: The, and her Gentlemanly Captain; Waddel Capt. an "American Gentleman"
lead_paragraph: -- The Melbourne correspondent of the London Telegraph has come across a "splendid specimen of an American gentleman." He found this lusus naturae in the person of Capt. WADDELL, of the rebel pirate Shenandoah, on board of which the correspondent was writing his puff of her master. What struck him so much in this officer was the indignation he expressed at the fate of the Florida, captured by the "rascally blackguards" of the Federal navy in Rio Janeiro. Capt. WADDELL was very emphatic and "gentlemanly" in speaking upon this subject, and intimated a very strong desire to make reprisals upon the unarmed Yankee merchantmen then lying in Melbourne Harbor; but he did not, because, said he, "the Confederates, Sir, are gentlemen, and, please God, we shall always act up to that standard!" This settled the question with the Telegraph's correspondent. He could not doubt, after that remark, that Capt. WADDELL was a "splendid specimen of an American gentleman." The Shenandoah was built in England, equipped in England, carries eight rifled Whitworth guns, of coarse made in England, and devotes herself to the gentlemanly business of robbing, plundering and burning unarmed American merchantmen at sea. This class of operations, and the gentlemen engaged in it, command a remarkable degree of admiration and respect from our neutral English brethren now-a-days; but they will have an account to settle for it before very long.

abstract: Fall of Richmond, Justifies Offer; Salt Works Destroyed by US Soldiers; Ladona Expedition
snippet: Fall of Richmond, Justifies Offer; Salt Works Destroyed by US Soldiers; Ladona Expedition
lead_paragraph: We give this morning, from our special correspondents, very interesting details of the recent battles for the possession of the rebel capital. The regular war dispatches also convey many important particulars, the wires being now working direct from City Point to Richmond. Gen. WEITZEL telegraphed early yesterday morning that he found 28 locomotives and 150 cars in the city, Gen. GRANT is said to have directed WEITZEL to allow No one to leave or enter the city except men connected with the army. On Sunday night, before the evacuation of Richmond, the rebels blew up their forts and rams on the James River, the explosion of which was terrible. Our gunboats have moved up the river, and are engaged in removing the obstructions. The rebels fired Petersburgh in several places before evacuating the town, but the fire was speedily extinguished. Gen. GRANT was, at 3 3/4 o'clock on Tuesday morning at Sutherland's Station, ten miles from Petersburgh, from which point he telegraphs that "SAERIDAN picked up twelve hundred prisoners to-day, and from three to five hundred more have been gathered by our troops. The majority of the arms that were left in the hands of LEE's army, are now scattered between Richmond and where his troops now are. The country is also full of stragglers. The line of retreat is marked with artillery, ammunition, burned or charred wagons, caissons, ambulances, &c." We are yet without definite knowledge of losses on either side, but our captures of prisoners are something wonderful. A Washington dispatch estimates that we had taken more than 25,000 up to Monday noon This figure is reduced by others to 20,000; others say 15,000 to 18,000. But this is, mainly, guesswork; GRANT has no time to make inventories. Many thousands of prisoners have already been received at City Point, and others are continually arriving. A sufficient number of troops could not be spared to guard them, and detachments of sailors and marines were taken from the gunboats and placed in charge. The destruction of property by the rebels is very great, but not equal to the general expectation. They burned some public buildings, but no attempt was made to convert Richmond into a Moscow; indeed, their haste was such that they lacked time for anything like systematic work. It is the general opinion, justified by GRANT's own position, that LEE is retreating upon the Danville Railroad, and that SHERIDAN is upon his flanks.

abstract: Captured, What Next; Overtures to Rebels may now be made
snippet: Captured, What Next; Overtures to Rebels may now be made
lead_paragraph: The capture of Richmond plucks out the very heart of the rebellion. It is not enough to say that the rebel capital has been taken. Richmond bore a much more important relation to the rebellion than that term would express. It was not merely the locality where rested the rebel government -- as Washington is the seat of the Federal Government; -- it was the great generator of the vital force of the Confederacy. The largest city in the Confederacy, since New-Orleans came into our possession; having an inherited prestige that no other could claim; the headquarters of the principal rebel army, as well as of the rebel civil administration; its press working, for the rebel cause with a vehemence and a fire, and an effectiveness incomparably beyond anything displayed elsewhere in Southern journalism; and, what is most important of all, having been so attacked and so defended from the beginning of the war, that it is associated, the world over, with the very substance of the war, and bears, as no other spot does, its "form and impress," -- Richmond came to be the very vital source of all the material energy and all the moral power of the rebellion. Its collapse is the death of the rebellion. The confederacy will hereafter exhibit no activity or sign of life, except as it is galvanized.

abstract: The aspect of the drafting question, yesterday, was far less unpromising than on any previous day. The victories in Virginia induce a notion, by no means without reason, that enlistment now is much more like an engagement to take promenade in blue at a very fair rate of wages, and much less like a covenent with death than heretofore.
lead_paragraph: The aspect of the drafting question, yesterday, was far less unpromising than on any previous day. The victories in Virginia induce a notion, by no means without reason, that enlistment now is much more like an engagement to take promenade in blue at a very fair rate of wages, and much less like a covenent with death than heretofore. The one year plan of the County Committee is also a good one, and largely economizes the funds. The subscriptions to the county loan continue to come in, though to be sure, not without some effort. The repayment from the State of bounty money, advanced by the county, is, if not formally agreed in, yet reasonably sure to be made within a few days. The efforts of the ward organizations are kept up with considerable effect.

abstract: Completeness of the National Victory
snippet: Completeness of the National Victory
lead_paragraph: The material losses inflicted upon the rebel army around Petersburgh, in men, in the equipments and munitions of war, not less than in position, have not yet been so computed that their overwhelming weight can be made at once appreciable. A careful comparison of different data gave LEE, three months ago, an army of 85,000 men. Within that period there is superabundant evidence to prove to us that this force, so formidable in numbers, and, peradventure, scarcely less formidable in its tough experience, had lost full 15,000 men. We should clearly be under, rather than over the actual number, if we set down LEE's losses, in killed and wounded, in the five day's engagements, at 10,000 more. And putting together all the returns of captured prisoners already received, we are unable, by the most moderate computation, to reduce their aggregate below 25,000. These deductions alone bring the relics of the rebel army of Virginia down to 35,000 men, without including the gangs of stragglers from that fugitive band, met with at every furlong of GRANT and SHERIDAN's pursuit. If LEE to-day has even 30,000 in his immediate command he must have found material for conscription in the line of his inglorious flight. And each succeeding sunrise can but witness not only the decline of his army in bulk, but its rapid and irreclaimable demoralization as well.

abstract: Our National, Condition of; Government and Prestige Blown to the Winds; Finances; Our
snippet: Our National, Condition of; Government and Prestige Blown to the Winds; Finances; Our
lead_paragraph: In our financial column we give an official statement of the indebtedness of the nation on last Friday, the 3lst of March, as compared with the figures of Oct. 31, 1864. The grand total of the debt on the 31st ult. was $2,366,955,077, showing an increase of $574,088,037 since July 5, 1864, when Secretary FESSENDEN succeeded Secretary CHASE. This increase has been at a comparatively moderate rate of $2,134,156 per day. The interest charge on the debt, March 31, was $102,836,531, including $64,016,631 in gold, and $38,819,899 in currency. This interest charge, as applied to the aggregate indebtedness, is at the low rate of $4 35 per cent. per annum.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen, at their meeting yesterday, adopted a resolution appointing a joint Special Committee to make preparations for celebrating the fall of Richmond.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen, at their meeting yesterday, adopted a resolution appointing a joint Special Committee to make preparations for celebrating the fall of Richmond. A communication was received from the Mayor, stating that although opposed to celebrating victories gained over our fellow citizens, he would suggest the anniversary of the birthday of JEFFERSON as a fitting occasion for a celebration that would demonstrate to the Southern people that our object is a lasting amity and not subjugation. It was referred to the committee appointed under Mr. NORTON's resolution. The City Inspector was directed to annul the contract for removing dead animals from the city, and to enter into another on more favorable terms to the city.

lead_paragraph: We give our readers this morning letters direct from the City of Richmond -- the late capital of the so-called Government of the Confederate States of America. Richmond has been the rebel capital since June, 1861; the first rebel Congress met there on the July following; at the beginning of May the rebel army stationed there numbered three thousand and seventy-two men; and the Richmond Dispatch, in announcing the advent of that "eminent body of statesmen and soldiers who compose the Montgomery Government" -- of "President JEFFERSON DAVIS, that tower of strength," "with his brilliant civic and military staff" -- and, "perhaps of the famous BEAUREGARD, to take command on an important line of operations in Virginia" -- said that thus "Richmond bade fair to become a scene of stirring interest, worthy of inaugurating the magnificent history of the future capital of the Southern Confederacy."

abstract: How will London Times Account for
snippet: How will London Times Account for
lead_paragraph: -- Some of the opposition journals, which have done all in their power to belittle our victories and depreciate the valor of our soldiers, express great curiosity and anxiety to see how the London Times and kindred sheets will receive the news of our great successes, taken out by the Australasian yesterday. Possibly the London Times and its abettors will be quite as anxious to see how the journals in this country, which have done so much to furnish them ammunition for their assaults upon everything American, manage to account for these same victories themselves.

abstract: Carme, M, French Player; Exhibition
snippet: Carme, M, French Player; Exhibition
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, at the Billiard, manufactory of Messrs. PHELAN COLLENDER, Mons. PIERRE CARMS, the great French billiard-player, whose arrival was announced in the TIMES of Tuesday, gave an exhibition of his wondrous skill, in the presence of a select audience, including representatives from the principal daily and weekly newspapers, and several of our most influential citizens. This Board met in special session at 3 o'clock on Tuesday, Mr. ROCHE in the chair. The hour announced for opening the exhibition was 4 o'clock; but, at the urgent solicitation of gentlemen who, in their anxiety to witness his performance, had arrived before the proper hour, M. CARME commenced at about 3 o'clock. The feature of the entertainment was the execution of the different varieties of the masse, and the boldness, brilliancy and originality of the artist was a theme of unbounded praise. During the first hour, particularly, M. CARME's efforts surpassed even expectation, and the accuracy with which he consummated the most difficult problems, drew forth the most flattering encomiums from such of the spectators as, having seen that other wonderful player, M. CLAUDIUS BERGER had come prepared to measure the new comer by that high standard. Although the exhibition was an impromptu affair, conceived and carried out in a few hours, and notwithstanding, also, that M. CARME played upon a table of inferior size to that with which he is familiar, and in a building where the movement of machinery was a source of continual jarring, it gave eminent satisfaction to all who participated in it, and conclusive proof that the French expert is all that had previously been claimed for him -- a player daring in conception, and brilliant and accurate in execution. He exhibited, altogether, about thirty different strokes, the majority of which were novel and striking in the extreme. It is his intention to give a moderate number of exhibitions in several of the prominent cities; the first two of which will take place at the Hall of the Cooper Union on the evenings of Tuesday and Wednesday, the 11th and 12th of April. During the succeeding week he will appear in Boston. In each of these seances he will be assisted by Messrs. PHELAN, GOLDTHWAIT, and others.

abstract: The draft was yesterday in abeyance, the number of recruits being sufficient to keep the District Provost-Marshals busy. We cannot, as has been already observed, furnish on each day the exact figures of enlistments the day before, as the returns are not consolidated in season.
lead_paragraph: The draft was yesterday in abeyance, the number of recruits being sufficient to keep the District Provost-Marshals busy. We cannot, as has been already observed, furnish on each day the exact figures of enlistments the day before, as the returns are not consolidated in season. Thus we can give this morning the number of enlistments, not on yesterday, but on Tuesday; it is 107, of whom 70 were substitutes and 47 volunteers. By districts the numbers were as follows: Fourth, 25; Fifth, 21; Sixth, 26; Seventh, 16; Eighth, 18; Ninth, 11. The figures for yesterday are not far from these.

abstract: can call the South back to the Union
snippet: can call the South back to the Union
lead_paragraph: good soldiers in any cause to acquire a personal attachment to their General, if he be able and brave, and to feel no more like abandoning him in his hour of peril than he would feel like abandoning them when danger threatened. We look for some exhibition of this spirit from a portion of LEE's veterans. There are men in his army who will probably adhere to him and fight for him to the last -- till he either makes a voluntary surrender of himself, or succeeds in effecting his escape from the country. But no part of the army has any such feeling toward JEFF. DAVIS, or any other of the civil leaders. Nor are the Southern people out of the army bound to LEE's fortunes by any such military sentiment. It is their action that is the primary concern. It they resolve to give up the Confederacy, and show this determination by their political action through their State Legislatures and their primary conventions, the mere fact that some of LEE's soldiers might do a little fighting on his account, would make no change. Such warfare, with no civil government behind it, and no popular sentiment to back it up, would quickly languish and end.

abstract: The national credit is improving rapidly in this market, influenced by the recent decisive triumphs of our army in Virginia. Pertinent proof of this is afforded by the vastly increased and rapidly increasing demand for the Gold-bearing bonds of the Government. Through the Stock Exchange, yesterday, the sales of national securities ...
lead_paragraph: The national credit is improving rapidly in this market, influenced by the recent decisive triumphs of our army in Virginia. Pertinent proof of this is afforded by the vastly increased and rapidly increasing demand for the Gold-bearing bonds of the Government. Through the Stock Exchange, yesterday, the sales of national securities reached $647,500, (making $2,070,500 in two days,) including $422,500 worth of the old and new Five-Twenties, which opened at 106 1/4, and closed at 107 1/2, an advance of 2 cent. since Monday; and $94,000 worth of the the Six cent. of 1881, at from 106@107 1/4, the latter, the closing rate, showing an advance of 2 1/4 cent. within two days. The private purchases of each class of the Six cents, through the commission houses, were also quite extensive, embracing $230,000 worth of the old Five-twenties at 107 1/4. The market closed quite strong and buoyant. The Ten-Forties sold up to 92 1/2, as against 91 1/2 on Monday. The steady and inevitable appreciation of the Gold-bearing bonds tends to stimulate the popular demand for the 7-30 Currency Loan, the aggregate subscriptions to which thus far this week have averaged $2,091,650 per day, as follows: Monday, $2,108,300; Tuesday, $2,075,000. The orders for the $50 and $100 notes of this Loan have averaged 1,486 a day. The subscriptions to the Loan last week reached an average of $2,381,360 per day, and the orders for the $50 and $100 notes of the Loan an average of 1,652 a day.

abstract: First National Convention
snippet: First National Convention
lead_paragraph: The first annual National Convention of the Unitarian Church assembled yesterday morning at the Atheneum (Dr. OSGOOD'S old church.) Nearly four hundred clerical and lay delegates were present, including many talented and well-known gentlemen. Among the delegates are Gov. Andrew and Ex-Gov. Boutwell, of Massachusetts; Hon. Ichabod Goodwin, of Portsmouth, N.H.; Rev. A.A. Livermore, President of the Theological School at Meadville, Penn.; Rev. Drs. Bellows and Osgood, and Peter Cooper, of this city, and Rev. A.P. Putnam and John W. Chadwick, of Brooklyn.

abstract: If we had no other evidence of the overwhelming nature of the rebel defeat involved in the evacuation of Richmond, the official telegrams and the special dispatches to the TIMES, which we publish to-day, would be sufficient to show that the catastrophe in the tragic record of these four years of war has been reached. The captures of guns alone -- five hundred in Richmond itself, having already come into Gen. WEITZEL's possession -- show that there was neither choice nor method left to LEE and his confederates in their mode of taking a midnight farewell of their capital.
lead_paragraph: If we had no other evidence of the overwhelming nature of the rebel defeat involved in the evacuation of Richmond, the official telegrams and the special dispatches to the TIMES, which we publish to-day, would be sufficient to show that the catastrophe in the tragic record of these four years of war has been reached. The captures of guns alone -- five hundred in Richmond itself, having already come into Gen. WEITZEL's possession -- show that there was neither choice nor method left to LEE and his confederates in their mode of taking a midnight farewell of their capital.

abstract: Government to be Transferred to Richmond
snippet: Government to be Transferred to Richmond
lead_paragraph: The letter of our special correspondent in Richmond will be read with curious interest. We can hardly blame the people for skepticism in ordinary matters connected with our victories, but doubt was carried to the extreme yesterday, and there were not a few honest people who looked upon the slight rise in gold (in the absence of any direct advices from Richmond in the morning papers) as evidence that the rebel capital had not been taken -- that the whole story was false, or at least quite premature. We trust that our own letters and official telegrams from the War Department will reassure these distrustful friends. Our correspondent says that LEE telegraphed on Sunday that GRANT had driven him a mile and a half, that he had suffered severely, held an untenable position, and requested that the city should be evacuated that night. The flight of the rebel leaders began at once -- JEFF. DAVIS is said to have heard the news while in church. He had previously sold his furniture, and was ready to go at once. Leaving Mrs. LEE behind, he started for Charlotte, N.C. Other accounts say that he started with his family the previous Wednesday -- the day GRANT began his march -- but subsequently returned to his capital. Gen. WEITZEL now occupies his house, and Gen. DEVINS resides in the house of Gov. SMITH of Virginia. Our men approached the city very cautiously on Monday morning over grouad, thick with torpedoes -- so thick that our main body marched in single file, while pioneers pointed out the dangerous places. No opposition was made to our approach; a small squadron of cavalry rode in, and Mayor MAYO handed over the keys at 7 A.M. on Monday morning. Gen. WEITZEL soon followed, and was greeted with enthusiastic cheers by citizens both white and black. The rebels set are to many important buildings, in order to burn the tobacco on storage, and most of Main-street is destroyed; but our men soon extinguished the fire. The State House, the Enquirer and Dispatch newspaper offices, and two or three bridges are burned. All the rebel magazines and gunboats were blown up. There were no Union prisoners found, all having been sent off for exchange the day before. Commissioner OULD handed to Gen. MULFORD all the papers in his possession on the subject. The departure of the rebel army after SHERIDAN's victory at Five Forks must have been very sudden, since they left all their tents behind. Our captures in Richmond amount to about one thousand rebel soldiers in health and five thousand wounded, mainly in the hospitals, with 5,000 stands of small arms, and five hundred pieces of artillery President LINCOLN visited Richmond on Tuesday, but returned yesterday to City Point. Gen. SHERMAN put his army in motion on Saturday morning, but in what direction we are not informed further than that it is moving northerly in accordance with plans arranged by Gen. GRANT.

lead_paragraph: The Army of the Potomac has been in and out of Petersburgh this morning, merely making a flying visit. abstract: I thank my fellow-citizens for the honor they do me by calling to congratulate me on the fail of Richmond. I am now about writing my foreign dispatches. What shall I tell the Emperor of China? I shall thank him, in your name, for never having permitted a piratical flag to enter the harbors of the empire. What shall I say to the Sultan of Turkey? I shall thank him for always having surrendered rebel insurgents who have taken refuge in his kingoom. What shall I say to the Emperor of the French? I shall say to the Emperor of the French that he can go to-morrow to Richmond and get his tobacco so long held under blockade there, provided the rebels have not used it up. To Lord JOHN RUSSELL I will say, that British merchants will find the cotton exported from our ports under treaty with the United States, cheaper than cotton obtained by running the blockade. As for Earl RUSSELL himself, I need not tell him that this is a war for freedom and national independdnce, and the rights of human nature, and not a war for empire; and if Great Britain should only be just to the United States, Canada will remain undisturbed by us, so long as she prefers the authority of the noble Queen to voluntary incorporation in the United States. What shall I tell the King of Prussia? I will tell the King of Prussia that the Germans have been faithful to the standard of the Union, as his excellent Minister, Baron GEROLT, has been constant in his friendship to the United States during his long residence in this country. To the Emperor of Austria I shall say that he has proved himself a very wise man, for he told us in the beginning that he had no sympathy with rebellion anywhere. I do not doubt, fellow-citizens, but that at least you accede to the theory by which I have governed myself during the war namely, that the rebellion will end in ninety days. I have thought this the true theory, because I never knew a physician able to restore his patient to health unless he thought he could work a cure under the most favorable circumstances in ninety days. Finally, if the American people approve, I will say that our motto in peace shall be what our text has been while in war. Every nation is entitled to regulate its own domestic affairs in its own way, and all are bound to conduct themselves so as to promote peace on earth and good will to mankind.

abstract: -- The Crown Prosecutor for Lower Canada professes to have found it impossible to get a judicial certificate in that section of the colony for the extradition of the St. Albans robbers. They are now to be tried under a provincial statute for a breach of neutrality. The trial has been transferred to Upper Canada, where it is probably, assumed that there is still some respect paid to international obligations.

lead_paragraph: The Panama Star Herald of March 21 states that on Thursday evening, the 19th ult., the longtalked-of revolution against the State government broke out in Panama. It was a quiet affair, the whole matter being settled in a few minutes, by the actual President. Senor CALANCHA, abandoning his post and taking refuge in the United States Consulate until he had a chance to escape about midnight on board the United States sloop-of-war St. Marys, the arrest of the leading members of his administration, and the assumption of the Presidential chair by the candidate of the revolutionary party, Senor JIL COLUNJE. The national troops, the militia, and the population generally, appear to have been on the same side. The Commander of the national forces was arrested in the street at the outbreak, and the Captain of the forces made a show of supporting the government, but as neither his officers nor his men stood by him, he soon gave himself up. Four or five soldiers were killed, rather by accident than otherwise; and a good deal of alarm existed for a time. Senor COLUNJE was duly sworn in at noon on the 20th, at the Cabildo, as Provisional President of the State. On the 17th an armed force was dispatched from Panama to Aspinwall to establish the provisional government there. On the arrival of the men they were met by the Prefect, Senor BRACHO, who opposed them with the small police force under his charge, and in the encounter three of the latter were killed. The Department was then handed over to the new government. On the same day a force was sent to Veraguas and Chiriqui with a similar object. It is expected there will be bloodshed in the latter place, as that is the Ex-President's native State. In Panama everything is quiet and no further trouble is anticipated.

lead_paragraph: The Etna arrived last evening with four days later news from Europe. Political news is unimportant. The British law-makers are still uneasy about American affairs, and inquiries were made in Parliament as to steps taken to protect the property of British subjects in the Southern States. The answer of Mr. LAYARD is hesitating and muddy; all he could say was that the Washington Government had that British subjects would find no obstruction in prosecuting legitimate claims. Some members, alluding to the probability of a was with America, declare than Great Britain was worse off now than when they began the war of 1812; that America was was under great obligations to England for remaining neutral in this revolution, because if England had taken part with the Confederates, she might not only have protected Canada, but have put an end to "the atrocious Munroe doctrine." LAIRD's last rebel ram is to be a British man-of-war. The Oesterrichische Zeitung, of Vienna, asserts that the negotiations at Washington between the agents of the Emperor MAXIMIMIAN and Mr. SEWARD are progressing satisfactorily. It reiterates the statement that Mr. LINCOLN has promised to recognize the new empire at tRe termination of the present war.

lead_paragraph: About three hundred persons, most of them amateurs, last night assembled at GOLDTHWAIT & CAHILL's little arena, over their rooms on the Sixthavenue, to witness the long-promised contest betwen Messrs. GOLDTHWAIT and WICKS. It proved truly a remarkable game, and, no doubt, caused considerable money to change hands. For years Mr. WICKS has played like games with all the most celebrated professionals in the country, and has usually come out ahead. It will be remembered that he made an easy victim of MELVIN FOSTER, in the same room a few weeks since.

abstract: In Senate, yesterday, bills were passed incorporating the Soldiers' Messenger Corps; amending the charter of the Manhattan Gas Company; incorporating the New-York Pier and Warehousing Company; to amend the charter of Troy relative to schools.
lead_paragraph: In Senate, yesterday, bills were passed incorporating the Soldiers' Messenger Corps; amending the charter of the Manhattan Gas Company; incorporating the New-York Pier and Warehousing Company; to amend the charter of Troy relative to schools. The bill amending the Registry Law was ordered to a third reading; the Broadway Tunnel Railroad Bill was reported; the bill amending the act relative to the Harlem Bridge was then taken up, and JOHN M. DODD, GEORGE R. JACKSON and WM. ROBERTSON were appointed commissioners; the bill was then ordered to a third reading. Mr. FIELDS introduced a bill authorizing an increase of the interest of 7 per cent. on New-York Riot bonds. The bill authorizing the incorporations of clubs and societies for certain social and recreative purposes, was passed. The bill authorizing the Second-avenue Railroad Company to lay new tracks was ordered to a third reading.

abstract: The Retreat and Rout of
snippet: The Retreat and Rout of
lead_paragraph: Late on Wednesday night, the War Department was in communication, by telegraph, with a portion of the advance of our army at Burkesville Station, (the junction of the Southside and Danville Railroads.) SHERIDAN, with the main body of his cavalry, at 3 P.M. of that day, was at Jetersville, on the Danville road, a station forty-three miles from Richmond LEE, at the same date, with the remnants of his army, was at Amelia Court-house -- a point thirty-six miles from Richmond, and seven miles north of SHERIDAN's advance. And on Wednesday evening, as appears from an intercepted letter of a rebel officer, LEE's army was drawn up in line of battle.

abstract: -- In the Fourth avenue cars is posted a list of instructions for conductors. One item is, that they are to "stand constantly on the rear platform, with their backs to the car, looking out for passengers." This may all be very well for the company, but how about the passengers already secured? The company have placed the cord which rings the bell out of the reach of the passengers, and it is quite impossible to catch the conductor's eye while he is obeying the orders of the company. Half the time women and others are carried two or three blocks beyond their destination, because they can't reach the bell-pull, and the conductor is "standing on the rear platform with his back to the car."

snippet: Marechal, Fr Com of Vera Cruz, Defeated and Killed; The Rapid Destruction of; The Destruction of; How destroyed; Destruction of Rebel Armies
lead_paragraph: It is not wonderful that at first thought there should be some incredulity about the sudden destruction which has overtaken LEE'S army. That a veteran army, whose estimated strength only a few weeks since was between seventy-five and eighty-five thousand men, should be so suddenly and disastrously demolished, is sufficiently remarkable to cause astonishment.

abstract: FUNERAL OF THE FIREMEN KILLED AT THE FURMAN-STREET CONFLAGRATION. The flags of all the public buildings in the city, and some private residences, were displayed at half-mast yesterday, out of respect to the memory of the disaster in Furman-street. The engine houses were draped in mourning.
lead_paragraph: FUNERAL OF THE FIREMEN KILLED AT THE FURMAN-STREET CONFLAGRATION. -- The flags of all the public buildings in the city, and some private residences, were displayed at half-mast yesterday, out of respect to the memory of the disaster in Furman-street. The engine houses were draped in mourning. Four bodies were conveyed to their last resting places -- those of ALEXANDER S. BENSON, of Niagara Hose, No. 8, and LOUIS C. GARDINER, of Franklin Hose, No. 5, in the morning; and those of CASPER R. CAMMEYGER, of Mechanics Hose, No. 2, and EUGENE P. BAKER, of Water Witch Hose, No. 8, in the afternoon. The remains of BENSON were taken from his parents' residence, No. 271 Jay-street, to the Church of St. Charles Boromeo, in Sidney-place, where a solemn requiem high mass was offered for the repose of his soul. The body was then carried to the Cemetery of the Holy Cross for interment. The body of GARDINER was taken from his brother's residence, Hon. THOS. A. GARDINER, No. 167 Johnson-street, to the Church of the Assumption, corner of York and Jay streets, where a solemn requiem high mass was also offered, and, after the services, was conveyed to the family vault in St. Patrick's Cathedral, New-York City. The funeral services of the late Mr. CAMMEYER were held at his father's house, No. 27 Stanton-street, and those of Mr. BAKER at his parents' residence, No. 286 Pearl-street. Both bodies were conveyed to Greenwood Cemetery, accompanied by delegations from every fire, company in the city. The processions met on Court-street, opposite City Hall, and the Hall bell toiled solemnly as they marched along to the grave. The same respect was shown to the deceased whose funerals took place in the morning. The sight was a most affecting one as the long line of mourners passed quietly through the streets. The funeral of the late JOSEPH H. BROWN, the last of the victims thus far, will take place to-day.

abstract: Adela, S. S.; Officers of
snippet: Adela, S. S.; Officers of
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Pensacola will be towed to-day or early to-morrow from the Navyyard to Baltimore, by the United States steamers Adela and Calypso. The Pensacola, on arriving at Baltimore, will receive her machinery, which was manufactured at that place. The three vessels are already lying in the stream. The following is a list of the officers of the Adela: Acting Master Commanding, Edwin Coffin; Acting Ensigns, J.H. Goodwin, Albert C. Davis, Wm.H. Dumont, C.M. Jones, Ed. C. Remington; Acting Assistant Paymaster, George E. Martin; Acting First Assistant Engineer, George M. Bennett; Acting Second Assistant Engineers, H.C. White, Fred. A. Hutchinson; Acting Third Assistant Engineer, Aaron Varslow. The following is a list of the officers of the Calypso: Acting Volunteer Commander, Louis K. Shodder; Acting Ensigns, W.H. Fogg, Henry J. Dunn, George C. Cassidy, Harry D. Whittemore; Acting Assistant Paymaster, Dominick Batione; Acting First Assistant Engineer, B.F. Hann; Acting Second Assistant Engineers, E. Minne, O.S. abstract: Barbarous Burning by Rebels; Resistance Continued; Consequences of
snippet: Barbarous Burning by Rebels; Resistance Continued; Consequences of
lead_paragraph: The news of the deliberate, reckless and barbaric conduct of the rebel troops in burning the public buildings of Richmond, their destruction of private property, of which they have proclaimed themsleves the special protectors, the reappearance of gangs of their pirates in an estuary of the Chesapeake close to Baltimore so late as Tuesday, and, above all, the apparent decision of LEE to permit the regular warfare which has been under his sole control to degenerate, as it must henceforth do, into vagabond raids by gangs of freebooters, most surely tends to keep alive feelings of vengeance which a prompt surrender would have eradicated forever. The tone of every loyal journal of influence in the country, the public exhortations of the clergy of nearly every denomination, the general tone of public opinion among us in its less formal utterances, have made it thoroughly apparent to the South and to the world at large, that the last thought in the public mind is that of enmity or revenge. But it is well that the Southern people -- especially those who can still communicate with LEE and his confederates -- should be apprised of the fact, that if bitter and vengeful feelings be again revived, it will be due solely to these mad efforts to prolong a warfare which must have become divested -- with the dispersion of the rebel government -- of every element of regularity and responsibility.

abstract: Jersey City People's Convention and Ticket
snippet: Jersey City People's Convention and Ticket
lead_paragraph: -- A meeting of the men of all parties was held last evening at old Washington Hall, in Montgomery-street, Jersey City, for the purpose of uniting on a People's ticket for city officers. There was a large gathering present. Alderman QUAIFE occupied the chair, and PETER POST acted as Secretary. A Nominating Committee was appointed, who reported the following ticket, which was adopted: For Mayor, Alderman J.M. PANGBORN, (Rep.;) for Water Commissioner, Ex-Mayor JOHN B. ROMAR, (Dem.;) for Chief of Police, JOSEPH MCMANNUS, (Dem.;) for School Superintendent, Rev. Mr. PARMLY, (Rep.) During speeches by Mr. WALVERT and Maj. PANGBORN, there was considerable interruption and confusion by the adherents of Mayor CLEVELAND and the other Democratic nominees. Subsequently an adjourned meeting of the delegates to the Republican City Convention was held at the hall corner of Jersey and Newark avenues, and the People's nominees were adopted unanimously.

abstract: Gov Fenton's Proclamation for Thanksgiving; Proc on Fall of Richmond; Gov Fenton's Proc on Thanks. Fall Richmond
snippet: Gov Fenton's Proclamation for Thanksgiving; Proc on Fall of Richmond; Gov Fenton's Proc on Thanks. Fall Richmond
lead_paragraph: Richmond has fallen. The wicked men who governed the so-called Confederate States, have fled their capital, shorn of their power and influence. The rebel armies have been defeated, broken and scattered, and the formidable character of the rebellion is apparently at an end. Victory everywhere attends our banners, and our armies, under Providence, are rapidly moving to the closing scenes of the war. Through the self-sacrifice and heroic devotion of our soldiers, the life of the Republic has been saved, and the integrity of the American Union maintained.

abstract: Volunteering going on
snippet: Volunteering going on
lead_paragraph: -- The work of recruiting for the army goes on well. Indeed there is no reason why it should not. According to all appearances the war is nearly over. Its heaviest and bloodiest battles have been already fought. Those who enlist now may reasonably count on easy service and little danger. Bounties, before very long will inevitably fall, and the only way to secure those now promised is to enlist at once. The government is wise in filling up the quota. It is well to give the rebels to understand that we are prepared for any contingency; we shall keep our ranks full, whether we have any work for them or not.
headline: {'main': 'VOLUNTEERS FOR THE WAR.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'VOLUNTEERS FOR THE WAR.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Montevideo invested, land and sea, by Brazil forces
snippet: Montevideo invested, land and sea, by Brazil forces
lead_paragraph: News from Uraguay is to the middle of February. Montevideo was invested by a Brazilian army of 13,000 men and 20 vessels; the land defences were strong, but those of the water side were weak; they are garrisoned by about 5,000 men. While the government was determined upon a desperate defence, the foreign residents were in a great state of alarm, mainly through fear that the powder magazine might be exploded, which would be certain to destroy nearly the entire city. The Paraguayans had taken the town of Miranda, dispersing the Brazilian garrison.

lead_paragraph: Official and general dispatches from GRANT'S army and from Richmond continue to bring us good news. Our troops got possession of Burkesville, the place of junction of the Richmond and Danville, and Petersburgh and Lynchburgh Railroads, on Wednesday afternoon. SHERIDAN himself states that reinforcements were coming to him, and he feels confident of capturing LEE's army. GRANT was, at last advices, only a few miles east of Burkesville, and SHERIDAN was operating north of GRANT. No junction between LEE and JOHNSTON is possible, and the retreat of the rebel Army of Virginia must be toward Lynchburgh and the mountains.

abstract: The reports more than once made in both morning and evening papers, that money from the State has been furnished to Mr. BLUNT, are erroneous. Comptroller BRENNAN, yesterday, received the first of the amount to be refunded by the State to the County to replace county expenditures for bounties, ...
lead_paragraph: The reports more than once made in both morning and evening papers, that money from the State has been furnished to Mr. BLUNT, are erroneous. Comptroller BRENNAN, yesterday, received the first of the amount to be refunded by the State to the County to replace county expenditures for bounties, being $50,000 in cash. It is promised that an additional sum of $200,000 in State bonds shall be lodged with him to-day, but it had not been so lodged yesterday. These bonds must of course be sold in order to afford money for recruiting; and measures are already taken by Comptroller BRENNAN, which have secured the sale of a portion of them. The whole amount thus received is a quarter of a million; but the amount actually paid out by the county for recruits, and which is due from the State under the same rule, is toward three million dollars.

abstract: PETER COOPER writes a letter warmly approving the new Fire Department Law, and returning his thanks to the Senate and Assembly for passing it. He says; "There is nothing, in my opinion, that will so effectually aid us to bring about a good government in our city as a law that will join in one body the Police and Fire Department, and make it the dollar and cent interest of the whole body to faithfully perform their duty."
lead_paragraph: PETER COOPER writes a letter warmly approving the new Fire Department Law, and returning his thanks to the Senate and Assembly for passing it. He says; "There is nothing, in my opinion, that will so effectually aid us to bring about a good government in our city as a law that will join in one body the Police and Fire Department, and make it the dollar and cent interest of the whole body to faithfully perform their duty."

abstract: Proclamation Offering Terms of Peace; Magnanimity to rebels now safe and wise; Proclamation to Southern People now Proper
snippet: Proclamation Offering Terms of Peace; Magnanimity to rebels now safe and wise; Proclamation to Southern People now Proper
lead_paragraph: While the military strength of the rebellion remained unbroken, we opposed, as unwise and unnecessary, any proffers of peace to the rebel leaders, or any ostentatious tender of "terms" to the rebel army. So long as the rebel government held its seat in the capital, and was backed up by the compact and powerful army of Gen. LEE, the great mass of the rebels had something at once to lean upon and to fear. They were, willingly or unwillingly, subjects of that government, and any step they might take toward breaking away from their allegiance to it would subject them to such punishment as absolute and irresponsible power, driven to desperation, of necessity inflicts. The one indispensable condition for their return to the Union was the destruction of the rebel army: until that was accomplished, all proffers of peace from us seemed to them like mockery, and all tenders of mercy were far more likely to sting and exasperate than to win over to the Union cause.

abstract: MISS HARDINGE'S LECTURE. Miss EMMA HARDINGE delivered an eloquent and instructive lecture last evening at Cooper Institute, on "Reconstruction." She denounced the Southern aristocracy, the subservient Democracy of the North, and the curse of slavery.
lead_paragraph: MISS HARDINGE'S LECTURE. -- Miss EMMA HARDINGE delivered an eloquent and instructive lecture last evening at Cooper Institute, on "Reconstruction." She denounced the Southern aristocracy, the subservient Democracy of the North, and the curse of slavery. When the strife of battle shall have ceased, she said, we would have to decide whether the country was to be governed by e democratic or aristocratic form of government; we would also have to decide the status or the foreigner and of the negro. She did not believe that in acquiring the elective franchise the negro would attain a position higher than that belonging to him by virtue of his intellect and his moral worth. At the conclusion of her lecture, Miss HARDINGE gave notice that on the 14th inst. she would lecture at Dodworth Hall on "Politics and the Pulpit," when a portion of the evening will be devoted to answering such questions as may be propounded by persons in the audience.

abstract: Trade may now be Revived
snippet: Trade may now be Revived
lead_paragraph: All the great Southern cities and centres of population are now in our hands, and the flag of the Union waves over all the seaports of the Atlantic coast. Now that the great armies of the rebels, and the military power of the Confederacy are nearly effectually demolished, there will not much longer be any necessity or avail in maintaining any of the severe restrictions that originated with the blockade, or in continuing the rigid anti-trade orders of military commanders. After the demolition of the armies of LEE and JOHNSTON, there will be no coherent rebel forces in existence, and little danger of any further organized resistance, on a large scale, to the Union power, and there will be no chance of any goods being imported or used for rebellious purposes. Take, for instance, the States of North Carolina and Virginia. With our troops in possession of Fayetteville, Raleigh, Goldsboro, Wilmington, Newbern, and all the seaboard of North Carolina, what possibility would there be of any organized rebel force existing in any part of the State? And in Virginia, with the possession of Norfolk, Richmond, Fredericksburgh, Lynchburgh, Burkesville and Danville, no rebellious army could maintain itself. The bringing about of public order and security would be a matter of a very short time, and would be effected in great measure by the people of the different counties and towns. Nothing would tend more to this than the inducement of activity by the revival of trade and commerce. The people should be invited and encouraged to bring their products into the cities, and should be protected in legitimate traffic. There are undoubtedly immense quantities of the great Southern staples now in the South -- cotton, rice, tobacco, and the naval stores of North Carolina. Our army saw vast amounts of naval stores in the region along the Cape Fear River, and there is no reason why these should not be all gotten out now at once. The people of Wilmington, Goldsboro, and all other parts of North Carolina, have welcomed the advent of our army; and the greater part of them have shown their willingness to take the oath of allegiance at once. Great quantities of cotton can also be gotten out very speedily, by way of Savannah and Mobile, if we adopt the proper measures. There is no sufficient reason why trade with the Southern cities and the Southern country should not immediately be greatly enlarged, and in a few months Southern staples may flow forth to enrich the land, enlarge the general prosperity, and strengthen the public credit. Already in this city, and at other Eastern ports, many ocean steamers are being fitted up, in anticipation of a general resumption of trade with the seaport cities of the South.

abstract: Barnum, Zenas, of Baltimore
snippet: Barnum, Zenas, of Baltimore
lead_paragraph: A wide circle of friends and acquaintances will regret to read the announcement of the death, on Wednesday morning, at Baltimore, of ZENAS BARNUM, Esq., long connected with the hotel that bore his name in that city. Mr. BARNUM was a native of Pennsylvania, and, we believe, by profession a civil engineer. He possessed fine business capacities, and after realizing a handsome fortune in the management of his hotel, he relinquished it, to devote his time, as President, to the resuscitation of the Baltimore Central Railroad, a task that he soon and effectually accomplished. He was also among the earliest, in connection with Hon. AMOS KENDALL, WILLIAM M. SWAIN, Esq., and others, to venture his money and time to the establishment of the magnetic telegraph -- an enterprise that derived great advantage from his excellent judgment and talent in adapting details to practical results. His high integrity of purpose which, as President of the pioneer line, he infused through all the operations of the new business, also did much to command that public confidence so essential to success, Mr. BARNUM was the first President of the present American Telegraph Company, and was an active director in it, as well as President of the old "Magnetic Company" at the time of his death. He was connected with various improvements in his own State and in Virginia, and was ever among the foremost with his capital and his great business qualifications to encourage and aid every public improvement. We knew him well as a most worthy man. He was domestic in his habits, and kindly disposed to all. -- Philadelphia Ledger, April 5.

abstract: Return to New-York
snippet: Return to New-York
lead_paragraph: The China brings dates to the 26th ult. Sir FREDERICK BRUCE, the new Minister from Great Britain to the United States, is a passenger. There have been important debates in Parliament on the Canadian Reciprocity Treaty and American affairs generally, the principal speakers being Earl RUSSELL, Lord PALMERSTON, Mr. BRIGHT, Mr. LAYARD, Mr. DISRAELI and Gen. PEEL. SMITH DOUGLAS & CO., of London, and JAMES SMITH & CO., of Liverpool -- one establishment -- have suspended. Liabilities 300,000 to 400,000 sterling. The King of Belgium is on a visit to Queen VICTORIA at Windsor. Paris advices state that the rebel ram Stonewall quitted Ferrol on the 21st, accompanied to sea by a Spanish frigate. The United States frigates Niagara and Sacramento immediately followed. The expectation of a fight caused immense excitement among the Spanish population, but the Stonewall, finding no chance to escape, returned to port. Capt. JAMES ANDERSON, of the Cunard mail steamer China, has been appointed to command the Great Eastern during the laying of the Atlantic Telegraph Cable. The Great Eastern will sail from Valencia, Ireland, about the 1st of July, and may be expected at Heart's Content, Trinity Bay, by the middle of that month. It is expected that Europe and America will be in telegraphic communication before the 20th July. The news from the Continent is generally unimportant.

abstract: Army of; The Rout of
snippet: Army of; The Rout of
lead_paragraph: The official telegrams to-day give abundant indication that Lieut.-Gen. GRANT is still engaged with tremendous vigor in the work of demolishing the army of LEE. Three corps of our infantry, with the cavalry under Gen. SHERIDAN, were actively and immediately operating against him, on Thursday, near Amelia Court-house; and two of these corps, the Second and Sixth, under Gens. HUMPHREY and WRIGHT, succeeded in forcing LEE to action, the result of which was the rout of the enemy, the capture of EWELL, and other general officers, and many prisoners and guns.

lead_paragraph: The new State Government for Tennessee was organized in Nashville on the 3d inst., with Parson BROWNLOW as Governor. Petitions are in circulation in Memphis and other cities, asking the President to declare that Tennessee is no longer an insurrectionary State, and that the tax on goods from Northern States shall be remitted by the Treasury Department. Gen. WASHBURNE, the military commander of Memphis, in order to facilitate the restoration of new free State Government, has ordered the military and Provost-Marshals in his department to confine their attention to military offenders and hand over all other cases to the civil authorities.

abstract: Relations; Sir F Bruce, Arrival of
snippet: Relations; Sir F Bruce, Arrival of
lead_paragraph: Sir FREDERICK BRUCE arrived yesterday by the China. The time of his arrival is, in a certain sense, auspicious. Much of the labor that fell to the lot of his predecessor, will probably be spared him. At least, he will be relieved of that portion of the daily task that devolved upon Lord LYONS -- of reporting to the British Foreign Office the progress and prospects of the war. His first official report will probably embrace a survey of the closing incidents of the great rebellion, and the series of victories by which the end thereof was finally reached.

lead_paragraph: THE LATE FIRE. -- Another victim to the recent conflagration is Furman-street was consigned to his final resting place yesterday morning. His name was JOHN H. BROWN, of No. 17 Engine Company. The funeral services took place at his father's residence, No. 19 Concord-street, and were conducted by Rev. Dr. ROBINSON, of the First Presbyterian Church. The remains were conveyed to Cypress Hill Cemetery for interment. At the request of the parents of deceased, there was no demonstration by the firemen.

abstract: Generals; Havoc among
snippet: Generals; Havoc among
lead_paragraph: -- Fearful havoc has been made among LEE's leading officers as well as among their subordinates and the rank and file of the army. His most trusted lieutenants in all the operations of the last two years have been A.P. HILL, EWELL, LONGSTREET and EARLY. HILL was killed on Sunday last; EWELL is a prisoner in our hands; EARLY is a fugitive in the mountains; and LONGSTREET seems to have been worth very little since he was wounded in the Wilderness last year. It is a fact moreover that the past year or two seems to have developed no officers, in subordinate positions, able to take the places of these notable rebel chiefs. Capable officers and leaders have been becoming more plentiful on the Union side, while among the rebels they have almost all disappeared.

abstract: Trotter, Jonathan, Second Mayor of Brooklyn
snippet: Trotter, Jonathan, Second Mayor of Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: A fair business was transacted yesterday in Government gold-bearing Bonds, which closed more firmly. Through the Stock Exchange the sales were $327,500, making the average for four days $706,375 a day, including $189,500 worth of the old and new Five-Twenties, at from 107@107 1/4; $40,000 worth of the Six cents. of 1881, at 107 3/8; and $98,000 worth of Ten-Forties, at 92 1/8@92 1/4. The China, from Liverpool, brought considerable orders for the Five-Twenties, unlimited as to price and the currency rate of Exchange; and private purchases were made on these advices to the extent of at least half a million dollars. The private purchases of Government Bonds through the commission houses on Wall-street have averaged over $1,000,000 a day since Monday last, mainly in execution of orders from buyers for permanent investment. The principal brokers in Government Securities do not anticipate the return of more than one or two million dollars' worth of the Gold-bearing Bonds from Europe, and even this small amount only in response to New-York orders sent out in advance of the recent decisive triumphs of our arms in Virginia. Leading street operators anticipate the receipt of large foreign orders for our National Securities, by the steamers from Europe, toward the close of the current month of April, which will bring an emphatic response to the glorious intelligence of the fall of Richmond and Petersburgh, and the "collapse" of the psuedo Confederacy. The latest London quotations for the Five-Twenties received by the China, at this port, were 53 1/2@53 3/4, accompanied by a report of an active demand for the bonds at these figures. Much higher rates are looked for by later arrivals.

abstract: Proclamation for Thanksgiving April 20
snippet: Proclamation for Thanksgiving April 20
lead_paragraph: The city was greatly excited yesterday over a report that LEE's army had surrendered, but the joy wss premature; it was FITZ HUGH LEE, and not the General-in-Chief, who had succumbed; at least such was the ultimate story -- from Philadelphia. But there was enough of genuine newsto keep up the joyful fever of patriotism which has marked every day and hour since GRANT begun his last glorious campaign. Our dispatches make it very clear if not already at the point of surrender, LEE will very soon be brought to that alternative; the unremitting blows of SHERIDAN's avenging sword are too powerful to be endured; the rebels have not time to form an effective line of battle before our troopers are upon them, and another disorderly rout is the result. SHERIDAN reports at 11 1/4 P.M. of Thursday: "The enemy made a stand at the intersection of the Burkes Station road with the road upon which they were retreating. I attacked them with divisions of the Sixth Army Corps, and routed them handsomely, making a connectiion with the cavalry. I am still pressing on with both cavalry and infantry. Up to the present time we have captured Gens. Ewell, Kershaw, Button, Corse; De Barre, Curtis, Lee, several thousand prisoners, fourteen pieces of artillery, with caissons and a large number of wagons. If the thing is pressed, I think Lee will surrender. As for the "pressing" we may safely leave GRANT and SHERIDAN alone for that. Further dispatches from Gens. MEADE, HUMPHREYS and WRIGHT give details of operations on Thursday, all of which were in every way favorable to our arms. MEADE says: "It is evident that to-day's work is going to be one of the most important of the recent brilliant operations." HUMPHREYS says: "Our last fight, just before dark, at Sailors' Creek, gave us two guns, three flags, considerable numbers of prisoners, 200 wagons, 70 ambulances, with mules and horses to about one-half the wagons and ambulances." WRIGHT says: "The result has been a complete success." And so the good work goes on.

abstract: Credit; Popular Faith in
snippet: Credit; Popular Faith in
lead_paragraph: -- Beside our great military victories, there is a national financial victory recorded in our columns daily, under the caption of the Seven-thirty Loan. Large capitalists invest large sums; and great numbers of small capitalists are ceaselessly investing small sums. About two thousand people daily invest each their fifty or a hundred dollars; and these subscriptions represent farmers, mechanics, laborers, apprentices, soldiers, women, and people of all ages and conditions of life, resident in every State of the Union, North and South. There are subscriptions from Louisiana and Arkansas, as well as from Maine and Iowa; from South Carolina and Virginia, as well as from New-York and California. The people have faith in the government, faith in the national credit, faith in the national future. This faith is as firm as their faith in themselves, and will be as enduring. When they repudiate their own character, their own history, their own interest, their own honor, and their own hopes, they will repudiate the national obligations, but not before that.

abstract: Rawson vs Penn R Co; What is Baggage
snippet: Rawson vs Penn R Co; What is Baggage
lead_paragraph: Dorothea Rawson vs. The Pennsylavania Railroad Company. -- The plaintiff in the action, is the wife of Mr. Rawson, a weathly retired merchant of this city, and she brought the action in her own name to recover the sum of about $4,000 from the company under the following circumstances, to wit: At an early hour on the morning of the 21st of September, 1864, a night express train running from Pittsburgh to Philadelphia, collided with a coal train which was standing on the track of the defendants at a station known as Thompsontown, about halfway between the two cities named. The engine, tender, baggage car and two or three passenger cars of the express train ran almost through the coal train, and were nearly demolished, and afterward wholly destroyed by a fire which had ignited on account of the collision. The destruction of life, limb and property resulting therefrom, was truly frightful. The readers of the TIMES will recollect the heart-rending scene which took place, where a mother and four young children were actually consumed in a partially buried car, simply because there were no means at hand to quench the flames or to extricate them from their terrible situation.

snippet: The Grand Old Army of the
lead_paragraph: The Army of the Potomac has done its work. It has captured Richmond, it has demolished LEE. Its unparalleled trials have been rewarded by uoparalleled success. What a history since that May night four years ago, when SHERMAN crossed his advance battery over the Long Bridge into the "sacred soil." What chapters of bloody grapple, of toilsome marching, of weary beleaguerment.

abstract: Rebel Ram, at Ferrol, declines to Fight
snippet: Rebel Ram, at Ferrol, declines to Fight
lead_paragraph: The Franco-Danish rebel ram, Stonewall, has disappointted the "sympathizers" in Europe. On the 21st ultimo, the Spanish Government gave the pirate the convoy of a frigate to enable her to quit Ferrol harbor without molestation from our fleet. This friendly act was not as successful as it was possibly meant to be. The Stonewall and the Spanish convoy were closely followed by the Niagara and Sacramento. The pirate refused to part company with his protector. Our naval commanders wisely restrained themselves from separating the two by force, and both were permitted to return to the harbor of Ferrol unmolested. There, also, our fleet is again anchored, and the status quo is resumed. The question how long -- in the present condition of Confederate belligerency here -- the European Governments that have extended over these pirates the immunities of privateers, can venture upon the continuance of this species of neutrality, must come up anon for executive deliberation. Pending that, there are two important duties incumbent upon the United States naval commander at Ferrol. The first of these is, that, under no contingency, shall this new piratical scourge be allowed to get out upon the high seas. The second is that he shall steer clear, as he has done in this instance, of an avoidable quarrel with the Spanish Government.

abstract: The
snippet: The
lead_paragraph: It is not remarkable, but it is worthy of remark, that they are the same people and papers who have for four years been showing their want of faith in the nation by declaring that we could never put down the rebellion, who are now trying to induce a want of faith in the national credit and depreciate the public securities, by declaring that we can never sustain the debt. They have simply changed their policy; but their purpose is the same. Our military victories have been too decisive for them to continue to show the impossibility of the success of the Union arms; but they can still, for a while yet, injure the country by assailing its credit. It is true that the Seven-Thirty victories are hard for them to explain away, and the Five-Twenty triumphs in Europe cannot be overlooked, and the Internal Revenue successes are great and growing. But still they have forebodings, and still they croak. They have for years been pointing us to the vast and ferocious armies of hundreds of thousands of rebels, and telling us we could never subdue them; but now, when that is nearly accomplished, they point us to the hundreds of millions of debt, and tell us we can never subdue that. As surely as we have achieved the one, however, just so certainly shall we accomplish the other. Neither the rebellion nor its cost will crush this nation, which has power and vitality enough to dispose of both, though twice as large. A sanguine Senator, who has his home in the setting sun, prophesied, when first the gigantic power of this rebellion appeared, that it would be crushed out by the close of Mr. LINCOLN's first term, and its expense paid by the close of the second. Time has already Justified the first part of what seemed then a very wild prophecy; and though the second part will not be fully realized, we have no doubt that by the time indicated, the financial problem will be as simple of solution as the military one now is.

abstract: Spurgcon, Mr; Singular Lecture
snippet: Spurgcon, Mr; Singular Lecture
lead_paragraph: A divorce suit has been tried, instituted by Col. POLLARD -- a brother of Mr. POLLARD-URQUHART, M.P. -- to obtain a divorce from his wife on the ground of her adultery with a Mr. HEMMING. Mrs. POLLARD was engaged to Mr. HEMMING before she became acquainted with the Colonel, but the engagement was broken off in consequence, it appears, of some quarrel between her brother and Mr. HEMMING. The brother, Mr. DYSART, afterward introduced Col. POLLARD to his sister, and was anxious that she should marry him. They were married in 1850, and went out to India together. There is no reason to suppose that, at this time, the Colonel knew that his wife had ever been engaged to Mr. HEMMING. In 1861 Mrs. POLLARD's health gave way, and, for the second time during her married life she had to come to England. Mr. HEMMING then began to visit her. This he did almost daily for some time. At last, when the Colonel came home, toward the end of 1863, he found his wife had eloped, leaving a note behind her owning that she had been untrue to him, and saying that, by the time her note reached him, she would be at sea, hundreds of miles away. She afterwards wrote to her sister, saying she had gone thousands of miles away from home with the man who had loved her, and whom she had loved, sixteen years ago. Col. POLLARD could not find out where they were till August, 1864, when he ascertained that they were living together as man and wife near Barking, in Essex. There was no defence to the charge of adultery, but the counsel on both sides addressed the jury on the question of damages. For the Colonel, it was contended that Mr. HEMMING, as a man of honor, ought not to have renewed his acquaintance with Mrs. POLLARD while she was without her husband's protection; and that, having abused the opportunity afforded him by his previous acquaintance to alienate her affections from her husband, he ought to pay exemplary damages. For Mr. HEMMING, it was urged that the real origin of the misfortune was the marriage of the Colonel with a lady who had formed a strong attachment to another person, and that Mr. HEMMING being a man of very moderate means, he would be completely ruined by heavy damages. The Judge-Ordinary told the jury that Mr. HEMMING's position in life was not the measure of damages, for, if he could not pay in purse, he must in person. He told them the question was, what loss had the husband sustained. The jury returned a verdict for the petitioner, with 1,000 damages.

abstract: The Pursuit of
snippet: The Pursuit of
lead_paragraph: Mr. STANTON's brief telegram, of yesterday, gives us news from Gen. GRANT up to noon. He was then at Farmville, sixteen miles west of Burkesville Station. This position puts beyond the possibility of doubt the fact, that LEE is completely shut out from North Carolina, and, in fact, from the whole South. Consequently he turns northwesterly, and hastens toward Lynchburgh. Our pursuit is so vigorous that Gen. GRANT is very sanguine that the rebel leader will very soon be driven to a surrender. He cannot be unaware that both THOMAS and SCHOFIELD -- the former from East Tennessee and the latter from the Shenandoah Valley -- are rapidly nearing Lynchburg, and may be on hand to bid him welcome. We have no direct news from SHERMAN, but it is pretty certain that he is looking after JOHNSTON, and probably moving rapidly toward the grand theatre in which GRANT is doing his great work.

abstract: -- A few days ago a young married woman named CHAMBERLAIN, daughter of Rev. Mr. CRANDALL, a well-known clergyman in Le Seur County, Minnesota, shot her betrayer, a man named STANLEY. The woman was the wife of a soldier in the Tenth Minnesota Volunteer Infantry, and during the absence of her husband at the front was seduced from the paths of virtue by STANLEY, who is a rebel deserter from Virginia. Some months after, hearing of the death of her husband, she wrote to her parents, stating that in order to shield them from disgrace she had made arrangements with the man who had ruined her to take her out of the country, entirely beyond the reach of friend or foe, and there leave her to herself and her own resources.

abstract: Maringues to inform his family of her death he himself died of apoplexy. JEAN started of instantly in a state of most demonstrative affliction. A sudden doubt flashed across the mind of his sister. She inquired at the post-office, and on ascertaining that no letter from Marseilles had been delivered to her brother, she felt convinced that he had murdered her parents. JEAN made his appearance at the end of two days. A frightful scene ensued. To the appeals of his family as to what he had done with his parents, he replied, "That is my secret. What has been done will benefit you all, and I abide the consequences." His sister, frantic with grief and horror, and perfectly convinced of his guilt, took him apart, and implored him to save the honor of the family, and commit suicide rather than ascend the scaffold. A few hours later, the poor creature, struck with remorse for having suggested a fresh crime to her brother, and maddened by despair, cut her own throat. The police, saving got scent of the suicide and of its motive, succeeded in capturing JEAN, who had left Maringues the night of his sister's death. The idea is, that JEAN packed his father's and mother's bodies into a huge box, which some men belonging to the railway station at Riom remember to have had considerable difficulty in placing on a truck. The trial, which has commenced, excites great interest.

abstract: Rebel Brigade Band performing at Washington
snippet: Rebel Brigade Band performing at Washington
lead_paragraph: Among the rebel deserters who arrived here yesterday, and who took the oath of allegiance at the Soldiers' Rest, were seventeen musicians who gave themselves up in Petersburgh to our forces. Seven of them resided in Petersburgh, and they belonged, with the exception of two from the Fifty-fifth North Carolina Regiment, to various Virginia regiments and battalions, several of them hailing from Norfolk and Richmond. Most of them were in Gen. MAHONE's division, being detailed from their regiments into a brigade band.

abstract: The London Builder says : Few or none and we include men of learning and rank are aware that nine English peers, of the Upper House, or second estate, have greater landed and house property in London, west and north-west of Temple Bar, than any ninety or more commoners, of the Lower House, or the third estate.
lead_paragraph: The London Builder says: Few or none -- and we include men of learning and rank -- are aware that nine English peers, of the Upper House, or second estate, have greater landed and house property in London, west and north-west of Temple Bar, than any ninety or more commoners, of the Lower House, or the third estate. Here are the names of the nine lucky lords: -- 1. The Duke of Bedford; 2. The Duke of Portland; 3. The Marquis of Exeter; 4. The Marquis of Salisbury; 5. The Marquis of Northampton; 6. The Marquis of Westminster; 7. The Marquis of Camden; 8. Earl Craven; 9. Earl of Portman, No other nine peers or M.P. of London citizens of "credit and renown," can be pitted, we repeat, against these nine peers as owners of London property west of Temple Bar and without the jurisdiction of the Right Hon. the Lord Mayor and the [???]al[???]n truncheons of the Peelers of the city police.

lead_paragraph: The Melbourne Argus, of Jan. 15, relates a singular incident at sea. On the 21st of November, while a heavy sea was running, one of the crew of the steamer London, from London to Melbourne, fell overboard. A boat was at once lowered, and Mr. HARRIS, the sailing master, and five men, pulled off in search of the man, who, however, perished. The man fell overboard about 11 o'clock in the morning, and Capt. MARTIN, the captain of the London, felt confident he saw the boat [???] down soon after it was lowered from the ship. Nevertheless, the search was continued until dusk, about 7 o'clock, when all hope of ever seeing any of the men again alive was abandoned. Throughout the day the London was plainly visible to the [???] themselves, but their boat, as large life-boat, drawing barely four inches, had no hold of the water, and drifted to leeward so rapidly that they could not put up to the steamer. However, they had a resources Passengers, as we all know, will cause annoyance on shipboard by using the boats as storerooms. Mr. HARRIS had himself cleared out the life-boat a few days previously, but it was now round that there had been a fresh transgression, and that two or three rugs and blankets, and other "gear" of that description were on board. These were speedily made use of. Two oars, lashed blade upper most, the one forward and the other [???], furnished masts on which the rugs were hoisted; a broken oar was transformed into a bowsprit, and a linen bolster case split [???] made a couple of jib-sails, which answered admirably. Still the boat would not lie close to the wind'. The most that could be done was to keep a parallel course with the steamer. When evening fell, and the vessel was shut out from sight, she was not above six miles away, so that while the light lasted the rise and fall of her bowsprit with the swell could be plainly traced. Mr. HARRIS divided the men into watches, one man to steer and another to look out while the others slept, and he kept on the steamer's course until daylight, though the chance of catching her was but small. In the morning nothing was to be seen, and Mr. HARRIS then determined to steer for Trinidada, a little [???] perched on the ocean between South America and Africa, a barren spot, but on which water is to be procured, and on which, it is said, though it is not positively known, that a few walls of society obtained a precarious living. Trinidada must have been one hundred miles distant, but the wind was fair, and aided by a fifth sail, a square sail, rigged amidships on the boat-hook, the little craft slipped along at the rate of five or six knots the hour. There was literally nothing in the way of eatables on board; there was not even a beaker of water or a pipe of tobacco, but the men bore the privation with perfect good humor, laughing as to who would have their "plum duff." By-and-by, the masts of the Henry Tabor, an American whaling-bark, were sighted. She was about eight miles off, but, as the wind was free, the boat soon ran down to her, and the crew met with a hospitable reception. They had been in the boat for thirty-two hours, and had encountered a very heavy sea during the whole of that time. Next day the Henry Tabor fell in with the John Bunyan, and the men were taken on board, that vessel and conveyed to Melbourne. After the arrival of the lost men, rumors, emanating from some of the passengers, attributed blame to Capt. MARTIN in not having instituted a sufficient search for the boat; but, on the other hand, the saloon passengers presented Capt. MARTIN with an address at the close of the voyage, as an expression of their approval of his conduct, and Sir DANIEL COOPER and Archdeacon REIBEY, two of the passengers, formally expressed their opinion that every effort was made to find the boat, and that the search was not abandoned until all hope was given up. Mr. HARRIS has also written a letter, declaring that no commander could have done more than Capt. MARTIN did. An inquiry was made into the facts by the Acting Shipping Master at the port of Melbourne, and the evidence taken by him was laid before the Attorney-General, who pronounced that it did not furnish grounds for a charge of misdemeanor against Capt. MARTIN. Doubtless investigation will be made by the Board of Trade in England.

abstract: Investiture with the Pallum
snippet: Investiture with the Pallum
lead_paragraph: This very interesting ceremony of the Catholic Church took place yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral, the investor being the Right Rev. the Bishop (LAUGHLIN,) of Brooklyn. The pallum is the badge of authority of an Archbishop of the Catholic Church, and its investiture is as old as the church itself. There is a record in existence to the effect that the pallum of St. Peter was transferred to his successor Linus, and that of St. Mark to his successor in Alexandria, which at the present day Paltea, similar to those of the Roman Church, are used by the Greeks, and other Easten Christians. On the 27th January, (the feast of St. Agnes,) in each year two lambs are taken and placed in the custody of religieux until shearing time. From the wool then taken the pallum is made. It is then taken to the tomb of St. Peter and there blessed by the Holy Father himself, and is thus said to be taken from the body of St. Peter. It is an emblem of commuion between the head of the church and his successors. Until received by the Archbishop he cannot exercise the functions of his office, but in the case of Archbishop MCCLOSKY, a special dispensation to exercise said functions was given from Rome.

abstract: In the Senate Saturday, a bill for the protection of the New-York Fire Department Fund was reported; the Subaqueous Dock and Pier Company Bill was ordered to a third reading; also the bill to pay certain extraordinary expenses in Brooklyn. Among the bills passed were: The New-York Riot Bonds Bill; for the protection of planted oysters in Queens County; relative to the State Lunatic Asylum and insane female convicts; to incorporate the New-York and Brooklyn Turkish Bath Company; the Gettysburgh National Monument Bill (it appropriates $25,000.) The Second-avenue Railroad Extension Bill came up on its third reading, and was amended by providing that the company comply with the restrictions and regulations in force, and pay car license to the corporation of New-York, and was then laid aside. The New-York Railroad Consolidation Act was made the special order for Tuesday.
