abstract: Magazines for April
snippet: Magazines for April
lead_paragraph: -- Harper's New Monthly Magazine (NewYork: HARPER & BROTHERS) presents its usual variety of instructive and entertaining matter. Among the best articles are: "The Petroleum Regions of America," by JOHN S. SCHOOLEY; Mr. ABBOTT'S "Stir- ring Adventures Beyond the Mississippi," devoted to an account of Gen. BANKS' ill-fated Red River Expedition, and "Recollections of Gen. SHERMAN, by W.F. SHANKS. "Armadale" and "Our Mutual Friend" will be welcomed by all lovers of romance. The current numbers of these stories show no falling off in their attraction. DICKENS, indeed, seems to be taking more pains as the work proceeds. The scene of the resuscitation of a half-drowned man in the present installment, is written with much of his old power. "Wall-street in War Time" will interest all who wish to understand the secret of the rapid fortunes that everyone hears of as matters of daily occurrence. "Where the Wateree Was" is a pleasant sketch of a cruise in South American waters, with some capital illustrations.

abstract: Frankfort Journal on American Finance
snippet: Frankfort Journal on American Finance
lead_paragraph: We find the following paragraph in a recent number of the Frankfort (Germany) Journal. What it says of the service rendered to the American cause in Europe, especially in Germany, by Mr. MURPHY, our Consul at Frankfort, is well deserved. Mr. MURPHY has labored incessantly to offset the unremitting efforts of the rebel emissaries to injure the credit and depreciate the resources of our country, and to his exertions, in a very large degree, is due the popularity which our bonds have always enjoyed in Germany.

abstract: Return of Money Stolen Nine Years Ago
snippet: Return of Money Stolen Nine Years Ago
lead_paragraph: Some nine years ago, Mrs. HENRY SPENCER, of Bethlem, Conn., lost her pocket-book, containing between six and seven hundred dollars in notes and bills, while shopping in Waterbury, and nothing was ever heard from it until a few days ago, when she received a letter from a Catholic priest in Oil City, Penn., requesting her to describe the lost property, which she did. She was soon after rejoiced to have the same returned just as it was lost, excepting that a portion of the bills had been changed to greenbacks, at which she did not complain.

abstract: Secretary, Accident--Serious
snippet: Secretary, Accident--Serious
lead_paragraph: -- We regret to learn that the accident to Mr. SEWARD was quite as serious as was at first reported, and that his condition is still somewhat critical. His arm was broken near the shoulder-joint, and his lower jaw was also broken. He suffers a great deal of pain from both, and although the symptoms, in the judgment of his surgeon, are favorable, the critical point has not yet passed. At this important juncture in the affairs of the nation, the country will regret the loss of his judicious and patriotic counsels.

abstract: Trial Commenced
snippet: Trial Commenced
lead_paragraph: Several months since, Mr. OSBON, in his capacity of naval reporter, furnished sundry journals with the details of an expedition about to be made, with the understanding that the matter was not to be used until he should notify the editors of its propriety. The newspapers, however, published the matter, and it was extensively copied, to the alleged injury of the expedition. The name of Mr. OSBON was given to the authorities, and he was arrested and taken to the Old Capitol Prison at Washington, where he has since been detained. Last week, by order of the government, he was sent to this city and placed in charge of Gen. DIX. In pursuance of orders from the War Department, a court-martial was detailed by the Commandant of the Department of the East, consisting of the following officers:

abstract: John Bull's obstinacy and stupidity; John Bull's Obstinacy
snippet: John Bull's obstinacy and stupidity; John Bull's Obstinacy
lead_paragraph: The British nation is undergoing one of its semi-occasional spasms about railroad accidents. The great problem how to establish communication between the passenger-cars and the engine-driver is again puzzling the brain of our thick-headed old grandmother. It was discussed in Parliament a few nights since, and Mr. MILNER GIBSON made light of it. Whereupon the Times is deluged with letters from persons who say that if Mr. GIBSON had been in their places on such and such occasions, he would have thought it a serious matter. A Mr. POPE narrates his experience. The railway-carriage in which he was seated ran off the track, and although every passenger in it put his head out at the window and screamed at the top of his voice, the train ran a mile and a half over the sleepers before they could attract the driver's attention, and even then it was merely by accident that he happened to look round! -- and half-a-dozen others tell similar stories.
headline: {'main': "JOHN BULL'S OBSTINACY AND STUPIDITY.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "JOHN BULL'S OBSTINACY AND STUPIDITY.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Vicksburgh, S. S.; List of Officers
snippet: Vicksburgh, S. S.; List of Officers
lead_paragraph: The U.S. steamer Vicksburgh arrived at this port to-day from Hampton Roads, and proceeded to the navy-yard. She has been nearly eighteen months in commission, was actively engaged in blockade duty off Wilmington, N.C., and in cruising for runners and privateers, also occupying a prominent part in the engagements, resulting in the capture of Wilmington. Her last duty was up the Pamunkey River. Va., in cooperation with the forces of Gen. SHERIDAN to prevent the erection of batteries on the bluffs. She is said to be one of the most beautiful vessels in the service, and carries the formidable battery of one 100-pounders, four 30-pounders, one 20-pounder, all rifles, and one 12-pound howitzer.

abstract: A REBEL EX-CONGRESSMAN IN SEARCH OF PEACE. -- Ex-Senator FOOTE, who escaped from Richmond two or three months since, and was afterward expelled from the rebel Congress, has returned from Europe and is now under arrest in this city. We publish in another column a letter in which he states the circumstances and motives of his return. For what special reason he is in confinement here we do not know; but we presume that he has only to take the oath of allegiance to secure his release. The government has certainly nothing to fear from him, for he his fled from the authority of the rebels, and is thoroughly in favor of a restoration of the Union. He was always erratic in his actions and opinions, and is very likely now to prefer imprisonment rather than comply with conditions which our government has prescribed for the regulation of such cases. There is neither reason nor wisdom, however, in subjecting him to any severe or rigorous treatment.
lead_paragraph: A REBEL EX-CONGRESSMAN IN SEARCH OF PEACE. -- Ex-Senator FOOTE, who escaped from Richmond two or three months since, and was afterward expelled from the rebel Congress, has returned from Europe and is now under arrest in this city. We publish in another column a letter in which he states the circumstances and motives of his return. For what special reason he is in confinement here we do not know; but we presume that he has only to take the oath of allegiance to secure his release. The government has certainly nothing to fear from him, for he his fled from the authority of the rebels, and is thoroughly in favor of a restoration of the Union. He was always erratic in his actions and opinions, and is very likely now to prefer imprisonment rather than comply with conditions which our government has prescribed for the regulation of such cases. There is neither reason nor wisdom, however, in subjecting him to any severe or rigorous treatment.

abstract: New-York City; Bleecker-street line
snippet: New-York City; Bleecker-street line
lead_paragraph: Very handsome and convenient cars were started yesterday for the first time on the Bleecker-street and Fulton Ferry Railroad. They run from the ferry up Fulton-street. William, Ann, Park-row, Centre Leonard, Elm, Howard, Crosby, Bleecker, McDougal, Fourth, &c., returning, for most of the route, on the same streets. The Amity-street and Seventh-avenue line of stages is discontinued, so that the crowd in Fulton street will not be greater by reason of the cars than heretofore with the stages. Although an entirely new line and running over aroute where there have been no conveyances on Sunday, the cars were immediately and constantly crowded. It would be difficult to find a route of twenty blocks in the city where cars would not be well patronized in these flush times of fractional currency.

abstract: The evening of Palm Sunday, sacred to the PRINCE of PEACE, was made ever memorable and glorious in the history of this nation, by the announcement of the SURRENDER OF GEN. LEE AND HIS WHOLE ARMY.
lead_paragraph: The evening of Palm Sunday, sacred to the PRINCE of PEACE, was made ever memorable and glorious in the history of this nation, by the announcement of the SURRENDER OF GEN. LEE AND HIS WHOLE ARMY. It is the harbinger of an immediate and glorious Peace, a Peace gloriously won by the grand courage, endurance, and unshaken faith in their cause of the splendid Armies of the Potomac and the James, aided by their glory-crowned brethren under SHERDAN and THOMAS and HANCOCK, and the heroes of the ocean who have kept watch and ward along our coasts from the Delaware to the Rio Grande. The news is none the less welcome because prematurely announced, none the less glorious and important because for many days considered a foregone conclusion. It is the end of the Confederacy. There may be sporadic efforts here and there; JOHNSTON may venture a battle; Mobile may undertake a half resistance; the rebel troops west of the Mississippi may indulge in irregular campaigns; but LEE has surrendered -- LEE, their Commander-in Chief, and practically Dictator; LEE, upon whose shoulders, by universal consent, has for half a year rested the fortunes of the rebellion, has abandoned their cause as hopeless. He surrendered an army never surpassed in bravery, in suffering, in persistence in a bad cause -- an army that had everything to gain by success -- everything to lose by defeat. The corner-stone is removed -- the edifice has fallen beyond the possibility of restoration. It is the greatest and most importhant event for this country since the imperishable Declaration of July 4, 1776, the most, momentous fact of the century as affecting the stability of democratic government. It will be hailed, not only in our own land, but wherever mankind aspires to freedom and progress, as a turning point in the history of man.

abstract: TION BEFORE THE CORONER. The investigation into the circumstances connected with the recent disaster in Furman-street, whereby five persons lost their lives, was commenced before the Coroner and jury on Saturday afternoon. JAMES S. SMITH, residing in
lead_paragraph: TION BEFORE THE CORONER. The investigation into the circumstances connected with the recent disaster in Furman-street, whereby five persons lost their lives, was commenced before the Coroner and jury on Saturday afternoon. JAMES S. SMITH, residing in Portland-avenue, near Dekalb, testified that he was on the roof of the burning building, with others, and while there was cautioned to step back; some twenty or thirty men were on the roof at the time; Mr. GEORGE HAVILAND cautioned them to leave; the firemen remained; they were playing on the fire; a minute or two after the warning the roof fell in; there was some one who directed the movements of the firemen, but he heard no orders given. WM. WESSELS, of No. 158 York-street, Jersey City, testified that he was upon the roof of the burning building, No. 93 Furman-street; told the Chief Engineer that it was useless to throw any water there, and was told to mind his own business; some one cautioned him that the roof was in danger of falling any minute; the caution was loud enough to be heard by all; the firemen were apparently doing no good there, as they were throwing the water into the street; after the caution, the citizens mostly left; was just in the rear when the roof went in; labored under the impression that the Chief-Engineer went down with the rest. T.D. HERBERT, of No. 90 Hicks-street, heard the Chief give an order, and supposed it to be an order to vacate the roof, some ten or fifteen minutes before the accident. ROBERT BARR, Assistant-Engineer, testified that he was present at the fire, but heard no order given for the people to get off the roof. Had been at the fire about half an hour when, the root fell in, and assisted several men out of the ruins. The question of the security of these buildings had never been raised among firemen to his knowledge. Had no conversation with the Chief-Engineer that night, and did not consider that there was any danger. Did not know that the Chief was there at the time the root fell in. Did not think it safe to have a covering of earth on those buildings. GEORGE COLGAN, of No. 7 Engine, testified that the Chief-Engineer ordered the men on the roof to cease playing, as they were throwing the water on those below. As the order was not obeyed, he went on the root himself. The fire had been burning about half an hour at this time. In a few minutes thereafter the Chief gave the order to stop playing, the roof fell in. The inquisition will be resumed this afternoon at 1 o'clock.

abstract: Army
snippet: Army
lead_paragraph: The most interesting question now is, what will Jo. JOHNSTON do? He commands the only army of any magnitude now left in the Southern Confederacy. It is not a very formidable army in numbers, nor is it coherent in character. In every characteristic of an army, it is vastly inferior to that lately under LEE. It has never, as an army, fought a noteworthy battle. It has no traditions of success. It has no capable leaders. The troops of HARDEX, who fled from Savannah and then from Charleston, form its nucleus, and to these have been added the tail of HOOD's old army, the Wilmington force of BRAGG, the picayune force of BEAUREGARD, various feeble forces and garrisons picked up around, and a cavalry force under WADE HAMPTON and WHEELER. It is a piebald collection. Since its organization -such organization as it has -- it has been steadily on the retreat; and the last we hear of it is that it has fled from Raleigh, and it must be now somewhere near the Southern border of Virginia. It was supposed that, in the last resort, LEE would try and effect a junction with it; but JOHNSTON and his troops doubtless heard yesterday of the surrender of LEE and his whole army.

abstract: If any one had looked yesterday to see our people go into extravagant demonstrations over the surrender of the rebel army -- which is the surrender of the rebellion itself -- he is by this time undeceived. Had we not been fully aware of the deep and solemn earnestness of the loyal heart, we should indeed wonder at what might almost be characterized as indifference. But still waters run deep. Four years of trial such as no nation on the earth has lived through; four years of unequalled financial pressure; of mental and physical tension, to the top of our bent; of armies till now unknown in history for numbers, for courage, for endurance, for achievement; four years of wrestling with a foe of our own blood and birth, a foe howsoever grievously at fault still "worthy of our steel;" four years in which no sun has set that did not pale its fire over newly bereaved hearth-stones, and rekindle its morning rays amid the tears of widows and orphans; four such years have sobered and chastened our hearts to feelings more in accordance with our sufferings and our hopes than could be expressed in any wild bacchanalian revelry.

abstract: Kean, Charles, in New-York; Sale of Seats
snippet: Kean, Charles, in New-York; Sale of Seats
lead_paragraph: Theatre, to witness the eleven eights' performance of Mr. and Mrs. KEAN, took place yesterday morning, under the direction of Mr. C.W. TATLEURE the auctioneers being Messrs. HENRY H. LE[???]DS & MINER. The private boxes A, B, and Nos. 1, 3 and 4, were first put up, when A and B were disposed of at $20 each premium -- the seats per night being $15, thereby bringing $470. The purchasers were Mr. B. FISHER and Mr. T.B. MCDONALD. The sale for orchestra chairs then proceeded, when the choice of selection was knocked down at $4 50 each, the chairs per night being $2 50 -- when the following result was reached: 160 chairs for eleven nights at $2 50, $1,400; premium for the eleven nights for 160 orchestra cha[???]s, $720; total, $5,120. The dress circle tickets were next set up, when twenty of them were disposed of at $6 75 premium, the seats being $2 each, which produced $575 -- the total amount of the day's sale being $6 165. The selection of seats not sold yesterday will be disposed of at the box-office to-day, and all that may then remain unsold will be sold for single nights on Wednesday morning. Mr. LEEDS said he was authorized by Mr. KEAN to say that the statement that he had made a second engagement was e[???]roncous. He had made only the engagement.

abstract: The Advent of; A New Epoch; the Advent of Peace; Religious Sentiment of U. S. Amidst War
snippet: The Advent of; A New Epoch; the Advent of Peace; Religious Sentiment of U. S. Amidst War
lead_paragraph: This continent quivered yesterday as never since its upheaval from chaos. The lightning flashed peace, and from ocean to ocean, all minds thrilled with the sense of a new order of things. No more deluge of blood. No more whirls of ruin. No more brooding darkness. The republic rested again, and upon foundations as eternal as the hills. The whole heavens were spanned with the rainbow of promise, and every eye saw it.

abstract: Hartford Charter Election, Union Majority; Borden, N B, Fall River; Eclipse, Partial, of the Moon, April 10
snippet: Hartford Charter Election, Union Majority; Borden, N B, Fall River; Eclipse, Partial, of the Moon, April 10
lead_paragraph: GRANT's victory was fitly indorsed yesterday by the voters of Hartford, Conn. That city has for years indulged in the bad habit of giving Democratic majorities. Last week, however, things took a turn; the dissolving view of JEFF. DAVIS' Confederacy was the signal for a change of base on the part of the Hartfordites; they astonished themselves and everybody else by giving 248 Republican majority. That was great; but yesterday, at the Charter election, the Democracy followed LEE's example and surrendered, the Union majority being 422 on the highest candidate. That was glorious.

abstract: The Assembly was occupied to-night with a discussion on the Senate Bill to pay the members of the Common Council of New-York two thousand dollars each per year. The House went into committee, and Mr. VAN BUREN denounced the bill as an outrage on the people of New-York. The proposition was to tax the people without a single petition for it, when money was yearly taken from the treasury by fraud the bill called for.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Monday, April 10.

abstract: A letter dated Headquarters Army of the Potomac, Jetersville, Amelia County, April 7, says that on Monday the cavalry under SHERIDAN made as important capture of prisoners, guns and wagons. It appears that LEE'S army was moving as rapidly west as his limited transportion and the demoralized condition of his troops would permit, on the road between Amelia Court-house and Jetersville.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Monday, April 10.

snippet: The, and Major Dodge; Reply to Demonstration on Lee's Sur
lead_paragraph: In the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, ABRAHAM RICKS pleaded guilty to an assault with a deadly weapon, and was sent to the States prison for five years. HENRY LANGWORTH was tried and convicted of grand larceny, and sent to the States prison for three years and six months. MARY O'BRIEN, also convicted of grand larceny, was sent to the States prison for two years and six months. WILLIAM SMITH, who was indicted for murder of a sailor named LAWRENCE, in a drunken quarrel, pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the fourth degree and was remanded for sentence. The Court adjourned until this morning, at 11 o'clock.

abstract: Surrender, Rejoicings, Resolutions, Meetings, >amp;c.
snippet: Surrender, Rejoicings, Resolutions, Meetings, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The surrender of LEE and his army was first announced to the people of New-York in an extra TIMES, issued at 11:30, on Sunday night. The premature announcement on Friday had the effect of making the people incredulous; the hour of the real announcement was late, and, as it was on Sunday night, the weary world was wending bedward, there was not that amount of rejoicing which would naturally have arisen at an earlier hour. Yet the excitement was equaled only by that which followed the attack upon Fort Sumter; the surrender of LEE and his army was anticipated, looked for, and to a great extent discounted in advance. The utter demoralization of the rebel army, the increased esprit of our own forces, the vigorous pursuit of the Union troops and the prophecy of Gen. GRANT had prepared us for the great news which, on Sunday night, was flashed across the wires to an expectant public. Despite this, however, the errand of the mercurial newsboys was successful; with their arms full of extras, they rushed up town and over to the neighboring cities, shouting the glad tidings as they ran, so that before the morning papers disclosed the fact, the great mass of the people were aware that LEE and his armed men no longer stood in the pathway of the Army of the Potomac. Newsboys and news extras have been detected ere this in imposing upon a credulous and a hopeful people, and at the hotels it was some little time before the cries of the little fellows were regarded with attention. But the dispatch characteristic of Secretary STANTON, settled every doubt, and the wildest delirium of joy seized everybody and held possession for the night.

abstract: ITALIAN OPERA. -- Mr. MARETZEK's benefit takes place to-night. It is tendered to him by the members of his company, and is honestly a proper mark of respect to a hard-working and conscientious man. What we have here in music we owe almost exclusively to Mr. MARETZEK. All other managers are trivial and unimportant speculators in comparison with him. It is needless for us to dwell on the merits of a gentleman whose merits we have for many years been called upon to indorse. It is unnecessary also to direct attention to to-night's performance at the Academy -- the seats being nearly all taken. But, however useless, there are times when the critic feels that his voice may be raised with pleasure to himself. To-night is certainly the opportunity.

abstract: In Senate yesterday resolutions were proposed pertinent to the great event of LEE's surrender. They were referred to a committee in consequence of FIELD's objection to the word "slaveholders." The New-York Fire Department Fund bill and the Pay Side Ferry Company bill were reported. The following bills were passed: The Third-street Brooklyn Improvement bill; to close a portion of One Hundred and Thirty-ninth-street, New-York; ratifying the amendment to the Constitution prohibiting slavery; incorporating the National Turkish Bath Company; providing for the registration of deaths in the several towns and wards in the State; incorporating the New-York Sub-aqueous Metalic Dock and Warehouse Company; incorporating the North American and Italian Steamship Company; authorizing the extension of the track of the Third-avenue Railroad.

abstract: Ports, Sovereign Rights of U. S.
snippet: Ports, Sovereign Rights of U. S.
lead_paragraph: RIGHTS OF THE UNITED STATES. -- The meaning of the President's proclamation in regard to the blockade of certain Southern ports, which we published yesterday, is, perhaps, only made fully intelligible by referring to an intimation received from several of the leading Powers of Europe, shortly after the outbreak of the war. That intimation was to the effect that, while an effective blockade would be respected, our claim to exercise legal authority over the ports blockaded would be ignored. The President, in a quiet and unostentatious way, has resolved to put this matter right at once. He claims that we have some sovereign rights as an independent Power; and in declaring anew what ports of the South are open and what ports are closed, he will bring the existence of these sovereign rights to the test. This is all right.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- A brilliant and crowded audience greeted Mr. MARETZEK last evening, when he took his benefit. The programme opened with "Il Poliuto" and closed with an act from "La Forza del Destino." In the first-named work, both Signor MASSIMILLIANA and Mme. ZUCCHI are heard at their best. The gentleman, indeed, can hardly be seen to greater advantage. Although a little under the weather he sang with remarkable spirit. Signor BELLINI contributed very handsomely to the pleasure of a thoroughly agreeable evening, and Mme. ZUCCHI was admirable.

lead_paragraph: M. CARME, an eminent billiard artist, arrived from France a few days ago, and last night gave the people an opportunity of seeing some of the curiosities of the cue at Cooper Institute. He is certainly a most skillful and graceful player, both at the regular game and the fancy, or masse, shots, in which the laws of force and motion seem to be set at naught. M. CARME has issued a challenge for the champion cue, which must create no little interest among the professors and amateurs.

lead_paragraph: The rejoicings are by no means over. Again the city was draped with bunting, and again the chimes rang forth their silver notes of patriotic melody. The feature of yesterday's celebration was the ceremony at Trinity Church. From the hour when the first gun was fired at Sumter to this moment she has borne aloft the flag of the republic and remembered its defenders day and night. Memorable services of various natures and of grandeur have been held within the walls of this temple, but at no time has New-York so centred at Trinity as it did yesterday.

abstract: Revision Proposed by President
snippet: Revision Proposed by President
lead_paragraph: having finished the immediate business in hand at Richmond, has turned his attention, on his return to Washington, to the question of the treatment meted out to United States vessels of war at foreign ports. Immunities have been denied to these vessels, under a pretext of neutrality, which are conceded, either by treaty, by public law, or by the comity of nations, to the vessels of every other Power. The President thinks the time has come when this should be revised. Otherwise, the foreign governments thus continuing to bear themselves toward us, will find their vessels subjected to precisely the same treatment in our ports. This fair and honest action might have been adopted, probably, with advantage at an earlier date. It is the readiest and least offensive way of putting it to a direct test, whether the leading European Powers desire to put our war vessels much longer on a footing with the rebel pirates.

abstract: Carme, Pierre; First Seance and Challenge
snippet: Carme, Pierre; First Seance and Challenge
lead_paragraph: Mons. PIERRE CARME, formerly of Versailles and Paris, gave his first seance in the large hall of the Cooper Institute last evening, and notwithstanding the threatening state of the weather, he was greeted by an audience of nearly two thousand people, among which were many eminent citizens, including judges of the courts, leading bankers, lawyers, merchants, editors, etc., and a large delegation of ladies. M.CARME was assisted by M. PHELAN and Wm. GOLDTHWAIT. On introducing the Professor. Mr. GAVIT took occasion to observe the serious disadvantage M. CARME was laboring under in this exhibition. That he was an almost total stranger in the country, had only recently arrived from a sea-voyage, that the table, balls, machinery, etc., of the game was entirely new to him. Again, as in the case of all first appearances, he was considerably embarrassed with "the glare of the foot-lights." Therefore, if he should fail in some of his shots on the first attempt, under the existing circumstances, he trusted to receive their kind indulgence. The playing then commenced with a French three-ball game -- fifty points up, between M. CARME and Mr. GOLDTHWAIT, which was won by the former. After which M. CARME demonstrated the power of the masse and other intricasies of billiards in a series of about thirty shots, the most of which were made with wonderful accuracy, and showing the most astonishing control over the balls. Some of the demonstrations drew forth salvos of applause. After this Mr. GAVIT came forward and stated that he was now enabled to answer a query which had been repeatedly asked during the last few days, viz.: "What is the strength of M. CARME in a game of billiards." The reply to this was a letter from M. CARME to Mr. PHELAN, which he would now read.

abstract: vs. Political Power of Confederacy; Peace Negotiations with Lee
snippet: vs. Political Power of Confederacy; Peace Negotiations with Lee
lead_paragraph: In leaving the peace negotiations, which were brought to so successful an issue on Sunday last, in the hands of Lieut. Gen. GRANT, a variety of perplexing issues were avoided. The cumbrous and dubious phrases of diplomacy became unnecessary, and the national authorities were spared the unsavory task of covenanting with the political leaders of the rebellion. The status of the Confederacy came under review neither in the proposals which the Lieutenant-General felt himself empowered to make, nor in the unreluctant acceptance of these proposals by LEE. The offer of terms made by Gen. GRANT, as completely ignored the political conspiracy and its originators as if the agreement had involved the surrender of a force of Indian rangers on the Texan frontier. DAVIS, BENJAMIN, TOOMBS, COBB, MASON and SLIDELL, and the prime instigators of the rebellion, became of as little account in settling the compact by which the power of the rebellion was surrendered, as if they had been so many English or French speculators, building rams under neutral flags for the destruction of our commerce.

abstract: Booth, Mary H C, the Poetess
snippet: Booth, Mary H C, the Poetess
lead_paragraph: MARY H.C. BOOTH, the poetess, died in this city yesterday morning. She had long been a sufferer, and for several years has lived in Switzerland, the rarefied air of an elevated region being grateful to her. Some of the most touching and inspiring words of cheer which have come over to us during the war, have borne her name. A small collection of her poems was printed at Zurich in a quaint little volume. Her last work was the correction of a complete edition, which LIPPINCOTT has in press, elegantly illustrated by WU[???]T.

abstract: Jeff Davis Ought to be; N. Y.and Punishment of Jeff. Davis; What Shall be Done with Him
snippet: Jeff Davis Ought to be; N. Y.and Punishment of Jeff. Davis; What Shall be Done with Him
lead_paragraph: We are going to hang the murderer of HARRY LAZARUS, a week from next Friday. Why? A young varlet born, haply, of a rag-picker in a back attic of Cow Bay, his swaddling clothes a ragged dish-clout, suckled in adulterated gin, weaned over an apple-stall, his first lessons the choicest phraseology of blasphemy and obscenity, knowing nothing that he had a soul, and witless of all distinction between himself and the street curs, save that the dogs bit him and he kicked the dogs, well grounded for his early years in the rudiments of picking and stealing, a pupil of Jack Sheppard at the Bowery Theatre, and in due course removed to the Benicia Boy's Finishing School -- for aught we know BERNARD FRIERY was guilty of all that, and now having brought his villainy to climax by getting "drunk as a lord," and idiotically killing the first man he ran against, the law has decided that it is high time he should be put out of the way, and this it is going to do.

abstract: Canal-street Ferry and Mail Steamship Company; Outlets for Canal-st Ferry
snippet: Canal-street Ferry and Mail Steamship Company; Outlets for Canal-st Ferry
lead_paragraph: -- One of the large mail steamship companies asks the Common Council to reconsider their resolution to reopen the Canal-street Ferry to Hoboken, on the ground that to do so would injure its business. What if it does? -- which we do not believe however. The means of exit from the lower part of this over-crowded island need multiplying ten fold rather than diminishing. The loss of the Canal-street Ferry has been long and bitterly felt by thousands at both sides of the route. The request of the company, in these circumstances, is scarcely decent, and we urge on the Council that it be not listened to for one moment. Until the facilities for suburban travel are vastly increased and improved, the great body of citizens who have but moderate means to depend upon, must continue to be victimized by the extortionate class of landlords. Cheap, speedy and regular means of conveyance to and from the suburban districts, is the only remedy for this growing and intolerable evil. We must see to it, then, that the plea of commercial convenience, nor any other plea, shall interfere with the improvement and extension of our city lines of travel either by land or water.

abstract: SALUTE OF 100 GUNS AT UNION-SQUARE. -- In compliance with orders from General Headquarters, Albany, a salute of 100 guns was fired at Union-square, at noon yesterday, in honor of our victories at Petersburgh and Richmond. Col. TELLER, commanding the Fourth Regiment N.Y.S.N.G., had charge of the arrangements. Quite a large crowd assembled in the square, and the surrounding houses were gaily decorated with the national colors. The Union League Club building was especially noticeable, being almost hidden beneath the Stars and Stripes.

abstract: The
snippet: The
lead_paragraph: The Inman steamer, City of Dublin, which left on a special voyage for Liverpool on Monday, carrying thither the news of LEE's surrender, will doubtless reach Queenstown by Thursday, the 20th, if she have fair weather. She will easily run ahead of the Portland steamer, which left on Saturday, and which calls at Londonderry. And as she is light-freighted, and has a special mission in hand, it is not improbable that she may make better time even than the Australasian. The latter vessel had the start by five days and several hours, and carried out the news of the evacuation of Richmond and Petersburgh. The difference in the time of their arrival on the other side will just be sufficient to enable the British rebel organs to found some new theory on the flight of the "Confederates" from their capital, and prove to the sagacious crowd of "sympathizers" that the movement is one originating in the highest kind of high strategy, and opening up -- as DAVIS' late local organ put it, by anticipation -- "new hopes for the independence of the South." The bulletins of the City of Dublin's news will spoil no end of this sort of newspaper strategy. Even the London Times will be at considerable loss to prove to the moneyed and commercial classes of the United Kingdom that all its predictions are exactly fulfilled. Another cotton loan will hardly be in order for some time, we reckon.

abstract: Lincoln, Pres. on new State Gov't of; on Status of Seceded States; Speech on Louisiana
snippet: Lincoln, Pres. on new State Gov't of; on Status of Seceded States; Speech on Louisiana
lead_paragraph: The executive departments, including the President's mansion, were again. illuminated to-night and adorned with transparencies and national flags, as were also many places of business and private dwellings. Bonfires blazed in many parts of the city and rockets were fired. Thousands of persons of both sexes repaired to the Executive mansion, and after several airs had been played by the band, the President, in response to the numerous calls, appeared at an upper window. The cheering with which he was greeted having ceased, he spoke as follows:

abstract: Army; No More Work for; Army Dist'd from Rebel Politicians
snippet: Army; No More Work for; Army Dist'd from Rebel Politicians
lead_paragraph: The Army of the Potomac has now no enemy to fight. It will never again have an enemy to fight in Virginia. It has fought its last great battle. As one of the great organized armies of the nation, it must soon, we suppose, cease to exist as a military force. The future must develop its uses and its history. A part of it will undoubtedly be retained for some time in Virginia; but with all the strategic positions, the military lines and cities of the State in our hands, fifty thousand men could maintain peace in any contingency and repel any foe.

abstract: States and Union Office Cleared Out
snippet: States and Union Office Cleared Out
lead_paragraph: An unusually active inquiry (mainly for permanent investment) prevailed yesterday for the gold-bearing bonds of the Government, which advanced 1 1/4@1 1/2 cent., and closed with a strong upward tendency. The bonds were extremely searce, and much difficulty was experienced in executing orders for round sums, either through the Stock Boards or through the commission houses. The latter were decidedly more eager to buy than inclined to sell, at even the improved rates. A few speculative purchases were made, chiefly of the new 5-20s, and the 10-40 five per cents. The demand from buyers on foreign account was developing significantly, promising soon to absorb a large portion of the comparatively limited supply of the bonds in the market, and at rising figures. One or two leading foreign banking firms had their brokers busily employed in running from counting-room to counting-room on Wall-street, and endeavoring to purchase large lines, especially of the funded six per cents, at prevailing quotations; but, owing to the reduced supply available, their efforts were comparatively unsuccessful. The home demand for small sums was so respectable in the aggregate, and, withal, so urgent, that the commission houses were kept actively at work in filling the popular orders. All parties seemed to anticipate an early and marked appreciation in the market value of the bonds, which are now 4@6 cent. lower than at this time last year, even in the face of the recent decisive Union successes, implying unmistakably a speedy restoration of the national authority throughout the length and breadth of the Republic. The prompt effect of the news of these successes abroad will be a vast increase of foreign orders for the funded stock of our country. The immediate effect at home is to be seen in the steady augmentation of the sales of the 7-30 Currency Loan now in process of distribution. The subscriptions to this Loan opened this week with the high daily aggregate of $2,873,650, including 2,011 single orders for the $50 and $100 notes of this Loan. The amount subscribed yesterday reached $3,132,400, and there were 2,193 subscribers for $50 and $100 bonds.

abstract: In the Senate, the bills authorizing plank road and turnpike companies to charge additional fare; providing for the payment of certain extraordinary expenses of Brooklyn; incorporating the St. James Benevolent Society of Brooklyn; conferring additional powers on the Marshals of New-York; relative to the Marine Court of New-York; incorporating the Hicksville and Huntington Railroad Company, all were passed. The bill amending the Registry Law was passed by 19 to 11. The bill authorizing County Treasurers to receive taxes was passed. The Central Railroad Bill was then taken up for consideration, and after some debate, progress was reported, and the bill was made the special order for to-day.

abstract: Winthrop, Brig-Gen; Funeral of
snippet: Winthrop, Brig-Gen; Funeral of
lead_paragraph: Brevet Brig.-Gen. FREDERICK WINTHROP, a gallant officer of the Army of the Potomac, was killed at the battle of Five Forks, near Petersburgh, Va., on the 1st instant, and buried with fitting ceremony in Trinity Church-yard, yesterday afternoon. In pursuance of orders from headquarters the Seventy-first. Twelfth and Twenty-second regiments were detailed as escort for the remains of the deceased and formed near Union-square at 3 o'clock. At the residence of Gen. WINTHROP's parents, in Fourteenth-street, a large assemblage of near friends met early in the afternoon and participated in the solemn services which were led by Rev. Dr. SEABURY, the Pastor of the church whereat the deceased was wont to attend. At the conclusion of these ceremonies the more public testimonies of esteem and respect were manifested, the coffin being placed in the hearse, and the grand procession formed in line. A more imposing cortege has rarely been seen on Broadway, and the silent crowds which uncovered as it mournfully moved along, regarded with an affectionate interest the enflagged coffin, which contained all that was left of him who but a few days since was the light of a loving home, and the pride of a fighting host.

abstract: Metropolitan Health Bill
snippet: Metropolitan Health Bill
lead_paragraph: in committee of the whole yesterday, the Assembly brought the Metropolitan Health Bill squarely into the House, and it was ordered to a third reading by the satisfactory vote of 60 to 49. The opposing members made no argument against it, but used the utmost license in trying to retard progress by points of order and the other means of fillibustering permitted under the rules. As this affirmative vote is within five of enough, and as nineteen members were absent, or did not vote, the prospect of its adoption is excellent. It is substantially the bill already passed by the Senate

abstract: Popularity of
snippet: Popularity of
lead_paragraph: The homely phrase, "going off like hot cakes," is completely applicable to the manner in which the new loan is being taken by the people. Yesterday the subscriptions reached the enormous sum of $3,526,000; there was one subscription of $358,000, and nearly twenty-five hundred were for $100 and $50. Evidently the people have confidence in their government and in the future. While the new loan is meeting with such great and gratifying success at home, we learn by yesterday's steamer from Europe of a still further rise there of three per cent. in the old Five-Twenty stock. If this went up to 57 on such news as they had at the close of last month, what will it reach when they learn of the fall of Richmond, and what will it not reach when they learn of the surrender of LEE's army, the crushing out of the rebellion, the termination of the war, and the complete triumph of our government?

abstract: The New-York brings European news to the 29th, three days later. The most important intelligence is in a dispatch from Lisbon, dated the day the New-York sailed, which says: "The Federal frigates Niagara and Sacramento attempted to sail before the expiration of the time fixed by the Portuguese authorities, and were fired upon by the Belen Fort. The Niagara was struck, and a seaman was killed. The vessels thereupon anchored." It seems that the Stonewall, the new rebel pirate, had escaped in some way from Ferrol, and got into the port of Lisbon; that our two steamers followed her in; that the authorities ordered her to leave, which she did; and that (according to the dispatches above quoted,) our steamers were a little too hasty in pursuit. We shall need further advices to get the true bearings of the case.

abstract: Notwithstanding the rain, over one thousand persons were present at M. CARME's seance, at the Cooper Institute last evening, and as on the first appearance, many ladies graced the occasion. The exhibition commenced with 100 points, three-ball French game, between M. CARME and Mr. GOLDTHWAITE. The latter was in most excellent play; made one run of 37, and one or two other runs in the "teens;" he was successful in winning the game with 41 points to spare. M. CARME then exhibited the masse, and other difficult shots, making many of them at the first trial; but owing to having broken his favorite cue, in his afternoon's practice, all were not as successful as on the previous evening. It was, however, a brilliant exposition, and at intervals drew forth rapturous applause. The performance closed with 150 points up, four-ball American, between M. CARME and Mr. PHELAN, which the former ran out in four innings, scarcely giving the latter a shot.

abstract: Speech on Reconstruction; The Presidents Speech on
snippet: Speech on Reconstruction; The Presidents Speech on
lead_paragraph: Those who expected from the President the statement of a settled reconstruction policy have been disappointed. His speech disclosed nothing new on that subject. It was made up chiefly of remarks upon the inherent difficulties of the general task, and upon the considerations that prompted the attempt to restore Louisiana to its old status on the basis of twelve thousand loyal voters. No pledge was given, or intention declared, to hold to this or any other particular plan for the future. The special characteristic of the speech was its reserve.

abstract: The anniversary of the attack on Fort Sumter was celebrated last evening by an oratorical and musical entertainment at the Academy of Music, in Fourteenth-street. About five hundred persons were present. After the performance of "William Tell," some selections from "Ernani" and "La Forza de Destino," by Grafulla's Band, Maj.-Gen. JOHN G. PECK made the opening address, in which he referred to the events preceding the attack on Fort Sumter, the defence made by its brave garrison, under the gallant ANDERSON, and the proposed, restoration of the old flag to the battered walls of the fort on Friday next. He concluded with an appeal in behalf of the orphans of those who have fallen on the field of battle in defending the country's flag.

abstract: Stonewall, Rebel Ram, escape from Ferrol and Lisbon; Neutrality of; The Stonewall Affair
snippet: Stonewall, Rebel Ram, escape from Ferrol and Lisbon; Neutrality of; The Stonewall Affair
lead_paragraph: The last report of the Franco-Danish ram, Stonewall, left the pirate anchored in the Spanish harbor of Ferrol; the United States war vessels Niagara and Sacramento keeping watch within sight. On the 21st of March the Stonewall, by the assistance of a Spanish man-of-war, was enabled to put to sea. The ram and the convoy, however, were followed so promptly by our fleet, that, despairing of making sufficient headway, after parting with the Spaniard, the pirate put about, and reentered the harbor under the wings of the convoy.

abstract: IRVING HALL. -- Mile, DE KATOW and Mr. JAMES M. WEHLI gave an excellent concert here last evening. The lady played several of her agreeable tunes in a pleasant and popular way. Mr. WEHLI has rarely been beard to greater advantage. His left-hand performances are really surprising; but beyond this, and preferable to our taste, are the particular productions from the gentleman's own penmor ceaux that possess merit of the nicest order, and are played invariably with unfaltering delicacy, and the just amount of strength.

lead_paragraph: The steamer Solent arrived at Havana from Vera Cruz, the 1st inst., with City of Mexico dates to March 28. She brings little news of importance. Nicholas Romero, Maj. Hegmis Alvarez, Lieut. Rajas and Sergeant Perez, of the Liberal army, had been captured and executed. The Ere assures the readers that the government has finally arranged to pay the French debt at six per cent. On the 18th of March there was an insurrection in the City of Mexico, which was speedily quelled. Five of the insurgents were executed on the 21st. The papers say that it had no apparent political cause. Senor MEDESTO DE OLAGUEBEL, a prominent statesman, died on the 26th. About 12,000 French and Austrians were on the way to Sonora.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, bills were ordered to a third reading, incorporating the New-York and Brooklyn Disinfecting Company; incorporating the New-York and Bayside Ferry Company. Bills were passed reappropriating certain moneys for canal awards, and for building weigh locks at Oswego, and rebuilding the dams on the Oswego River; authorizing the consolidation of railroads in Brooklyn; incorporating the New-York and Brooklyn Petroleum Floating Storage Company. The Central Railroad Fare Bill was considered, and without vote was made the special order for Thursday morning.

abstract: -- We publish this morning the highly interesting details of the surrender of Gen. LEE's army to Gen. GRANT on Sunday last and its attendant incidents. Our special account gives a clear description of the pursuit which preceded the surrender, and the particulars of the event itself as it occurred in the little village of Appomattox Court-house on Sunday afternoon last. It will be read with eager interest.

lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, bills were reported relative to the Croton Aqueduct in New-York and to change the grade of streets affected thereby; amending the Soldiers' Voting Law; fixing salaries of clerks of Justices' Court and Justices of Peace in Brooklyn; for the better protection of seamen in the port of New-York; incorporating Harry Howard Association of Exempt Firemen; amending the Brooklyn Public Park and Parade Grounds Bill; the New-York and Housatonic Railroad Bill. Resolutions of gratitude to God and thanks to our army for the recent victories were reported. A motion to add thereto an emphatic indorsement of the terms and acts of LEE's surrender was voted down.

lead_paragraph: We have news from Panama to April 5. Matters on the Isthmus have remained quiet since the sailing of the last steamer, though the natives are in constant dread of further revolution. The government keeps a strong night guard around the city, and a couple of old cannon are planted at the entrance of the town, in case the negroes should attempt to make an assault. But there is at present little cause for alarm.

abstract: -- A few weeks since, one of the churches in the village of Chester, Vt., through their trustees, resolved to replace the old bell in their church with a new one, and it was proposed to procure the new bell by a general subscription. A gentleman waited upon the Messrs. LELAND, of the Metropolitan Hotel, of New-York, (who are natives of Chester and worshiped at this church,) with a subscription list. "How much do you want?" interrogated the LELANDS. "As much as you choose to give," replied the gentleman. "How much will the new bell cost?" "Six hundred dollars," was the reply. "Well, then," responded the LELANDS, "order the bell, put it up, and send the bill to us and we'll pay it. What money you have subscribed put into the poor fund of the church." "Chester," continued the brothers, "is our native place, and we consider it a privilege to have this opportunity of showing our respect for the place and its good people. We left Chester poor boys, and from the early instructions and moral teachings inculcated there in our youth, we have succeeded in gaining our present position. Put up the bell, and every time its echoes are heard through the hills of Chester, let it remind the rising generation that the road to honor and wealth is open to all who seek it through dilligence, honesty and truth." In connection with this incident, it may not be out of place to state that Hon. AARON LELAND, formerly Governor of the State of Vermont, an uncle of the LELANDS of the Metropolitan Hotel, officiated as pastor of this same church for over forty years, and what is most remarkable, he never drew a dollar salary during the whole time. -- Exchange.

abstract: -- Last evenng the members of the Henry Clay Festival Association celebrated the anniversary of the natal day of the illustrious CLAY by a private supper at the Maison Dore. The room was decorated by a bust and portraits of CLAY, the banner of the society and the Stars and Stripes. The association was formed on the 12th of April, 1845, for the purpose of celebrating the birth of the great statesman in an appropriate manner. The gathering of last evening was of a purely social character, no speeches being made. Among the distinguished gentlemen present were N.P. Beers, President: De Witt Baldwin, Secretary Joseph L. Townsend, Treasurer; Dr. Benjamin Drake, Dr. John H. Leveridge, John H. Ormsbee, C.W. Frederickson and others.

abstract: Kentucky; Palmer, Gen, Receiving Surrender of Rebels
snippet: Kentucky; Palmer, Gen, Receiving Surrender of Rebels
lead_paragraph: Maj.-Gen. DIX yesterday received official notice from the War Department, that, in consequence of the important change produced by the surrender of the rebel army, the Government has concluded to suspend drafting and recruiting in all the loyal States, to curtail purchases of arms and supplies, reduce the number of general and staff officers to the actual necessities of the service, and remove military restrictions upon trade, as far as it can be done consistently with public safety. Special orders to effect these measures will be prepared as soon as practicable.

abstract: Trotting Season; Opening Fashion Course
snippet: Trotting Season; Opening Fashion Course
lead_paragraph: With the return of genial Spring the sports of the turf have recommenced, trotting taking the lead as usual, and from this time forth until late in October of the current year, there will be no intermission of the patent pastimes of the race-track -- racing and trotting alternating, throughout the season, which promises to be one of more than usual brilliancy. There are an immense number of horses in training, both for racing and trotting purposes. All the large Southern stables have wended, or are wending their way North, and larger fields of horses may be anticipated at all our great meetings than have ever previously been known.

abstract: -- Gen. LEE, in his capitulative correspondence with Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, declared again and again his great anxiety for the restoration of peace. Our special correspondent informs us that in the personal interview between LEE and GRANT, on Monday last, the rebel officer signified very emphatically his desire for a total cessation of hostilities, and indicated his intention to do all in his power to effect that end. The immense influence of LEE throughout the South will make his efforts in the direction of pacification of the very highest importance.

abstract: THE PATRIOTISM OF OUR PUBLIC SCHOOLS. -- Grammar School No. 8, in Grand-street, near Wooster, having been beautifully decorated in honor of our late victories, was this morning thrown open to the public. The names of our heroes, festooned with flags and decked with stars, adorned the walls, and emblems and arches bearing patriotic devices met the eye on every side. The details were elaborate and beautiful, and the general effect brilliant in the extreme. The whole affair, which was almost impromptu, was highly creditable to the teachers and the school. Spirited addresses were delivered by Commissioner ADAMS and the Trustees, Messrs. RUSSEL and CLARK. A large number of people were in attendance. This is one of the most flourishing schools in this city. Grammar School No. 17, in West Forty-seventh-street, near Ninth-avenue, has been beautifully decorated with the national colors -- four thousand flags being tastefully disposed about the apartments. Yesterday a musical entertainment was given by the pupils, and a number of patriotic airs were sung.

abstract: -- Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning a difficulty occurred at a porter house in Newark-avenue, Jersey City, between two young men named LOGAN and CHARLES MCIVER, when it is alleged the latter drew a revolver and fired. The ball took effect upon the person of BERNARD MCDONALD, proprietor of the place, inflicting a probably fatal wound in the abdomen. MCIVER was arrested and committed to await the result of the injuries. About 12 o'clock on Wednesday night a disturbance occurred at the corner of Grove-street and Newark-avenue, between several persons, growing out of a political discussion, during which a man named CONNER was shot in the leg, as is alleged, by a man named Nathans. No arrests were made.

abstract: In the case of Wilson vs. The City of New York, tried in the Court of Common Pleas, on Wednesday, the jury, after being out several hours, were discharged yesterday morning without being able to agree upon a verdict. Ths principles involved are regarded as important, not only to individuals, but to New-York in its corporate capacity. The trial was quite fully reported in the TIMES of Thursday.

abstract: Securities appreciation of; Securities; Appreciation of
snippet: Securities appreciation of; Securities; Appreciation of
lead_paragraph: -- Heavier sales of government gold-bearing bonds were made yesterday, including the sixes of 1881 and the 10-40s, at comparatively steady prices, while the 5-20s, old and new series, suffered a temporary depression of 1 and 1 1/2 per cent., caused by efforts of a few foreign banking agents, to realize on bonds held here, or expected "to arrive soon," on European account -- efforts originating mainly in real or affected disappointment at the latest quotations by the New-York from Frankfort and London, (to March 30.) These quotations showed an advance in the 5-20s of 3 to 3 1/2 per cent. in the principal foreign markets as the immediate response to the news from this side (to March 18) of SHERMAN's occupation of Fayetteville, N.C., and of SHERIDAN's cavalry raid from the Shenandoah Valley to the James River. Intelligence of SHERMAN's occupation of Goldsboro, and junction with SCHOFIELD; of the Council of War at City Point; and of the great events preceding (and including) the fall of Richmond and Petersburgh, has, by this time, reached Europe. In about a week from the present date, the official account of the capitulation of LEE, and the practical termination of the war, will be in Europe. Such decisive news must inevitably lead to unusual activity and a further very decided rise in the funded stocks of our government in foreign markets. It cannot be denied that this is the prevailing opinion among the most sagacious bankers and brokers here. Very few, if any, considerable lots of our national securities already in Europe will find their way back to this country, in the face of this recent glorious news. On the contrary, all the signs of the times distinctly indicate that the current of our funded stocks will be decidedly in the opposite direction.

abstract: The change to; Drafting Stopped
snippet: The change to; Drafting Stopped
lead_paragraph: Probably no act of the Government of the United States was ever received by its people with profounder satisfaction than the general order, just issued, stopping all drafting and recruiting, and announcing the speedy reduction of all branches of the military establishment. It was the first practical earnest that this dreadful war had indeed ended. To tens of thousands of families, who have been for weeks haunted by day and night with the terror of having a father, a son, a brother, taken away from them for years, perhaps forever, it brought a relief which no language can describe. To a vastly greater number of families yet, who for months and years have been in sorrow for the absence of a loved one, and in daily apprehension of tidings of his death, or of a capture entailing horrors worse than death, it brought a hardly less joyful assurance of an early reunion. And then there was the pleasure, hardly worthy to be mentioned, perhaps, in this connection, yet gladly coming home to the "business and bosoms" of millions -- the pleasure of being spared any further increase of the burdens of taxation, already very hard to be borne. One of the most wonderful things of this war is the cheerfulness with which the people have met the immense taxes and voluntary contributions necessary to support it. But this cheerfulness was no token that the sacrifice was light. To multitudes that sacrifice trenched far upon the comforts, and even upon the necessaries of life. An intense love of country alone braced the people up to its acceptance. How far it could have continued to augment without reaching that point where endurance is no longer possible, it is impossible to calculate. It is enough that every man feels it to be a great personal blessing to himself that it is to go no further.

abstract: THE FUNERAL OF COL. JANEWAY. -- The funeral of the late Col. HUGH H. JANEWAY, First New-Jersey Cavalry, killed in battle near J[???]ttersville, will take place this (Saturday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock, in the First Presbyterian Church, Washington-street, Jersey City. The special committee appointed by the Common Council to make arrangements for the obsequies, request of the citizens to close their places of business during the funeral ceremonies, and that the flags on the shipping and on all private residences be displayed during the day at half mast. The remains will be conveyed to New-Brunswick for interment.

abstract: At the moment when Secretary STANTON announced the end of drafting and recruiting throughout the country, New-York City was supplying volunteers for the national army at the rate of forty-six thousand a year. This the city was doing under most disadvantageous circumstances, arising from the insufficiency of the, available State bounty fund, the hectoring of petty military officials, and their refusal latterly, to allow substitutes to be mustered in by the County Volunteer Committee. Last, as well as first in the grand national struggle, New-York presents a record that no other community in the Union can show. It is almost time that this fact was generally recognized.

abstract: Weitzel's Gen. Safe Conducts at Richmond; Mischief Makers on Gen. Weitzel's Exchange
snippet: Weitzel's Gen. Safe Conducts at Richmond; Mischief Makers on Gen. Weitzel's Exchange
lead_paragraph: The accession of Gen. ORD to the immediate command in Richmond is so directly in the natural order of military arrangements, that it requires no ordinary share of the faculty of malicious invention for a newsmonger to pervert it into a censure of Gen. WEITZEL's conduct. A Philadelphia story was allowed to circulate, during the greater part of yesterday, by which it was made to appear that Gen. WEITZEL, in giving safe conduct to certain "Confederate" representatives of Virginia to assemble in Richmond, had disobeyed the orders of his superiors. Gen. WEITZEL did grant facilities for certain citizens of Virginia to assemble and discuss the question of the readmission of the State into the Union. But the statement that his doing so was the cause of his removal, is simply a mischievous falsehood. We are asked to give the story contradiction, and we readily do so. But the evil its circulation was intended to compass, was done when it was allowed to pass through the hands of the telegraph censor. One would suppose, that if a censorship is any longer necessary or useful, or ornamental, the suppression of such malicious paragraphs as this would have been attended to before it had gone through a hundred different offices, and been put in the hands of probably a million of credulous readers. If Gen. WEITZEL had been removed for allowing representative Virginians to meet and deliberate over the return of the State to its allegiance, the inference would be that the War Department was at issue with Gen. GRANT, if not also with the President himself. To create such an impression as this, even for a few hours, would temporarily serve no end of schemes. And it would, no less, gratify that class of intemperate politicians who are now bawling -- each louder than the other -- to have their peculiar theories of reconstruction, of subjugation, of retribution, and so forth, adopted. The mischief-makers here need the closest sort of watching. They are more dangerous, for the time than the disjointed bands of insurgents that still wear the ragged livery of JEFF. DAVIS.

abstract: GERMAN OPERA. Mr. GROVER'S announcement of his forthcoming campaign of German opera is certainly a most interesting and encouraging document. It is replete with the promise of a brilliant and varied season.
lead_paragraph: GERMAN OPERA. -- Mr. GROVER's announcement of his forthcoming campaign of German opera is certainly a most interesting and encouraging document. It is replete with the promise of a brilliant and varied season. The repertoire is unusually large, and embraces all the grander works of the new school. Among these we notice GOUNOD's "Mircille," and MEYERBEER's "Huguenots" -- the first entirely fresh, and second comparatively so. Mr. GROVER's company has been increased and strengthened. It is sufficiently ample to play six times a week with safety. There will, however, only be four performances at the Academy next week, opening on Monday with "Faust." We are glad to see that BEETHOVEN's "Fidello" is to be given on Wednesday -- especially as it has been thoroughly rehearsed in the country. Mr. GROVER's orchestra and military band will be large and good. We are glad to hear that the sale of seats has been unusually encouraging.

abstract: At Salisbury; Ingenious Clock Made by
snippet: At Salisbury; Ingenious Clock Made by
lead_paragraph: -A number of Union mechanics, from the rebel prisons, now at the hospital of the Union Volunteer Refreshment saloon, brought with them from Dixie a piece of their handiwork, well worth special mention. It consists of a clock, made by several ingenious fellows, to wile away their weary hours, at Salisbury, N.C., during their imprisonment last Winter. The mainspring is made from the blade of a sabre which once belonged to Stonewall JACKSON. The hair-Spring and balance-wheel were taken from the telegraph-office ime-piece at Andersonville, Ga. The hands are made of a toasting-fork from the kitchen of Vice-President STEPHENS. The wheels are made from the mountings of carriages, &c., of prominent Southerners. The pillars which connect the frame are made of a ramrod, and nearly all the parts are taken from something picked up in the Confederacy, and have more or less, romance attached to them. A saw used in constructing this interesting little piece or mechanism was made of a table-knife, and files, jack-knives, &c., used in making rings, were often called into requisition by the anxious workmen. Should this meet the eve of any of the returned prisoners who were patients in hospital No. 2, it will remind them very forcibly of A.H. and his "perpetual motion." -- Philadelphia N. American.

abstract: The announcement, yesterday, that the draft and recruiting were suspended in this city by order of the Secretary of War, was joyfully received by every one except the bounty-brokers. A salute of one hundred guns was fired at the County Volunteer Committee's Rooms, and it was announced that the business of the office was at an end. The whole amount expended by the committee is about $8,000,000 -- of which about $2,000,000 is to be refunded by the State.

snippet: Litchfield, Conn. Enquirer; J. Humphrey Retires; His Successors; Card on His Alleged Frauds; Eugene, French Bark, with Valuable Cargo, Wrecked off Inagua; Missouri Iron Works, North Wheeling, boiler
lead_paragraph: Gov. FLETCHER, of Missouri, named April 15 (to-day) as the occasion for popular rejoicing. In his proclamation he recommends "that on that day the people, regardless of all differences of opinion in the past, meet in their respective places of worship, and unite in religious exercises, the evening of the day to be marked by large assemblages, to be addressed by patriotic speakers, and that, amid bonfires, illuminations and resounding salutes of artillery, they testify their appreciation of the heroism of the army of the Union in the reestablishment of the National authority in Richmond, the seat of the insurgent forces, the capture of the Army of Northern Virginia, and of the manifestations of a disposition on the part of men in authority to stay the effusion of blood of Americans and freemen."

abstract: Corsica, steamship; Fatal Explosion of Spirits
snippet: Corsica, steamship; Fatal Explosion of Spirits
lead_paragraph: A terrible accident occurred on board the steamship Corsica on her late passage from Havana to this port, which resulted in the death of two persons, and three others seriously injured. It appears that when four hours out from port, a barrel of spirits was about being lowered into the lower hold, when, owing to some wrong management in arranging the slings, the barrel slipped, and fell with great force into the hold, where it immediately burst. The storekeeper, Mr. JOHN HUGHES, who was in the hold at the time, with several others, upon seeing the occurrence, went immediately to the barrel, and having a lighted candle in his hand, it set fire to the spirits, which exploded, killing Mr. HUGHES instantly, and mortally wounding the carpenter, Mr. L. MCNEAL, who died last night. Three others of the crew, named MITCHELL, THOMPSON and MURPHY, are seriously injured, but will recover.

abstract: Maj.-Gen. HANCOCK, in apprizing the citizens of the Middle Department, says, evidently with reference to MOSBY's guerrillas: "The marauding bands which have so long infested this section, subsisting on the plunder of the defenceless, effecting no great military purpose, and bringing upon you the devastation of your homes, must no longer find shelter and concealment among you. Every outrage committed by them, will be followed by the severest infliction, and it is the purpose of the Major-General Commanding to destroy utterly the haunts of these bands if their depredations are continued."

abstract: -The present year is thus far marked by violent and unusual storms. In India, the terrible cyclone that destroyed so many lives was the precursor of other convulsions of nature throughout the world. In Scotland, the severity of the Winter and depth of the snow were very severe and remarkable. In our own land, the Spring freshets were attended with great loss of property and of life. On the English coast, the Winter storms wrecked many a vessel, freighted with goods and precious lives, and in February last a most destructive flood visited the Mauritius; torrents of water rushed down the mountains about Port Louis with a fury known only to tropical crimes, and before evening the water was five or six feet in depth in the commercial part of the town; more than half a million dollars' worth of property was destroyed, and many lives lost. Recently we have seen the same turbulence of nature manifested in the breaking up of the ice on the St. Lawrence at Montreal.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Annual supply Bill was reported. A report against the retention of the present Commissioners of Charities and Correction was agreed to. A report was received from the committees to investigate municipal frauds in New-York. The Governor sent a veto on the Dry Dock Railroad Bill. Bills were passed to relieve the Croton Aqueduct; incorporate the New Rochelle Savings Bank; to to incorporate the Long Island Savings Band; to incorporate the Harry Howard Association of Exempt Firemen; to consolidate the Brooklyn and Ca[???]arsie and Bergen-street railroads. The New-York Central Railroad Fare Bill was adopted, after a sharp contest, by 18 to 14.

abstract: Times, Prophecies of
snippet: Times, Prophecies of
lead_paragraph: may have noticed that latterly we have taken no notice of the ponderous and pretentious letters of the London Times' special correspondent, and, indeed, have only brought the "Thunderer's" own pompous malice before our readers, when to do so was necessary to give to the public information as to the current of opinion abroad in regard to our affairs. It has long been noticed that whenever the London Times uttered one of its solemn prophecies with judicial air, the paper containing it was sure to arrive here either just after or just before the occurrence of an event directly in the face of the prediction. In these performances the special correspondent has beaten the home editor always, out and out; and has prophesied the thing that did not happen, and asserted "the thing that is not" twice to his principal's once. The following passage in his letter last arrived is too good to be passed over under the circumstances:

abstract: Cobb, >amp;c.--What Should be their Fate; The Murder of; President Lincoln
snippet: Cobb, >amp;c.--What Should be their Fate; The Murder of; President Lincoln
lead_paragraph: The heart of this nation was stirred yesterday as it has never been stirred before. The news of the assassination of ABRAHAM LINCOLN carried with it a sensation of horror and of agony which no other event in our history has ever excited. In this city the demonstrations of grief and consternation were without a parallel. Business was suspended. Crowds of people thronged the streets -- great gatherings sprung up spontaneously everywhere seeking to give expression, by speeches, resolutions, &c., &c., to the universal sense of dismay and indignation which pervaded the public mind.

abstract: The; Leaders; Treatment they should Receive
snippet: The; Leaders; Treatment they should Receive
lead_paragraph: The men who have filled prominent positions in the rebel army have, as a general rule, had no share in getting up the rebellion. They drew the sword in it, after the politicians had decreed it should take place, many of them, no doubt, from a mistaken sense of allegiance to their respective States, and others in the hope of more rapid promotion than they were likely to have in the United States army; and others again, for mere love of excitement, or from a feeling of sympathy with their neighbors. In the large majority of cases, if not in all, these men are sufficiently punished by their total defeat, by the hardships of the last four years, and by the loss of their commanders. It may, therefore be expedient to let them go home quietly, and ch ew the cud of bitter fancy. Their memories of the rebellion during the remainder of their lives are not likely to be agreeable.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebel Leaders and the Treatment they Should Receive.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebel Leaders and the Treatment they Should Receive.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: CUSTIS LEE, captured at Burkesville, is the second son of Gen. ROBERT E. LEE, Commander-in-Chief of the Confederate armies. Gen. ROBERT LEE had three sons in that army, Gen. G.W. CUSTIS LEE, who was educated at West Point, and is about 33 years of age; WM.H. FITZHUGH LEE, educated at William and Mary's College, in Virginia, but subsequently held a second lieutenancy in the United States army, and who is reported to have been killed last week at Five Forks, in his 27th year and ROBERT E. LEE, Jr., 20 years of age. The latter has been taught in a military school in Virginia, and was a member of JEFF. DAVIS' staff. There are three other children surviving-daughters. None of the children married but WM.H.F. LEE who it will be recollected, was a prisoner on this side at one time, having been captured at home in Hanover County. Va., after being wounded in the famous cavalry fight at Beverly Ford. He was confined up North as a hostage for Capt. SAWYER, and on the letter's release passed through Baltimore on his way South. Gen. R.E. LEE is the son of Gen. HENRY LEE, of revolutionary memory. There is also a FITZHUGH LEE, cousin of the sons of Gen. ROBERT E. LEE, who succeeded to the command of Gen. J.E.B. STUART's cavalry corps at the latter's death. It was in this corps that WM.H.F. LEE, as a Brigadier, commanded a division from the time he returned South until his supposed death, on the 2d inst., before Petersburgh. His first expedition of any importance was in June 1862, when, under STUART, he made the circuit of MCCLELLAN's army, on the Pamunkey River. At this time he was a Cononel commanding a brigade. -- Baltimore Sun.

abstract: Grant's, Gen, Sister Clara; Railroads, Gov Fenton's Veto of Dry Dock Co.; Brooklyn Navy-Yard; Strike; Particulars; Veto of N Y Dry Dock and R R.
snippet: Grant's, Gen, Sister Clara; Railroads, Gov Fenton's Veto of Dry Dock Co.; Brooklyn Navy-Yard; Strike; Particulars; Veto of N Y Dry Dock and R R.
lead_paragraph: Saturday morning we availed ourselves of the opportunity of walking over the identical spot of earth once occupied as headquarters by the Commander-in-Chief of all the armies in the proposed Confederate States. It is a picturesque little eminence about two and a half miles west of Petersburgh, to the right of the highway going out from the city. The country all about is rolling and variegated with landscape and forest, with little streams winding about here and there, and on the whole is one of the most romantic and beautiful localities we have seen anywhere in Virginia. The particular eminence occupied by Gen. LEE goes by the appellation of "Edgehill," on the plantation owned by Maj. WILLIAM TURNBULL, Presiding Magistrate of Dinwiddie County and one of the chief men in the Masonsic fraternity, being at the present time Grand Commandant of Knight Templars in Petersburgh. He is not a military man, though by common consent denominated in this region a Major. It was in the house of this gentleman the distinguished General, since the 1st of November last, made his residence.

abstract: not always their own monuments, it is proposed by some, to select from the ruins of Richmond the most perfect specimens of brick and granite that can be found, and rear in the midst of the wasted arena --made a desert by fire a monument that shall stand through all time -- inlaid with tablets, commemorative of the infamy of those who sought to destroy, by treachery, a city they could not hold by force, of arms, and never expected to retake. In our opinion, no haste need be made to erect a monument, the ruins themselves will constitute one for years to come: and then history will have recorded their infamy. -- Richmond Whig.

abstract: St Louis; Frauds in
snippet: St Louis; Frauds in
lead_paragraph: weeks past the United States Revenue Collector for this district has had his suspicions excited that a system of fraud in the manufacture and sale of whisky was being carried on, with the purpose of evading the payment of the tax on that article. The tax itself is $2 per gallon, and yet whisky has been sold in large lots as low as $2 75 per gallon -- a transaction, which, if correct, would leave only 15 cents per gallon for the value of the spirits. The collector has been diligently at work to procure evidence sufficient to warrant a seizure, and has at last been successful. He has seized about 1,500 barrels of whisky in this city for fraudulent evasion of the revenue tax. All this whisky is from Illinois -- some from Belleville, some from Pekin, some from Grafton, and some from other points where the manufacture of highwines is extensively carried on. The value of the seizure is something like $130,000 to $150,000.
