lead_paragraph: The terrible calamity which has befallen our country engrosses every thought and wrings every heart. We give up the printing of ordinary news to record, so far as feeble words call express the great sorrow of the nation. It would be presumption to undertake to condense that expression into the limits of a news column. Every word of extended detail will be read with tea[???]med eyes and bleeding hearts by a people bowed down in the valley of humiliation by a disaster never equalled in the history of the continent. Beside a few insignificant exceptions, we know but one sentiment in reference to the event, and that is of mingled grief and vengeance; grief that the man on whom our des[???]les seemed to hinge should be thus sna[???]d away in the moment of our utmost need, and revenge that the infernal spirit of treason should have found or made, just in the dawn of loyal triumph, occasion for a tragedy so terrible in its social and political aspects.

abstract: attempt to express in words the deep sorrow with which the death of our noble President has filled all hearts. To the honor of our people be it said, that, with a few unimportant exceptions, the nation's heart throbs with the profoundest grief, and the utterances of the nation's voice are all in accord in lamentation. The great calamity was scarcely known, and where known was hardly believed, at the late hour of its announcement on Friday night. But early yesterday morning we were assured of the mournful truth. As one man the people put on the habiliments of mourning, and the glad songs of triumph over the anticipated advent of peace were subdued to the wail of such grief as only a nation can feel. All day the stunned and bewildered citizens, were putting forth the emblems of mourning. Business was almost entirely suspended. Sorrow was visible on every face, not seldom varied with an expression that partook of revenge. The low, earnest conversation of friends, the almost fearful greetings of acquaintances, the entire absence of the ordinary hum and bustle of business, fittingly marked the people's appreciation of their bereavement. It was a day never paralleled, and never to be forgotten.

abstract: millions of people in the loyal and border States, perhaps more than one-half were yesterday apprized of the violent death of President "LINCOLN. The telegraph brings us brief notices of their feelings upon this dreadful catastrophe. There is but one expression in its silent flashes. Sorrow, deep and unfeigned sorrow, that words cannot fitly shadow forth, fills every hamlet and every heart from the Madawaska to the Pacific; a sorrow that is only beginning, and will be felt and expressed for months and years to come.

abstract: Friendly Word from on President's Death
snippet: Friendly Word from on President's Death
lead_paragraph: -- Yesterday was the time appointed for the official promulgation of laws in Nova Scotia, but the Governor, with a delicacy and feeling that does him great honor, announced that in consequence of the shocking intelligence of the assassination of President LINCOLN he should postpone the ceremony. The people most cordially responded to his manly expression, and the naval authorities gave further proof of brotherly feeling by ordering the flag of a rebel vessel lying in Halifax harbor to be hauled down. Such tokens fall like cooling dew upon the nation's burning sorrow.

lead_paragraph: Senate has refused to confirm the four Fire Commissioners nominated by the Governor. This action was taken not from any hostility, personal or political, to the Governor, nor from any special personal objection to the nominees, but from a conviction that it was due to the New-York public, and absolutely indispensable to the success of the great experiment which this commission is to make, that it should not be partizan in its character.

abstract: has courage, judgment and patriotism; Bereavement, the; Character and Virtues
snippet: has courage, judgment and patriotism; Bereavement, the; Character and Virtues
lead_paragraph: Death, as the Northmen imaged him, is no dart-brandishing skeleton, but a gigantic shape, that in wraps mortals within the massive folds of its dark garment. Long has it been since those dread robes closed upon a mightier victim than President LINCOLN. It is like the earth's opening and swallowing up a city. The public loss is so great, the chasm made in our national councils so tremendous, that the mind, not knowing how to adjust itself to such a change, shrinks back appalled. It comes home to every bosom with the force of a personal affliction. There is not a loyal family in the land that does not mourn. It is as when there "was a great cry in Egypt, for there was not a house where there was not one dead."

abstract: It was a solemn season in the churches yesterday. The usual exultation appropriate to Easter Sunday was postponed to some extent, and everywhere the services partook largely of the popular feeling of the hour. Most of the places of worship were decorated with elaborate emblems of mourning, and not a few displayed the most elaborate resources of art and taste in these silent recognitions of grief. Our reporters have condensed below a few notes, taken in a hasty visit to the churches most accessible at morning worship.

abstract: mediately after our army took possession of Charleston, the President wrote a letter to the commanding officer, directing him to inquire after the family of the late JAMES L. PETIGRU, and to provide them with whatever they might need. He inclosed fifty dollars as a personal contribution toward their wants, if they should be in a condition to require it. Special instructions were also given to secure them full protection and the quiet occupation of their home. Mr. PETIGRU, it will be remembered, was one of the most distinguished lawyers of South Carolina, and stood firm and immovable, though almost alone, in his devotion to the Union, through all the madness of nullification in 1832, and of secession at a later day. Like every other Southern Union man he was reduced to poverty by his course, but his high-toned integrity and his unflinching devotion to principle, commanded the respect even of his most bitter political foes. We are glad to learn that very considerable sums of money have been raised in Boston and New-York for the relief of the surviving members of his family.

abstract: Second Inaugural; Political History and Antecedents
snippet: Second Inaugural; Political History and Antecedents
lead_paragraph: ANDREW JOHNSON has been in continuous public life for thirty years. He entered the General Assembly of Tennessee ae a member of the House of Representatives the first Monday in October, 1835, from the County of Greene, in East Tennessee. He was reclected to the succeeding biennial Assembly in 1837, and again in 1839. In 1841 he was transferred to the State Senate by the Counties of Washington, Greene and Sullivan. In 1843 to a seat in Congress from the First Representative District, comprising the same counties and the new County of Johnson. He served the same district, by four successive reelections, until the new apportionment under the census of 1850, in all ten years, when, in 1853, he was made Governor of Tennessee, and was subsequently reelected in 1855. At the end of his second term, in 1857, he was made United States Senator, his term expiring on the 4th of March, 1863, since when, and until his recent election as Vice-President of the United States, he was Military Governor of Tennessee.

abstract: War news gives place to the absorbing subject of the assassination. The funeral of President LINCOLN will take place on Wednesday, the 19th. the anniversary of the battle of Lexington ninety years ago, and of the first deaths in our civil war four years ago when the Sixth Massachusetts was attacked by the secession mob in Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: War news gives place to the absorbing subject of the assassination. The funeral of President LINCOLN will take place on Wednesday, the 19th. the anniversary of the battle of Lexington ninety years ago, and of the first deaths in our civil war four years ago when the Sixth Massachusetts was attacked by the secession mob in Baltimore. Mr. SEWARD was reported yesterday morning as decidedly improved, but at night he was not quite so well. The latest bulletin states that FRDERICK SEWARD is gradually sinking; his recovery is barely probable. We hear and see but one expression among the people -- that of the profoundest sorrow, mingled with anxiety for the future. Mr. JOHNSON has taken the oath of office and assumed his duties, but of course has done very little business of an official character. Thus far the assassins seem to have eluded their pursuers; at least we have no announcement of their capture.

abstract: The Death of
snippet: The Death of
lead_paragraph: moment of our great domestic loss comes news of the death of the ablest and most intelligent friend of our country abroad, RICHARD COBDEN. Few English statesmen, living or dead, have rendered greater service to the cause of liberty, at home or abroad, than the leader of the Free-trade party of Great Britain. His loss to his countrymen will become more appreciable in years hereafter than it is to-day. Much of the seed he sowed, as a social and political reformer, will spring up and bear fruit in the future. With us his eminent worth, his large and enlightened views, his catholic sympathies with progress throughout the world, his entire freedom from the insular prejudices which mark so large a proportion of his countrymen, gave him a claim upon the regard of the American people which will cause his memory to be long cherished.

abstract: Last Address to the Country
snippet: Last Address to the Country
lead_paragraph: Probably all men in all quarters of the world, who read President LINCOLN'S last Inaugural Address, were impressed by the evident tone of solemnity in it, and the want of any expression of personal exultation. There he stood, after four years of such trial, and exposed to such hate and obloquy as no other great leader in modern history has experienced, successful, reelected, his policy approved by the people and by the greater test of events, the terrible rebellion evidently coming to its end, and he himself now certain of his grand position in the eyes of history -- and yet not a word escaped him of triumph, or personal glory, or even of much hopefulness. We all expected more confidence -- words promising the close of the war and speaking of the end of our difficulties. Many hoped for some definite line of policy to be laid out in this address. But instead, we heard a voice as if from some prophet, looking with solemn gaze down over the centuries, seeing that both sides in the great contest had their errors and sins, that no speedy victory could be looked for, and yet that the great Judge of the world would certainly give success to right and justice. The feeling for the bondmen and the sense of the great wrong done to them, with its inevitable punishment, seemed to rest with such solemn earnestness on his soul, that to the surprise of all and the derision of the flippant, an official speech became clothed in the language of the Bible. The English and French critics all observed this peculiar religious tone of the Inaugural, and nearly all sensible persons felt it not unsuited to the grandeur and momentous character of the events accompanying it. Many pronounced it a Cromwellian speech; but it had one peculiarity, which CROMWELL's speeches never possessed -- a tone of perfect kindness and good-will to all, whether enemies or political opponents.

abstract: National Affairs and President Lincoln's Death
snippet: National Affairs and President Lincoln's Death
lead_paragraph: The death of President LINCOLN naturally excites universal and profound solicitude as to the immediate future of the country. He has been so marked a figure in the terrible events of the last four years, the action of the government in its contest with the rebellion has been so stamped by the impress of his personal character, and he had come to have so strong a hold upon the confidence and love of the whole people, without distinction of party, that his sudden removal from the stage of events naturally excites anxiety and apprehension in the public mind. He does, indeed, seem to have been needed to close the great work of pacification which he had so well begun.

abstract: Considerable feeling has been manifested the past day Or two among certain passionate men in this district, and, in some instances, it has taken the shape of vengeance. Men occupying prominent positions in the community, and who have been, heretofore, known as violent anti-Administration men, have been threatened so openly with mob violence that many have appealed to the police for protection.
lead_paragraph: Considerable feeling has been manifested the past day Or two among certain passionate men in this district, and, in some instances, it has taken the shape of vengeance. Men occupying prominent positions in the community, and who have been, heretofore, known as violent anti-Administration men, have been threatened so openly with mob violence that many have appealed to the police for protection. Dr. WM.B. HURD, residing at No. 77 Fourth-st., E.D., yesterday claimed, through his friends, the protection of Capt. WOGLOM, of the forty-fifth Precinct, his house having been threatened by a mob. When the caption called upon Dr. HURD he was informed by that gentleman, that no word or thought of his could give offence to any, and that his sorrow for the horrible crime committed was as sincere and intense as that of any man in the community. Dr. HURD further stated that, although he was opposed, politically, to the members of the national government, his admiration for the personal character and recent magnanimous actions of the late President was hearty and profound. The police are fully prepared to repress all outbursts of passion and vengeance.

lead_paragraph: As yet the details of the great demonstration on on Wednesday next are unknown. Whatever they may be, the vast population of this city will see to it that, with all fitting regard to the solemnity of the occasion, they are carried into effect. At no period in the nation's history have our people so unanimously testified, by outward act, their feelings of rejoicing or despondency. The city is literally draped in mourning; our streets are filled with sobered, people, upon whose clothing are tied the insignia of grief; the stores, hotels, residences, and resorts of the inhabitants, are decked in trappings of funeral hue, and truly it may be said, the people go about sorrowing, and refuse to be comforted.

abstract: On Friday last JOHN McKINNEY, keeper of the cottage in the Ramble at Central Park, discovered the body of an unknown man lying in a secluded spot at the south side of the Ramble, at a short distance from the waterfall. The body was conveyed to the Arsenal building by Policeman JOHN RUSSELL, where an inquest was held yesterday by Coroner COLLIN.
lead_paragraph: On Friday last JOHN McKINNEY, keeper of the cottage in the Ramble at Central Park, discovered the body of an unknown man lying in a secluded spot at the south side of the Ramble, at a short distance from the waterfall. The body was conveyed to the Arsenal building by Policeman JOHN RUSSELL, where an inquest was held yesterday by Coroner COLLIN. From the evidence it appears that a single-barreled pistol, which had been discharged, was found near the corpse, and beside which was a flageolet, under which was a note-book, containing a letter and a fragment of a letter, both written in French. Dr. ROBINSON examined the body and found a lacerated wound of the head covering nearly the whole of the temporal bone on the right side, nearly all of the bone driven in. The wound was evidently produced by a bullet and not by a fall. There was fatty degeneration of the heart and liver, and from the condition of the intellectual organs. Dr. ROBINSON is of the opinion that deceased was subject to fits of hypochondriasis, during one of which he committed the fatal act. A verdict in accordance with the above facts was rendered by the jury. Deceased was apparently about 25 years of age, five feet seven inches high, and a native of France. The following is a translation of the letter found in his note-book:

abstract: This important subject is ably discussed in a new work by Dr. FRANCIS LIEBER. This patriotic jurisconsult exhibits great research, caution and learning. He desires to make our constitution perfect and sound as a rock of adamant. He cites numerous facts from foreign histories to illustrate his conclusions, without wearying the reader, for conciseness is the literary charm of this work. Dr. LIEBER has prepared a series of proposed amendments of the constitution, which he submits to "the consideration of the American people." They certainly deserve the earnest consideration of every right-minded citizen. The work is issued by the Loyal Publication Society.

abstract: Hardeman, Noted Guerrilla, Captured in Tenn.; Winding Up of the War
snippet: Hardeman, Noted Guerrilla, Captured in Tenn.; Winding Up of the War
lead_paragraph: We have news of two events this morning which indicate the closing up of the war in all the States of the late Confederacy -- with the exception, perhaps, of Texas. We have definite information of the capture of the City of Mobile by Gen. CANBY, on the 9th inst. -- the day of the surrender of the army of Gen. LEE; and we have news that at the close of last week Gen. JOHNSTON was in negotiation with Gen. SHERMAN relative to the surrender of the remaining rebel army. As SHERMAN is authorized to offer to JOHNSTON the same terms that Lieut.-Gen. GRANT offered to LEE, we doubt not they have been accepted by this time.

abstract: Surrender and Opinion on Peace
snippet: Surrender and Opinion on Peace
lead_paragraph: various matters which the pressure upon our columns compels us to postpone, to an interesting letter from one of our army correspondents, describing the incidents attending the surrender and paroling of LEE's army. He writes that Gen. LEE, in conversation with our officers, expressed the opinion that if reasonable clemency was shown to the South, the war would be virtually at an end, and that nothing but the prospect of a general rigid enforcement of the laws they had broken could lead the Southern people to prolong the struggle. In the rebel army generally the belief prevailed that all their prominent officers would be executed as traitors, and the opinion was freely expressed that this belief had led to the desperate resistance hitherto shown by the rebel armies. As a general thing, the took the surrender very calmly, few of them exhibiting any special emotion. Gen. LEE himself was very much affected, and in attempting a speech to the soldiers under LONGSTREET, he was obliged to desist from the depth of his feeling. The whole number of LEE's army is stated at 60,000.

lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letter from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader: and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Lesson for Europe; Executive Power of U S Government
snippet: Lesson for Europe; Executive Power of U S Government
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN, the head and hope, as was thought, of the Republic was stricken down at a blow. On the first day which followed the tidings, the subscriptions to the popular loan reached a higher figure than for weeks before, and in the first open market Government Securities sold at an advance. Thus is illustrated the public confidence in the staunchness of our institutions. Nothing is so timorous as credit. It begins to sink at the very first shade of uncertainty. Yet here it does not even flutter. It rises with a renewed strength.

lead_paragraph: MYSTERIOUS DEATH OF A WEALTHY STOCKBROKER. -- A mysterious death is reported from Thirdavenue, near Forty-seventh-street, involving, it is said, both murder and robbery. It appears that at a late hour on Sunday night, an officer of the Twentyfirst Precinct Police found on the sidewalk in front of No. 686 Third-avenue, the body of MAURICE BEAVSEEOIN, of No. 10 Waverley-place. The corpse was taken to the Station-house, and a Coroner was notified, as usual, and the case being regarded as of only ordinary interest, the police took no further steps, merely holding the body awaiting the arrival of Coroner GOVER; but later in the day, through friends of the deceased, it was ascertained that when Mr. BEAVSEEOIN left home on Sunday afternoon he had $2,000, a gold watch, and other valuable property. When found by the police, the body had been stripped of all these, and it is therefore feared that a foul murder has been committed. Mr. BEAVSEEOIN, who was a wealthy stock-broker, was a native of France, aged about 40 years. Coroner GOVER will institute an investigation at noon to-day at Bellevue Hospital.

snippet: Stonewall Affair with Portugal Settled; Stonewall Affair; The, Settled
lead_paragraph: -- There is a prompt and pacific end to the trouble between our naval Commanders at Lisbon and the Portuguese authorities. The Governor of the fort from which fire was opened on the American cruiser Niagara, has been removed, agreeably to the demand of our Minister at Lisbon. The matter will be allowed to rest here, so far as Portugal is concerned. And by the time the pirate reaches a new harbor, the intimation that we are about to institute retaliatory measures will doubtless have reached Europe.

abstract: Booth's Cowardice and Low Character; Cowardice of his Murder
snippet: Booth's Cowardice and Low Character; Cowardice of his Murder
lead_paragraph: There is no danger, let us hope, of either of the assassins rising, in the vulgar apprehen- sion, to the condition of criminal heroes. An inquest into the form and circumstance of the deed committed at Ford's Theatre reduces the actor to the grade of a very ordinary sort of felon. Between him and his confederate, who aimed at the prostrate and helpless Secretary of State in his sick chamber, the merit of heroic daring may be almost evenly divided. The "stroller" at the play-house has certainly less the advantage in this regard than at first blush might appear. Both rank essentially with the Bealls and Kennedys, who illustrated the chivalry of the rebellion on the scaffold as convicted incendiaries, compassing a violent death for hundreds of unconscious citizens, regardless of sex or age, in our hotels and along the lines of railroad and steamboat travel. The successive protests of these ruffians that they were Virginia "gentlemen" failed to relieve them not merely from the ignominy of justly-condemned criminals, but from the status of cowardly felons as well. It is important, looking to the examplar which a really great malefactor invariably becomes for the graduates in crime, that we should see to it, that neither the glare of the footlights, the trick and swagger of the mountebank, nor the accessories of the "property" room which this vagabond mimic knew how to appropriate, shall be allowed to make the criminal, by so much as one degree, less a poltroon than the essential facts of the murder will warrant.

abstract: (Melbourne) Authorities Refuse Supplies to the Shenandoah; The, Threatening the Melbourne Authorities
snippet: (Melbourne) Authorities Refuse Supplies to the Shenandoah; The, Threatening the Melbourne Authorities
lead_paragraph: THREAT. -- The colonial authorities of Melbourne, Australia, have set an example which might well have been supplied at an earlier date by the central government, and by the western dependencies of the British Empire. The pirate Shenandoah has been lying at the port of Melbourne for several weeks, and it now transpires that the cause of her detention is the refusal of the local government to allow her provisioning for starting on a new expedition, and continuing her depredations on our commerce. This refusal of "belligerent" rights by the Victoria government, has drawn from the commander of the pirate a protest and a threat which read like a parody of the broadest kind of farce. The conduct of the colonial, authorities, is to be reported to Richmond -- nothing less! The subject, however, assumes more serious form, when we remember that it is precisely this species of impotent threat that has made the governments of Western Europe the servants and instruments of this wretched imposture of a Confederacy, which has thus prolonged its infamous existence, which has alienated to a painful extent the respect and friendship of the American people, and which has led, by no indirect pathway, to the culminating crime of the conspirators that, to-day, spreads a pall of immeasurable sorrow over all the land.

lead_paragraph: After the opening of the Court HENRY BREWSTER Esq., said: If the court please, since last we met an awful, a direful calamity has overtaken the country; one that has overwhelmed the nation in deepseated grief. We have none of us the feelings or the spirit requisite to transact our ordinary business. Just as the rainbow of hope was beginning to be visible through the parting storm-clouds which for the past four years have enveloped our land, we are again placed in darkness. Just at the moment when our great and good President was reveling in the exuberance of his joy over a united country, he has been snatched away by the hand of a dastardly assassin. He has been taken at a time, too, when he was ready to forgive and forget, and when the nation was hopeful and full of joy. In view of the deep feeling of grief that now pervaded the entire community, and in view of the respect which was due to the memory of the deceased, the speaker said that he now moved that the court adjourn.

abstract: Again we devote nearly the whole of our space to details of the action of the people in regard to our national calamity. The public mind does not yet recover from the dreadful shock; ordinary affairs excite no interest, and even such events...
lead_paragraph: Again we devote nearly the whole of our space to details of the action of the people in regard to our national calamity. The public mind does not yet recover from the dreadful shock; ordinary affairs excite no interest, and even such events as the settlement of the pirate Stonewall matter, the capture of Mobile, or the movements of GRANT and LEE are read or heard with the most passive indifference. To-day occurs the funeral at Washington, of our beloved leader, and solemn recognition of the fact will be made in every section of the loyal land. To-morrow his body will lie in state in Washington; on Friday will begin the sad journey to his old home in Illinois, resting awhile at Baltimore, at Philadelphia and at New-York -- at the latter place, we believe, over Sunday. This will close a week of such widely-felt sorrow as New-York has not known since the death of WASHINGTON.

abstract: There is barely an exception to the universal feeling of friendly sympathy and deep sorrow which find expression throughout the neighboring provinces.
lead_paragraph: There is barely an exception to the universal feeling of friendly sympathy and deep sorrow which find expression throughout the neighboring provinces. The admirable article from the Toronto Globe, which we copy, undoubtedly reflects the all-prevailing sentiment in regard to the late President -- a sentiment not merely of profound respect, but something almost akin to personal affection. That there is an exception to this feeling is shown by the view of an assassination which is taken by the provincial organ of the rebels. That print, we believe, will be found to be the only so-called British newspaper in either hemisphere that will be able to find so self-satisfying a plea to justify the murder. It fitly represents the rebel refugees who celebrated the assassination at Toronto in a general debauch, over which "a Southern clergyman" very properly presided.

abstract: THE BRITISH RESIDENTS AND THE PUBLIC CALAMITY. -- We are bound to recognize the feelings and the taste which dictated the resolutions passed at a meeting of British residents, which was convened yesterday at the Astor House, under the presidency of Mr. Consul ARCHIBALD. The assembly was respectable in numbers, and equally so in character. The speaking and the formal record of the sympathies of those who attended were entirely commendable. And we trust the meeting may be taken as an earnest of the revival, once more, of the common friendship between the two nations which once existed, but which the jealousy and avarice fostered by this rebellion had all but uprooted. In the light of these closing scenes of the conspiracy, which threatened the national life, we doubt not many who at first saw in that conspiracy only a legitimate check to the progress of a great rival, will now discover the full hideousness of the thing they were tempted to nourish. Its expiring thrust will startle the "sympathizing" world from its complaisant mood, and show it what the system of the conspirators in its incarnate form has actually been from the beginning.

In the light of these closing scenes of the conspiracy, which threatened the national life, we doubt not many who at first saw in that conspiracy only a legitimate check to the progress of a great rival, will now discover the full hideousness of the thing they were tempted to nourish. Its expiring thrust will startle the "sympathizing" world from its complaisant mood, and show it what the system of the conspirators in its incarnate form has actually been from the beginning.

abstract: Toronto Globe on death of
snippet: Toronto Globe on death of
lead_paragraph: At twenty-two minutes after seven o'clock, on Saturday morning, about nine hours after he had received the shot of the assassin, ABRAHAM LINCOLN drew his last breath, surrounded by the members of his family, his Cabinet, and leading political and personal friends. His death would, under any circumstances, have produced an extraordinary sensation, but accompanied by murderous violence, the feeling; which has been created has been the most intense. No single event of the present century in America can at all compare with it in effect on the popular mind, and we think that in England the shock will be nearly as deeply felt. The grief which is expressed has two very distinct origins, the stronger of which seems to arise from personal sympathy and regard for the deceased. We hear in all quarters the strongest expressions of admiration of the character of Mr. LINCOLN, and deep sorrow that his noble career should have been brought to an untimely end. His simplicity of character, his straightforward honesty, his kindliness. even his bluntness of manner, seem to have won the popular heart, even among a foreign, and, in matter of opinion, a hostile nation. We may judge by that fact of his popularity among the citizens of the Northern States. Almost all of us feel as if we had suffered a personal loss. Mr. LINCOLN is spoken of in the same terms as are used toward a familiar friend. All mourn his untimely fate. He had risen by industry, ability and integrity to the great position of Chief Magistrate of his country. He found it in the most imminent danger, and his power to control the elements which were sweeping over the land were far from generally acknowledged. He was regarded with fear and trembling by the friends of his government, and with contempt by his opponents. But steadily he made his way. He was not the best man who could have been imagined for the post of Chief Magistrate in a great civil war. He had not the commanding force which infuses energy into all around him, and his public appearances were often lacking in dignity. But he was sagacious, patient, prudent, courageous, honest and candid. If he did not inspire great Generals, he gave every man in the army an opportunity of developing the talents within him. He recognized merit and rewarded it. He placed confidence, as a rdle, where it was due, and he had his reward in great military successes. Some say that he has been cut off at a favorable moment for his reputation, but we cannot accept this view. It seems to us that he had gone through his worst trials, that his patience, sagacity and honesty would have borne even better fruits in the settlement of the affairs of the South than during the wild commotion of the war. He has been cut off at a time when, certainly, he had accomplished a great deal, but leaving much undone which he was well qualified to do. A naturally strong man, of only fifty-six, he might have hoped to live many years after finishing his work as President, in the enjoyment of the respect and admiration justly due to one who had saved the life of his country. He will be held, we think, by Americans, if not equal to WASHINGTON, second to none but he. But he had not the gratification of his great predecessor, of seeing his work completed and enjoying for along period the gratitude of his conntrymen and the admiration of strangers. There are few so hard of heart as to not shed a tear over the sudden and Moody termination of so bright a career. As great as WASHINGTON in many moral and mental qualities, his genial character was calculated to win far more popular sympathy than his predecessor. Ability and honesty all admire, but when to them are added kindliness, simplicity, and freedom from selfishness. haughtiness and pride in high position, they win love as well as respect.

abstract: Brooklyn, Henry, Cut by Downey
snippet: Brooklyn, Henry, Cut by Downey
lead_paragraph: ATTEMPTED MURDER. -- Abut 1 o'clock on Sun- day morning, JOHN DOWNEY, an Irish laborer, attempted to take the life of Mr. MICHAEL HENRY, a favern-keeper, by cutting his throat with a razor. HENRY was seated in the oyster saloon of A. H. JACOBS, No. 1 York-street, when DOWNEY, who had just entered the soloon, rushed upon him and inflict-a gash on the left side of his neck four inches in length, severing one of the arteries, DOWNEY was immediately arrested. The cause of the outrage is supposed to have been HENRY's refusal on several occasions, to furnish DOWNEY with liquor. It is thought that HENEY's injuries will prove fatal.

abstract: The day of
snippet: The day of
lead_paragraph: The last sad rites are to begin to-day. Not they alone in the nation's capital will celebrate them, but the loyal millions from the Atlantic to the Pacific. Every city and town and village will be shrouded in mourning; the fervent stir of business will cease; the tolling of the bell will be heard; and from the thronged churches a nation's cry of sorrow and supplication will ascend to heaven.

abstract: -- The police can hardly need to be advised of the fact that the dead walls and fences throughout the city are placarded with bills, wherein the solemn subject on which the public mind is fixed is made to cover advertisements of fancy weapons, and other articles of commerce, suggested by the assassination. These and the equally objectionable bills, which take the form of inflammatory appeals, clearly ought to be prohibited. At least the advertisers should be compelled to show some regard to decency, while the city is enwrapped in the emblems of mourning.

abstract: The Slaves' Friend; Residents on the Death of President Lincoln; The Feeling on President Lincoln's Death; The day of Mourning for; Mourning for President Lincoln
snippet: The Slaves' Friend; Residents on the Death of President Lincoln; The Feeling on President Lincoln's Death; The day of Mourning for; Mourning for President Lincoln
lead_paragraph: One of the Commissioners for Emancipation was at Hilton Head in the earlier part of the war, and overheard a gang of negroes, working for the government, talk about their final chances for liberty. The question was raised among them whether the President knew their condition and would liberate them. An aged slave among them, who seemed a "class-leader," stopped his work, and, in the most impressive manner, said to them, with a certain awe which they all evidently responded to: "De President! Why, ob course he knows! He is ebrywhere! He is like depressed Lord; he walks de waters and de land!" This gentleman afterward related this incident to Mr. LINCOLN, and the kindhearted man had to turn away to the window to hide his tears at this instance of touching confidence and superstitious reverence in this simple-minded race toward himself.
headline: {'main': 'The Mourning of the Slaves.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mourning of the Slaves.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: GEORGE N. SANDERS sends us a note from Montreal, which we publish in another column. It implicates Hon. R.J. WALKER, so far as SANDERS' assertions can implicate anybody, in a disgraceful and criminal attempt to secure a surrender of the powers and rights of the government, as the price of peace with the rebellion. It is a little more contemptible, and a good deal more absurd, than the previous peace palavers which had disgusted the loyal sentiment of the country.

abstract: -- We learn that Col. ROBERT OULD, Confederate Commissioner of Exchange, Lieut.-Col. WILLIAM H. HATCH, his assistant, President BULLOCK, of the Southern Express Company, and H.A. HAMILTON, the agent, were captured within Gen. GRANT's lines, driving in a wagon, they having driven into the lines by mistake. Upon discovering their error they surrendered. The prisoners were brought to Richmond under guard, and were liberated on their parole on Thursday afternoon, we understand. One of the prisoners was present at the surrender of Gen. LEE, and describes the scene as a very impressive one. Gen. LEE delivered up his sword with great dignity, and it was received by Gen. GRANT in the same spirit. -- Richmond Whig, April 15.

abstract: The Key of
snippet: The Key of
lead_paragraph: -- Rev. Dr. BROWN, editor of the American Baptist, has in the possession the key of the notorious rebel prison, Castle Thunder. It was brought to this city by Rev. SOLOMON GALE, of Tolland, Conn., and it is intended to dispose of it by auction for the benefit of the orphans of our volunteers. The key is by no means a formidable-looking instrument, being about the size of our ordinary door-keys. It has apparently seen much service.

abstract: Out of respect to the memory of the late President, the people of this and the adjacent cities yesterday refrained from labor, trade or occupation, except such as pertained to travel and sustenance. The authorities very properly recommended that places of business should be closed, and the people, with a unanimity as touching as it was deserved, indorsed the suggestion most emphatically. On all occasions of festive demonstration the citizens of New-York assemble in the streets, the people of the rural districts throng the ears and other public convoyances, and joining their fellows, constitutes crowds great and multitudinous; but at these times, curiosity concerning the proposed procession, as desire to gape at the military display, or a reasonable yearning for a holiday, has much to do with the turnout.

abstract: On many notable occasions the people of New-York and vicinity have developed unanimity of sentiment. At divers times the citizens have risen as one man to testify their interest in, or their curiosity concerning, this or that individual. They have gathered in myriad throngs to welcome a CLAY, to gape at Eastern Ambassadors, to cheer the Prince of WALES, to witness the departure of regiments, to welcome home returning soldiers; but it was reserved for this first and greatest occasion of national bereavement to develop the deep-seated, unselfish feeling, which permeates every class alike, beating as truly in the heart of the most obscure as in that of the widest known or most respected. It needs no trumpet tone to sound abroad our grief. From every window in every street its mark may be seen. Modest and unassuming, or notably conspicuous, as the case nay be, it is evident, palpable and omnipresent. From the spires of our churches, from the domes of our halls, from every [???]ag-staff, from every pane of glass, on the lappel of the millionaire, about the arm of the laborer, on the shoulders of the women, on the dresses of our children, everywhere where life or home may be, are the insignia of grief, the physical and outward exponents of the sadness which reigns in every breast.

abstract: -- Coroner WILDEY held an inquest, on Tuesday, at the New-York Hospital, upon the person of JOHN PAGE, a person whose residence does not appear. On the 28th of March he was struck by an unknown man while passing through Liberty-street, near West, and the blow prostrated him to the pavement. When taken thence he was unconscious, and so remained down to the hour of his death at the hospital. Mr. JAMES E. WALKER, of No. 25 Clark-street, testified at the inquest that the unknown, alter striking the fatal blow, rolled PAGE's body into the gutter, and after depositing behind the counter of a porter-house on the corner the cart-rung with which the assault was committed, ran up Liberty-street and escaped. PAGE was aged about 35 years. The unknown murderer was about five feet eight inches in height, thick set, had dark hair and moustache, but no whiskers, and was well attired. The police have been able to secure no clue of him.

abstract: the Tallahasse at Liverpool
snippet: the Tallahasse at Liverpool
lead_paragraph: -- The Tallahassee, from Bermuda, is reported to have arrived at Liverpool. It will be interesting to hear what hospitality will be extended to her, or whether she is to fare as the Shenandoah has fared at Melbourne.

abstract: -- Rev. JOHN J. GEAR, Chaplain of the One Hundred and Eighty third Ohio Volunteers, who has been four years in active service and eight months in rebel prisons, will give an interesting narrative of his experience this evening, at 7:30 o'clock, at the New-York State Soldiers' Depot. Chaplain GEAR is the author of the book. A Yankee Prisoner Loose in Dixie, and comes on errand of mercy on behalf of the prisoners of Andersonville.
lead_paragraph: -- Rev. JOHN J. abstract: By the steamers Belgian, at Portland, and Persia and Pennsylvania at this port, we have three days' later new a from Europe. Mr. COLLINS, of the Inter-continental Telegraph, is a passenger. He has had entire success thus far, and now goes to Russian America to began operations. The difficulty between America and Portugal has been amicably settled. The Governor of the Belem Fort, has been dismissed, and the fort was to salute the American flag, with twenty-one guns. The Tallahassee had arrived at Liverpool from Bermuda. The most interesting matter in the British Parliament was the debate upon the defences of Canada. Mr. COBDEN's funeral was a grand testimonial to his honorable fame. The French Chambers were still debating the address with no prospect of closing. Count WALEWSKI had been seriously ill. The rumor of an expected outbreak in Venetia is contradicted. The question of the Duchies still occupies the Frankfort Diet. In Russia the plague engrosses attention; there had been 10,000 cases and 2,000 deaths in St. Petersburgh. There is much apprehension all over Europe lest this disease, which is thought to be the real old black plague, should spread all over the continent.

abstract: Yesterday's celebration will long be remembered in this city as the most remarkable testimonial ever paid to any man on this continent. lead_paragraph: Yesterday's celebration will long be remembered in this city as the most remarkable testimonial ever paid to any man on this continent. The day itself was one of the loveliest of Spring; the sky was clear, the sun moderately warm, and the wind just strong enough to float the ten thousand half-masted and muffled flags that gemmed the town. And after all the ingenious devicee that educated taste and lavish expense could produce, there was not one equal in grand and mournful beauty to our national banner; the glorious stars and stripes, alike inspiring and appropriate, whether flaunting in pride in far off seas, leading the death-dealing charge on the battle-field, enshrouding the cold form of the fallen soldier, or, as yesterday, dim with the tears of a nation. We have not undertaken to give elaborate descriptions of the streets and the people, only here and there we have noted a few stricking facts. The whole tone of the people was in keeping with the occasion; all business, save eating and traveling, wars suspended; the throngs that filled the streets were a quiet, serious, and bore themselves in a manner entirely consonant with the hour; the church attendance was good; there were no brawls, no fires, no accidents, no scenes to mar the solemnity of the sadly peaceful day.

abstract: We hope that hereafter the police will be a little cautious about clubbing people in the streets for improper, foolish, or wicked remarks. It has already turned out that not a few of the accusations made on Saturday last for indecent remarks about the assassination of the President, were false accusations, based in some cases on malice and in others on misapprehension. The police have very freely avenged the President's memory, when insulted; and the satisfaction with which their conduct was in the first instance received by the public has encouraged them to greater freedom in the use of their billies than is desirable. The grief for the death of Mr. LINCOLN is all but universal, as everybody knows and sees, and the pitiful handful of dissenters may very well be let alone. If they make unseemly demonstrations, let them be arrested, and legally punished; but let there be no passionate or unruly violence -- especially on the part of the police. We fear there have been cases in which the avenging of the deceased President has been a mere pretext -- the real impelling motive of assault being the safe gratification of private malice or vengeance. The incident of the assassination is too sad and solemn to be connected with such things.

abstract: House inked by citizens; Funeral Rites
snippet: House inked by citizens; Funeral Rites
lead_paragraph: The special religious observances at the capital, yesterday, were impressive, solemn and overpoweringly affecting to the dense mass of sorrow-stricken citizens that congregated to do the last sad offices of national affection. But grand in its solemni- ty as the immediate scene of the funeral obsequies must have been, it may be permitted us to doubt whether the great intensity of the public mourning could have been pictured in any formal assemblage however vast, as it was in every street and highway, in every alley and place of public resort, in every social gathering and communion of worshipers, in the parlors of the rich and by the hearthstones of the poor, all through the vast extent of this metropolis.

abstract: Securities in Europe
snippet: Securities in Europe
lead_paragraph: -- Twelve days ago the China brought us the report of American securities in London up to the 24th of March. In that report Five-Twenties were quoted at 53 1/4. To-day we have the Persia's report, by which it appears that, during the week closing the 8th inst., the same class of securities had been quoted as high as 60. This advance, within a period of two weeks, it should be noticed, took place at least five days before even the advance of Gen. GRANT to the Southside Railroad could have been reported in England. It is possible that a temporary decline may have followed the receipt of the news of LEE's desperate assault upon Fort Steadman, but this news would be so closely followed by the Australasian's, which carried out details of the victories around Petersburgh and the evacuation of Richmond, that we shall doubtless hear by the City of Washington, which is due here on Monday, of an advance of our securities even greater than that reported in the two weeks from March 24 to April 8. It is altogether probable that we shall find the Five-Twenties, by the next Liverpool Saturday Mail, quoted at a figure little, if anything, under 70.

abstract: System, Assassination, Barbarities,>amp;c.; Assassination and the Rebellion
snippet: System, Assassination, Barbarities,>amp;c.; Assassination and the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: There are but few persons, either in this country or elsewhere, who have paid any attention to the effects of the slave system on the character of those who grow up under it, or who are familiar with the history of the agitation carried on its defence both in Ameriittle surprise as it excites amongst us now, will, we are satisfied, a century hence, fill all students of our history with amazement. Nobody who, at that period, makes himself acquainted with the laws, and manners, and religious ideas of the Free States, as they were ten years ago, will fail to be puzzled, for instance, by the fact that on another portion of our soil, a few miles away, among a people differing from us in no respect except in the fact that they were slaveholders, and living under the same government, the punishment of burning alive should have been occasionally inflicted, down to the middle of the nineteenth century, by crowds of "citizens," too, and more than once under the superintendence of the sheriff. He will, probably, be still more puzzled by the fact that in that same community the right of private individuals to torture fellow creatures, if not to death, to death's door, was recognized and enforced by law; and that among ourselves there was a large body of the public always ready to defend the institution under which this atrocity was possible, and that among them there was in the year 1863 a Christian bishop.

abstract: Death; Punishment of rejoicers at; Speech to Illinois Deputation; President Johnson's Speech
snippet: Death; Punishment of rejoicers at; Speech to Illinois Deputation; President Johnson's Speech
lead_paragraph: The response of President JOHNSON to the address of the Illinois delegation is the first out-giving of the spirit which is to shape his administration of the government. It is very frank; and, we believe, it will prove very acceptable. Of course the President could not commit himself to any specific plans or measures. Called so suddenly as he was to his new position, that would have been precipitate and presumptuous. What was needed was a manifestation of the frame of mind that he would bring to the discharge of his mighty responsibilities. That we clearly have.

abstract: -- Coroner COLLIN viewed the body of HARRISON JAMES BEYEA, a youth of eight Summers, who died yesterday, having been run over by a Harlem Railroad train at the One Hundred and Twenty-ninth street crossing, near which the boy's parents reside. A jury exonerated the engineer and fireman, and added their opinion that the time has come when steam locomotives should be on longer tolerated within the city limits.

abstract: held an inquest on Tuesday upon the body of MAURICE BEAUSEEOIN, a wealthy stock-broker, who resided at No. 10 Waverley-place, and was found dead on the sidewalk in front of No. 686 Third-avenue, as reported in yesterday's TIMES. It was supposed that he had been foully murdered and robbed; but the Coroner's inquest has developed the fact that on Sunday evening BEAUSEEOIN leaped from a window of the house, wherein his friends had confined him, because, it is alleged, of intemperance. The money and watch, which were supposed to have been stolen, on account of their absence from his person at the time when his body was found, have been found in the hands of a Wall-street friend of the deceased.

abstract: Disloyal Clergyman of
snippet: Disloyal Clergyman of
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Cincinnati, dated the 15th says: "JUNIUS BRUTUS BOOTH is in deep grief over the tragedy which involves his brother WILKES as an assassin. His engagement would have closed to-night, but he dared not appear. He informs me that J. WILKES BOOTH was to have been married soon to a daughter of Senator HALE. Mr. BOOTH has gone to the country to-night, to keep quiet until the excitement has passed. He paces his room and pulls his hair like a man deranged. He also states that, if the reports are true against WILKES, EDWIN and himself will be compelled to leave the stage."

abstract: A Richmond correspondent of the London Times, under date of March 4, gives some curious speculations about the Union Generals who have been most prominent in the overthrow of the rebellion, and especially about Gen. SHERMAN, whom he regards as the ablest of them all. He foresees the overthrow of LEE's army and the capture of Richmond, and complains bitterly of the extent to which "politicians" in the Confederacy had succeeded in undermining their own government, and sapping Gen. LEE's strength in breasting the enemy. "SHERMAN," he says, "within a few weeks of this time, may be autocrat of this continent," and therefore he thinks it wise to study his character. He then proceeds:

abstract: The funeral of Mr. WATTS SHERMAN, late a member of the firm of DUNCAN, SHERMAN & Co., took place at Grace Church yesterday. Bishop POTTER and Rev. Dr. TAYLOR officiated. The remains were placed in an elegant coffin, on which was a silver place with the following inscription: "WATTS SHERMAN, died at Madeira, Feb. 20, 1865, aged 53 years." The body was buried at Greenwood. The funeral was attended by a large number of our prominent citizens.

abstract: Cantwell Lieut, Shot in Leg at Fort Richmond
snippet: Cantwell Lieut, Shot in Leg at Fort Richmond
lead_paragraph: rence took place on Tuesday afternoon, at Fort Richmond, Staten Island, resulting in the loss to the army of one of its most promising young officers. The circumstances were these: Lieut CANTWELL, of the Engineer Corps, a graduate of the class which left West Point last year, and be duty at the fortifications being erected at Fort Richmond, while calling on one of his brother officers, nothing a double-barreled fowling-piece standing in one of the apartments, took it up for the purpose of performing the "manual of the piece." After holding it for an instant, he passed it to the friend he was visiting, who took it by the stock, Lieut. CANTWELL still grasping it by the barrels. Scarcely had his friend seized it when there was a report, and Lieut. CANTWELL fell to the floor with the words. "I am shot." The officers in the room, one of whom was the Post Surgeon, not knowing that the piece was loaded, and supposing that a cap only had snapped, thought him to be jesting, but, he repeated. "Yes, I am shot," and then fell motionless. Still incredulous, his friends turned him over, and to their horror discovered a large wound in his left side, just above the groin, from which the blood was flowing in torrents. He did not speak again, and in a very few minutes he had breathed his last.

abstract: Emmerson, Trow's Foreman, Killed--Hatchway
snippet: Emmerson, Trow's Foreman, Killed--Hatchway
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon WILLIAM H. EMMERSON, assistant foreman in Mr. JOHN F. TROW's printing office, at No. 5[???] Greene street, while engaged in repairing a [???] the fourth story, slipped and [???] the ground floor, breaking through the board in the hatch, and landing [???] unconscious, and removed to the New-York Hospital, but died before reaching that institution; whereupon he was taken to the Eighth Precinct Station. He resided in Clinton-avenue, near Park-avenue, Brooklyn, where he leaves a wife and two children. He was a native of Connecticut, 36 years of age. Coroner WILDEY will hold an inquest at the Eighth Ward Station-house, at 7:30 o'clock this evening.

abstract: Idle apprehension about
snippet: Idle apprehension about
lead_paragraph: If the report of MOSBY's surrender should prove true, and we have little doubt it is, if not true, simply premature, it will furnish a fresh illustration of the folly into which many English observers have fallen, of expecting the war to be protracted by means of guerrillas, after the regular armies have ceased to exist. That it would be so protracted, and protracted indefinitely, no matter what fate might overtake LEE and JOHNSTON, has always been confidently predicted even by those of our critics abroad, who took the least favorable view of the prospects of the Confederacy, although there was really no better basis for the supposition than the vaporings of the Richmond newspapers.

abstract: The Death of
snippet: The Death of
lead_paragraph: The death of Mr. COBDEN, in spite of the great triumphs with which his life was crowded, and which will make his name and memory forever famous in English annals, and in spite, too, of the fact that he had reached the age when all men may fairly expect at any moment to rest from their labors, may still be called premature. For had he lived ten years longer, he would undoubtedly have witnessed the vindication here, and the success in England, of those great political principles, to the prosecution of which, ever since the overthrow of the protective policy in his own country, his life has been devoted.

abstract: Our own paper is still largely occupied with details of the late terrible event, and the mani- festation of the people thereupon. An attentive reading of a great number of newspapers coming from all sections of the loyal States, gives us but one view of the feeling of the people, and that is of intense horror and indignation. Here and
lead_paragraph: Our own paper is still largely occupied with details of the late terrible event, and the mani- festation of the people thereupon. An attentive reading of a great number of newspapers coming from all sections of the loyal States, gives us but one view of the feeling of the people, and that is of intense horror and indignation. Here and there we find an unwilling mourner, one whose mole-eyed prejudices cannot see above the indescency of rehearsing offensive partizan sentiments; but the great heart of the nation is roused to such reprobation of the spirit of treason, which prompted the murder, that the exceptions we have noted become utterly insignificant. To the disgrace of our nature we also find here and there actual rejoicings over the event; but the stern punishment in almost every instance visited upon the offenders in a healthy sign that all is well. The remains of our noble martyr will soon be on the way to his old home in Illinois, and the whole people will come forward as one man to bid a fearful farewell to all that remains of the great heart that loved them so well and served them so faithfully.

abstract: Acting Rear Admiral THATCHER, in a letter to the Navy Department, dated off Blakely River, Mobile Bay, April 9, communicates information of the fall of Forts Alexes and Spanish Fort, and says: "These very strong works were heavily bombarded last evening, from five until nine o'clock, by the army and navy. Our battery on shore, under command of Lieut. Col. GILLIS, late of the United States iron-clad Milwaukee, is highly spoken of by Gen. CANBY for its efficiency in the attack. The Stars and Stripes are now flying over these works, which are considered the key to Mobile. Our prisoners will amount to from 1,600 to 2,000 men, and we have also captured sixteen heavy guns. Eighteen large submerged torpedoes were taken up by our boats from Apalache or Blakely River last night, in the immediate vicinity of our gunboats. These are the only enemies that we regard.

abstract: PERSONATING A NEW-YORK DETECTIVE -- ARREST OF A SWINDLER AND SUPPOSED FORGER. -- A young man about 21 years of age, giving the name of J.K. ADAMS, and representing himself to be a New-York detective officer, was taken before Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, yesterday, on a charge of obtaining money under false pretences. The accused called at the residence of Mrs. M.J. KNAPP, No. 243 York-street, on Wednesday afternoon, where he represented that he was a detective officer, and had learned that a gang of burglars had concocted a plan for robbing her house that night. He then called for writing material, and penned the following:

abstract: A MONUMENT TO THE LATE PRESIDENT. -- The Treasurer of the Fifteenth Ward Recruiting Association, Col. C.W. DARLING, reports that the balance of the fund, as per statement audited and found correct by Messrs. G. TIMPSON and S. PHILBIN, is $1,505 62. This amount the Finance Committee have decided, if no objection is made by subscribers, to appropriate as the first donation toward a fund for the erection of a monument on Union-square to the memory of our late lamented President ABRAHAM LINCOLN.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Churches, Sermons, >amp;c
snippet: Churches, Sermons, >amp;c
lead_paragraph: The 20th of April was a dies non in the legal calendar, but in the record of this week of gloom and sadness it will ever occupy a prominent place. In addition to the terrible bereavement which oppresses all hearts, the long-continued cessation of business, the sombre appearance of the streets, and the season of fasting and humiliation recommended by the Governor, rendered it a day memorable for features disheartening and sorrowful. In the morning a chilly, keen, cutting wind blew sharply through the streets, filling the city with clouds of dust, and making a decided change from the Summer-like weather of Wednesday, when the heat was oppressive; in the afternoon and at night the heavens were opened, and from the leaden clouds came down copious showers of rain, drenching every flag, drooping every display of mourning, and causing the the streets to be deserted,

lead_paragraph: -- Christian's Mistake, by the author of "John Halifax, Gentleman," (12mo. New-York: HARPER & BROTHERS.) Miss MULOCK's last work is characterized by the usual qualities of her fictions. The story, however, has some points of originality, as it commences instead of ending with a marriage. The heroine is a charming creation, and her success in "living down" the obstacles and impediments that threaten is wreck the matrimonial happiness of her husband and herself, meets with the warm sympathies of the reader.

abstract: A Rebel Scheme for; Schemes for a Foreign War
snippet: A Rebel Scheme for; Schemes for a Foreign War
lead_paragraph: The condition of most of the military officers of the Confederacy will, after the conclusion of peace, be tolerably uncomfortable, owing, in the majority of cases, to the entire absence of any means of support. Those of them who owned plantations have either lost their negroes, or lost all the capital necessary to work them. Those who did not own plantations, either find the occupations in which they were engaged gone, or the friends on whom they were dependent utterly impoverished. Many of them, and these the ablest, held commissions in the United States Army, the restoration of which, as a matter of course, is hopeless.

abstract: Union, Transport; List of Officers
snippet: Union, Transport; List of Officers
lead_paragraph: It is rumored in naval circles that the successor of Capt. CASE, Executive Officer at the Navyyard, will be Capt. PENNECK, who will probably assume his position on May 1. Capt. PENNEOK formerly had charge of the naval station at Cairo. Capt. CASE will be the Fleet Captain, under Admiral GOLDSBOROUGH in the Mediterranean Squadron.... The Committee of Strikers sent to Washington from the Navy-yard last Friday, having seen the President and Secretary of the Navy, expected to have their business settled in a satisfactory manner; but the unexpected death of the President, on the same night, suspended all operations in the heads of departments, and to-day the "strike" is as effectively carried out at the yard as it was last week.

abstract: Toronto Globe on Rebel Carousal on President's Murder; Refugees Aided the President's Murder
snippet: Toronto Globe on Rebel Carousal on President's Murder; Refugees Aided the President's Murder
lead_paragraph: Those who hold the leaders and agents of the rebellion entirely guiltless of complicity with the Washington assassins, may read with profit an article from the Toronto Globe, which we publish in another column. The editor of that journal not only repeats his assertion, that the leading rebels of Toronto -- with a "Southern clergymen" at their head -- held a carousal in honor of the assassination, but he adds that those of the rebels that did not participate in the debauch, were unable to conceal their satisfaction at hearing that President LINCOLN had been murdered. The public opinion of the resident population compelled a change in their tone. But the first impulse of the ruffians was one of entire concurrence in the justice and righteousness of the murderer's act. Everything, indeed, goes to prove that the soi-disant peace agents were so far privy to the conspiracy against the President's life, that they have all along freely predicted his murder. It is important that these facts should be borne in mind in settling the limits of any future amnesty. The rebel cut-throats, who have been employed to hatch schemes of robbery and murder against us on foreign soil -- the Thompsons, the Slidells, the Sanderses, the Masons, the Burleys and the Youngs -- clearly rank with the class of outlaws whose crimes can neither be condoned nor forgotten.

abstract: The Vindication of
snippet: The Vindication of
lead_paragraph: Is justice revenge? Is the punishment of crime essential, or obligatory? Has law any attribute of permanence, of sanctity, of supremacy over generations and rulers? Or is it but the sliding-scale of the impulse of the hour? Is impartial equity the essential element of preventive as well as retributive justice? or is that majesty which men tremble at as a vicegerent of Deity in the soul, to wilt, like the effrontery of a bully, before gigantic crime? In short, is the law of crime ours, or God's? By what authority dare we take, by what authority dare we forbear to take, life for life?
headline: {'main': 'The Vindication of Justice.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Vindication of Justice.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Minister; Sir F Bruce; Reception of
snippet: Minister; Sir F Bruce; Reception of
lead_paragraph: -- There was not much for Sir FREDER ICK BRUCE to say in presenting his credentials, but what was proper to be said the new Minister put in words admirably chosen, alike as to the feeling, the delicacy and the taste which the occasion suggested. The expressions of condolence were neither overwrought nor needlessly iterated. And we can well believe that it was with no feigned emotion of Borrow and regret that Sir. FREDERICK BRUCE called President JOHNSON's notice to that inexpressibly painful episode in the opening of his mission -- that the day of President LINCOLN's death was the day named for his formal presentation as the accredited representative of his sovereign. The message from Her Britannic Majesty which the new Minister was charged to deliver in the Queen's name, would have been specially grateful to Mr. LINCOLN -- not less from the friendly response it was designed to give to his forbearing and forgiving policy, than from the confidence which the late President had cherished that the Queen's assurances of "regard and good will" were unaffectedly sincere, and that, in good faith, "Her Majesty has nothing more at heart than to cultivate relations of amity and good understanding between the two kindred nations of the United States and Great Britain." Addressing this message to Mr. JOHNSON, Sir FREDERICK BRUCE expresses the hope that his attempts to give effect to the Queen's intentions may meet with the President's approval.

abstract: Charities and Correction, Organization of Board
snippet: Charities and Correction, Organization of Board
lead_paragraph: -We print of another page an abstract of the annual report of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction for this city. Although many of the facts have appeared from time to time in our columns, the reader will be interested in the recap[???]ulation of their labors. Having the care of all the penal and charitable institutions, under public patronage they are charged with a vast responsibility not only in a pecuniary, but in a moral sense. And it is conceded on all hands that they have been good and faithful servants, prompt and economical in duty, and winning universal commendation for the manner in which they have guarded and dispensed the privileges and duties of their office. Yesterday the reorganization of the board took place. Mr. ISAAC BELL was chosen President, and Mr. JAMES BOWEN Secretary, the other members being JAMES B. NICHOLSON and OWEN W. BRENNAN. Collector DRAPER, so long the respected and efficient head of the commission, sent a note regretting that public business prevented his attendance, and expressing his warm sympathy with the board and the unfortunates in their care. The retiring members have deserved well of the people, and will be gratefully remembered.

abstract: Government gold-bearing bonds were not freely offered, and were very firm and buoyant in price yesterday, though no heavy transactions were reported. The next steamers from Europe are expected to bring highly encouraging news from Frankfort and London, relative to United States Five Twenties in those markers, as the earliest response to the authentic intelligence from this side of the fall of Richmond and Petersburgh, and the desperate flight and vigorous pursuit of Lee.
lead_paragraph: Government gold-bearing bonds were not freely offered, and were very firm and buoyant in price yesterday, though no heavy transactions were reported. The next steamers from Europe are expected to bring highly encouraging news from Frankfort and London, relative to United States Five Twenties in those markers, as the earliest response to the authentic intelligence from this side of the fall of Richmond and Petersburgh, and the desperate flight and vigorous pursuit of Lee. A week later, we shall have advices of the effect, which must be eminently favorable to the national credit and funded stocks abroad, of the report of LEE's surrender, and the practical close of the war. The principal holders of government bonds here are not eager to sell any considerable lots at prevailing rates, in anticipation of the expected news from Europe.

abstract: Toronto Globe on rebels in Canada; Toronto Globe on Rebels in Canada
snippet: Toronto Globe on rebels in Canada; Toronto Globe on Rebels in Canada
lead_paragraph: Mr. W.B. FLEMING, B.A., of Oakville, writes to a cotemporaty expressing his astonishment at a statement in the Globe of Monday, relative to the demonstration of approval with which the news of Mr. LINCOLN's assassination was received by certain Southernrefugees in Toronto. We beg to repeat the statement to which Mr. FLEMING refers, and to assure him that it is literally true: "It caused a thrill of horror in this city when it was made known that Southern refugees assembled in our chief hotel, as soon as the deed was known early on Saturday morning and entered upon a noisy debauch in honor of the event, and that a clergyman among them said publicly at the breakfast table at the same hotel that Lincoln had only gone to k -- l a little before his time." These facts are well known in Toronto, and nobody here thinks of disputing them. Even the Southern organ has been careful not to deny them. Mr. FLEMING, however, having "read without knowledge," rushes to the defence. He says that, even if the statement "about the debauch were true of some thoughtless young man over his cups. it is an outrage to hold the whole body of Southern refugees, or, indeed, any part of the thoughtful and sober, responsible for such sentiments." The statement is true of several men, "thoughtless" they certainly were, or they would have known enough to conceal "such sentiments." We hold nobody responsible for the exultation over President LINCOLN's assassination but those who were guilty of that outrage. We are willing even to say that some refugees would not have committed such an offence against decency as to give public expression to feelings so atrocious. But the reflection immediately follows that "sober and thoughtful" men are not so numerous among the Southern refugees in Toronto as they ought to be. Ordinarily we look for such qualities in clergymen, but a man has been found among; the refugees to degrade a sacred calling, by using language so blasphemous and atrocious that all good men must shudder to hear it.

abstract: Pride; The Prostration of; Humiliation to Conciliate Southern Pride
snippet: Pride; The Prostration of; Humiliation to Conciliate Southern Pride
lead_paragraph: It sounds strange to find men who professloyalty to the government and own obedience to the laws, protesting loudly, at this late hour, that nothing shall be done, in compelling the submission of the rebels, to wound the pride of the South. The doctrine, it is true, had an authoritative enunciation, and was offi cially practiced when JAMES BUCHANAN held parley with the prime conspirators, and refused to hurt the sectional feeling of the rebel leaders by assigning to their first overt acts either the character or the penalty of treason. But we had supposed that four years of carnage -- the bloody, heritage bequeathed by that wretched official to his country -- had brought home to us all a sufficient experience of this business of sparing sectional pride, and nourishing open and defiant treason. It might be thought, at least, that the culminating crime of the conspiracy to ruin the republic would bring with it the lesson, that when Southern pride shall have been fully propitiated, the national authority will be prostrated, and the individual members of the national government will be offered up as a sacrifice to the tender sensibilities of a chivalry whose communion is held to be essential to the common weal.
headline: {'main': 'National Humiliation-Wounding Southern Pride.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'National Humiliation-Wounding Southern Pride.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Five sacrilegious wretches were apprehended yesterday for despolling our dwellidns and shops of the drapery with which we shrouded the town on receiving tidings of the late President's death. Four of these persons who were taken into custody by Policeman FLEMING, of the Fourth Ward, rendered their names as CORNELIUS VAN ROUK, JOHN SMITH, HENRY SNYDER and FREDERICK VAN ROUK, and under these names they were committed by Justice HOGAN, to await trial for tearing emblems of mourning from the front of No. 103 Chatham-street....Policeman DICKSON, of the Thirteenth Precinct, arrested JACOB EVELY for stealing crape and gingham from dwellings in Grand-street, and on searching the prisoner's abode a large basket wan found, nearly filed with scraps of mourning goods, which he had stolen from door-knobs and elsewhere. Justice SHANDLEY committed the prisoner to the Penitentiary for three months.....Special Officer FIELD, of the Fifth Want, arrested PHILIP SNEDIKER, of No. 19 Desbrosses-street, for stealing $120 from MATTHEW THOMPSON, of No. 15 Morris-street, plumber. The complainant and prisoner, who are mutual friends, drank to excess on Thursday last, and SNEDIKER, according to his version, took THOMPSON's money for safe keeping; but, as the money which he took was from a roll of bills representing $450. Justice HOGAN regarded his statement as highly improbable and committed him for examination.

abstract: Quincyl; Democratic Mayor and Aldermen elected; Jackson, Andrew, Jr., Adopted Son of President Andrew, Accidentally Shot
snippet: Quincyl; Democratic Mayor and Aldermen elected; Jackson, Andrew, Jr., Adopted Son of President Andrew, Accidentally Shot
lead_paragraph: ANDREW JACKSON, Jr., adopted son of the late President JACKSON, accidentally shot himself while hunting near the Hermitage, Tennessee, on Monday week, and died on the Sunday following of lockjaw. He was a son of Mrs. JACKSON's brother, SAMUEL DONELSON, and a cousin of A.J. DONELSON. He took his adopted parent's name, and inherited, at his death, the Hermitage, and a large cotton plantation in Mississippi, both of which, however, passed out of his hands, He was fifty-six years of age, and leaves a wife. daughter and two sons. The sons cast their [???] with the rebels, both entering the army. SAMUEL, the younger, was an officer in the rebel service, and was killed beyond Chattanooga. The eldest brother, ANDREW JLCKSON, is a Brigadier-General in the rebel army. He terminated his military career in the surrender of Fort Morgan, in Mobile harbor, to the United States forces, at which time he was taken prisoner, and is now in [???]ands.

abstract: The military authorities in Canada and the other British North American Provinces, were prompt to show the usual token of sorrow for the death by assassination of President LINCOLN. The Lieutenant-General commanding ordered that all flags in British North America should be hoisted half mast high, until the funeral of the President had taken place. Gen. NAPIER telegraphed from this city to that effect to all the stations in his district where the military authorities have flag-staffs.

abstract: State delegations are still calling upon the President, making speeches and getting replies. The delegation from Indians, headed by Gov.
