abstract: Courtesy toward America; Spectator on America
snippet: Courtesy toward America; Spectator on America
lead_paragraph: It is eminently instructive just now to regard the tone of the English press, especially the weekly, on American affairs. The recent debate in Parliament on the Canadian defences arose from one of those mysterious panics to which the English people are subject in regard to foreign nations. The idea of a war with America arose solely from the leaders of the Times, or from the guilty consciences of the members. Not a threatening word had been breathed by our government; our press had been mainly absorbed in our own affairs; there was no immediate question to discuss between the two governments; yet the mere prospect of our success seemed at once to carry with it the thought of war with England.

abstract: Addresses of
snippet: Addresses of
lead_paragraph: -- Nothing could be more appropriate and becoming, in tone and sentiment, than the addresses which Mr. JOHNSON has been called on to make since the duties of the Presidency devolved upon him. They are weighty in manner and in matter. They indicate unmistakably that solemn sense of responsibility which is the best guarantee for the faithful discharge of his high trust. His reserve in speaking of specific acts of administration is especially considerate and wise. In declaring that he shall act upon each question as it may arise, and as may at the time seem best, he lays down the golden rule of all wise statesmanship and gives strong assurance that the government will be administered with strict regard to the practical necessities and emergencies of the hour.

abstract: -We are surprised to see a number of our cotemporaries quoting a blunder originating with the Journal of Commerce, as to the death of President TAYLOR, which is given as on the 9th of July, 1849, only four months after his inauguration, in place of the 9th of July, 1850, sixteen months after he was sworn into office. The mistake is the more singular because of the comparatively recent political (and somewhat exciting) events to which it refers.

lead_paragraph: There has been an effort put forth to call out the generosity of the American people toward Gen. LEE, in distinction from JEFF. DAVIS and other civilians who were leaders of the rebellion. A well-known politician, at a recent public meeting in this city, ventured to say, that "if Gen. LEE should come to New-York, he would be proud to have him as his guest." Such sentiments have probably somewhat evaporated since the last dying act of the rebellion.

abstract: Government Detective THOMAS G. GIRVAN recently learned that an organized gang of counterfeiters were operating in this city and vicinity, and, through the arrest of one JOHN A. COUTER for passing counterfeit money, he learned that in NELSON STEWART's house, on Staten Island, he might find a large quantity of bogus bills, plates, &c. He accordingly made affidavit at the Jefferson Market Police Court, and Justice DODGE issued a warrant to Sergt. WILSON for the arrest of STEWART. The arrest having been made, Detective GIRVAN searched STEWART's house, and found therein counterfeit fives on the Washington County Bank of Rhode Island, fives on the Union Bank of Boston, fives on the Highland Bank of Hudson City, N.J., and four plates for the printing of fractional currency. It is alleged that STEWART is an old counterfeiter, and has many confederates in this city.

abstract: The Stage and Pres. Assassination; New Plot in Canada; G N, injured innocent--His Letter
snippet: The Stage and Pres. Assassination; New Plot in Canada; G N, injured innocent--His Letter
lead_paragraph: GEORGE N. SANDERS, that injured innocent, is terribly afflicted at the intimation that he or his gang of refugee Confederates could have had anything to do with the conspiracy for assassinating the President. He speaks of himself as an "innocent person," -- as simply a "political opponent," -- and thinks it very hard that he should be charged with "crime." GEORGE'S sensitivenoss on this point is of recent growth. In his palmy days he look great delight in passing himself off as a "Red Republican." He was a special admirer of ROBESPIERRE, MARAT, and that brood of bloodthirsty "politicians," and was fond of expressing his sentiments in favor of cutting off the head of everybody who stood in the way of European regeneration. If he has been any less ferocious in his support of the rebellion, he has not advertised the world of the fact. Canada, since he has been there as a rebel refugee, has been a nest for hatching all sorts of bloody raids upon peaceful citizens, which have found in him a ready advocate and defender.

abstract: Earl Russell; Earl Russell on; on Neutrality, Reciprocity Treaty, >amp;c.
snippet: Earl Russell; Earl Russell on; on Neutrality, Reciprocity Treaty, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Earl RUSSELL, in his recent speech to the House of Lords on the rescinding of the Reciprocity Treaty, entered upon a defence of the conduct of England, against several of our charges against her. The first one to which he referred was the complaint which has been urged, that she hastened to grant to the rebels belligerent rights, as soon as she heard of the breaking out of the rebellion. We have complained that this act of hers was an unfriendly one, was done with undue haste, and indicated a disposition incompatible with the relations which had existed between England and this country.

abstract: Pressure on of addresses; Reply to Vermont Delegation
snippet: Pressure on of addresses; Reply to Vermont Delegation
lead_paragraph: It is beyond question altogether proper, that the new President should be assured of the sympathy and support of the people in different sections of the country. His position is one which calls for encouragement, and peradventure, for indulgence, from loyal men of all parties. And, probably, there is no better way of conveying Mr. JOHNSON an expression of public sentiment than by means of addresses from representative bodies, formally delivered. The question, however, may well be put, whether the range of representation in this case may not be inordinately extended. There must, we take it, be some limit set to the claims of the different varieties of organizations assuming a representative character, to participate in the formal presentation of these addresses. Good taste would surely dictate that there be no needless multiplying of formal resolutions, either hortatory or sympathetic. There is not a State in the Union but may be fitly and fully represented on such an occasion as the accession of a new Executive by half a dozen delegates. That number, carefully selected, would have done ample justice, at least, to the common sentiments of this community, and would have sufficiently embraced the great financial, commercial, political and religious interests of the State. What is true of New-York, in this regard, we take it is true of Illinois, Pennsylvania, and every other State, great and small.

abstract: It is now very close upon a century since the first RICHARD TATTERSALL, known to sporting chronicles, came up out of Lancashire, bringing with him a good reputation for knowledge in horse-flesh, and established the well-known auction mart and subscription room at Hyde-park corner. At that time the subsequently well-known and central establishment had nothing between it and the river, except green fields, and the future possessor of Highflyer got his ninety-nine years lease on easy terms. Gradually, however, Western London begin to grow up around him, until at last the unpretending establishment, in which probably more money changed hands than on any bourse in Europe, became almost smothered by the palatial edifices by which it was surrounded. "Tattersall's," however, bravely worked out its lease through four generations of representatives, and being at last obliged to move, has settled down on a most eligible freehold, not more than half a mile distant from its original location. As it was a hundred years ago, a RICHARD TATTERSALL is now at the head of the firm, and yesterday evening he and his partner EDMUND, threw open their new premises for the inspection of their friends and subscribers.

abstract: On the day preceding the assassina  tion, an affidavit was sworn to before Chief Justice RICHARDS, of Toronto, which disclosed the fact of a vessel having been fitted out at Collingwood, on the Georgian Bay, for piratical purposes. The nominal owner of the intended pirate was the notorious ruffian McDONALD, the confidante of BEALL and KEN  NEDY, and the special agent of SANDERS, THOMPSON and other outlaws. The expedition...
lead_paragraph: -- On the day preceding the assassina tion, an affidavit was sworn to before Chief Justice RICHARDS, of Toronto, which disclosed the fact of a vessel having been fitted out at Collingwood, on the Georgian Bay, for piratical purposes. The nominal owner of the intended pirate was the notorious ruffian McDONALD, the confidante of BEALL and KEN NEDY, and the special agent of SANDERS, THOMPSON and other outlaws. The expedition seems to have been ready for work when the local authorities interfered, and prevented its departure from Canadian waters. But we do not learn that either the principals or the agents in this enterprise have been put under arrest, or that there is any announcement of Lord MONCK's intention to put the recently enacted Alien Law of the Province into effect. By that law the Governor-General of the Provinces has the amplest power conferred upon him in regard to the expulsion of the whole of these criminals from British territory. Surely this is a case where Executive interference may fairly be invoked by the friends of order and peace.

abstract: To do things on an immense scale is a matter of course in the great West. Speaking of the lumber business on the Upper Mississippi, a Minnesota paper records the movement of a vast amount of logs, just after the ice gave way. It says: "The spectacle now presented is grand. It is estimated that there are from fifteen to seventy million feet of lumber, piled in every imaginable way, in some places towering up twenty or thirty feet, and reaching to the bottom of the river."

abstract: The rumors about Gen. SHERMAN's taking the responsibility of arranging peace terms with JOHNSTON, have taken positive shape, and are published by official sanction in another column. Last night a Cabinet meeting was held, and President JOHNSON was sustained by every member present, and by Lieut.-Gen. GRANT also, in his prompt repudiation of the whole proceeding. Orders were sent to Gen. SHERMAN to recommence hostilities forthwith, and Gen. GRANT left immediately by a special steamer to take supervision in person. It looks very much as it this negotiation was a blind to cover the escape of JEFF. DAVIS and a few of his officials, with the millions of gold they have stolen from the Richmond banks. The official dispatches of Mr. STANTON possess peculiar interest, in embracing the direction sent by Mr. LINCOLN himself to Gen. GRANT. when LEE was trying to talk about peace instead of submission.

abstract: Wooster-street--$16,000
snippet: Wooster-street--$16,000
lead_paragraph: At about 1 o'clock yesterday morning a fire of accidental origin occurred in a row of wooden buildings at Nos. 75, 77, 79, and 81 Wooster-st., and the upper parts of the buildings were consumed. Mr. T. ZACHARIAS, cabinet maker, who occupies the upper stories, estimates his loss at $15 000; he is insured for $4 6[???]0 in the People's office. No, 75, which was occupied by Mr. A. GEIGER, was damaged about $100, and is insured for $650 in the People's office M. JOHN MOORE, dealer in fancy goods, at No. 77, has lost $200, and is insured, as is also Mrs. MARY PARMLEE, who keeps a cigar store at No. 79, and lost about $50. Mr. L. BRISSON, lo[???], at No. 81, lost $50, and is not insured. The buildings were owned by Mr. PETER LORILLARD.

abstract: STREET ROBBERY AND BRUTALITY. -- Early yesterday morning, MICHAEL COTTER, of No. 156 Waverley-place, was followed from the "Smithsonian," in Greene-street, by JOHN H. EDDINGTON, CHARLES H. DANIELS and CHARLES S. COWING, and at the intervention of Greene and H[???] streets they robbed nim of a gold watch and $150 but as they were making their escape COTTER laid hands on the fellow that had the watch, and thereupon the confederates returned to aid their companion. They knocked COTTER to the pavement, and kicked and beat [???], and stole a diamond pin from his bosom. They were subsequently apprehended by policeman RILEY, of the Eighth Ward, and committed, without bail, by Justice DODGE.

abstract: Judge EDMONDS addressed an audience, last evening, at Hope Chapel upon the topics of the hour. He passed a glowing eulogy upon ABRAHAM LINCOLN, whose administration he briefly reviews; and in stating his own convictions of duty he held it to be obligatory upon us while chastening the leaders of the rebellion, to deal with their dupes, and particularly with the loyal men of the South, with Christian charity and love. The exercises of the evening closed with the singing, by the audience, of "God Bless our Native Land."

abstract: Funeral Obsequies in New-York
snippet: Funeral Obsequies in New-York
lead_paragraph: The city will pay its last formal tribute of respect to the remains of the late President to-day and to-morrow. Apart from the duty imposed by the sad occasion of the lying of the body in state, the citizens, we may say of all classes, have felt, as it were, a common impulse to prolong the period of civic mourning. During the whole of the period thus far intervening since the President's death, there has been a relaxation from what we are accustomed to regard as the regular routine of business, such as, we venture to say, has not been witnessed within the lifetime of the living generation. Men the least accustomed to give way to excitement or impulse, have found themselves unfitted for secular thought and occupation to a degree altogether new to their experience. But it would be impossible to name a single class among the honest members of the community, on which the blow struck at the head of the nation has not fallen with the directness of a personal affliction.

abstract: Personal Safety of the President; Declining precaution for his safety
snippet: Personal Safety of the President; Declining precaution for his safety
lead_paragraph: We see it stated from Washington that President JOHNSON, being unwilling to evince any distrust of the people, declines all precautions for his personal safety. We hope this is not true. We hope President JOHNSON has too much sense to suppose that his reputation for personal courage is of more importance to the country than the preservation of his life; and we are quite sure he is not likely to mistake conspirators and murderers for the people. The people, themselves, at all events, do not require any such indication of his confidence in them as involves the constant exposure of his life to the dagger or the bullet of a gang of assassins.

abstract: The rumors which have been circulating for some days about negotiations between SHERMAN and JOHNSTON have at length taken definite s[???]. A courier from Gen. SHERMAN arrived at Washington last Friday, with the intelligence th[???] that General had assumed the responsibility of arranging terms of peace with Gen. JOHNSTON, and had agreed upon a temporary suspension of hostilities. At a Cabinet meeting hall Friday night, the action of Gen. SHERMAN was disapproved by the President, by the Secretary of War, by Gen. GRANT, and by every member of the Cabinet, and he was ordered to resume hostilities immediately. Lieut.-Gen. GRANT left immediately, by a special steamer, to take supervision in person. A dispatch from Fortress Monroe announces his arrival at that place on Saturday. It is to be apprehended that these operations have given JEFF. DAVIS time to make [???] his escape, with the plunder of the Richmond banks.

GRANT left immediately, by a special steamer, to take supervision in person. A dispatch from Fortress Monroe announces his arrival at that place on Saturday. It is to be apprehended that these operations have given JEFF. DAVIS time to make [???] his escape, with the plunder of the Richmond banks.

abstract: The Toronto Globe of Friday publishes the affidavit of a citizen, sworn to before Chief-Justice RICHARDS, which details a plot, all but ready for execution, for the, sailing of an armed rebel streamer from one of the Canadian ports, for the purpose of preying upon our commerce upon the Lakes. The principal in this enterprise was the [???]ous MCDONALD, the confederate of KENNEDY and BEALL. The affidavit says: "That I am aware that the said W.L. MCDONALD, at his house on the corner of Agnes and Terauly streets, in the said City of Toronto, was manufacturing hand-grenades, Greek fire, shells and other implements of war, and had a considerable quantity concealed about the premises. I gave notice to the United States Consul in Toronto of the fact, but before the police authorities went to the premises, the said munitions and implements had been removed. Some of them have, in fact, been sent Collingwood, as I am informed and believe, for the said steamer Georgian. I am informed and believe that, in consequence of disclosures made to the said United States Consul here, and the discoveries of the police authorities, the Hon. ROBERT SPENCE did, on Friday last, the 7th day of April inst., proceed to Collingwood to inspect said vessel, and found on board thereof the said W.L. MCDONALD and various other parties, and thereupon seized the said vessel, as being about to pass the frontier of this province to some place in the said United States, (with which Power Her Majesty the Queen is at peace,) he considering that there was probable cause for believing that said vessel was about to be used for the purpose of a raid or expedition into the United States, contrary to the act of last session of Parliament entitled, 'An Act for the prevention and repression of outrages in violation of the peace of this province, and for other purposes.'"

abstract: The arrangements for the reception of the body in the City Hall are completed. The canopy under which the body is to be placed, extending from the door of the Governor's Room, is richly ornamented. In front and near the top is placed a bust of the late President, and on each side a funeral urn. The sides of the canopy will be covered with black cloth, and the bier with black velvet. A chandelier is placed on each side of the canopy, so that the light will fall upon the coffin.

abstract: While Gen. EWELL was at the Provost-Marshal's office, in this city, he conversed with several official and private individuals. He took this occasion utterly to deny the alegation that he had ordered the burning of Richmond, or that the fire which occurred upon his evacuation of the city was caused either by his order or that of any Confederate authority. He said that the fire was the work of the Richmond mob.

abstract: Beecher's, H W, Sermon at Plymouth Church
snippet: Beecher's, H W, Sermon at Plymouth Church
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning last, Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER and party returned from their incompleted Southern trip, and met with his parish that evening at prayers. In consequence of the announcement in Saturday's TIMES that Mr. BEECHER would deliver an address on Sabbath morning, appropriate to the season of National bereavement, a vast multitude gathered about the doors at Plymouth Church, thronging Orange and Cranberry streets so that passing was impossible. The church doors open at 10 o'clock usually, but at that time the efficient clerk of the society, Mr. WELD, and his many assistants had more work on their hands than they could easily attend to; the people would go in, and although strenuous efforts were made to keep up a reasonable hour the pews for their owners, the crowd had their own way and filled the church to overflowing. Thousands were turned away, and hundreds hung about the outer door in the vain hope of learning. The church was very by heat and effectively draped in black and white, and upon the Pastor's desk was placed a basset of beautiful flowers. At half-past ten Mr. BEECHER went to his platform the whole of which was occupied by men and women, while small boys fringed the front.
headline: {'main': 'THE NATIONAL BEREAVEMENT.; Touching Tribute from Rev. Henry Ward Beecher to the Martyred President.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE NATIONAL BEREAVEMENT.; Touching Tribute from Rev. Henry Ward Beecher to the Martyred President.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Extraordinary Negociation for Peace; On Military Peace Negotiations
snippet: Extraordinary Negociation for Peace; On Military Peace Negotiations
lead_paragraph: The loyal public will read with profound surprise the terms which Gen. SHERMAN tendered to the rebel government, as represented by its only uncaptured commander, Gen. JOHNSTON, as the basis of peace. In reading the provisions of this remarkable compact -- which was signed on the 18th of April, four days after the assassination of President LINCOLN -- one is at a loss to know which side agreed to surrender. JOHNSTON certainly could have intended nothing of the kind. He evidently believed himself to be negotiating with an equal -- dictating terms, rather than receiving them -- and laying the basis of a new government based on a theory of State rights as absolute and complete as CALHOUN ever dreamed of.
headline: {'main': "Gen. Sherman's Extraordinary Negotiation for Peace.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Gen. Sherman's Extraordinary Negotiation for Peace.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The funeral of Col. MATHEW MURPHEY, of the Sixty-ninth Regiment New-York State National Guards, took place from the City Hall, at 2 o'clock P.M., yesterday -- the Sixty-ninth and Seventy-ninth Regiments acting as escort. Among the poll-bearers were Col. O'Mahony, Col. Reid, Col. Murphy, Dr. Regan, Capt. McGuire, Capt. Goodwin, J. B. Kirker, Brig.-Gen. Dodge, Col. Lynch, Col. De Lacy, Col. Downing, Capt. Doran, Capt. Haggert, P. O'Rourke. The line of march was up Broadway to Eighth-street, and thence to the Tenth-street ferry and Cavalry Cemetery, where the body was interred. The diseased died of wounds received at the battle of Hatcher's Run, on the 6th of February last. He was in the 26th year of his age.

abstract: Cook, Geo W, Chief Engineer Camden and Amboy Railroad
snippet: Cook, Geo W, Chief Engineer Camden and Amboy Railroad
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. WM. COOK, Chief Engineer of the Camden and Amboy Railroad, and a leading man in the State of New Jersey, died at his residence in Hoboken on Friday night last, from typhoid fever, in the sixty-fourth year of his age. Gen. COOK was a native of New-Jersey, and a graduate of the United States Military Academy at West Point. Upon graduating he entered the Engineer Corps of the army, and served for some years being employed principally on government explorations and surveys. In 1830 he left the army to accept the position of Civil Engineer of the Camden and Amboy Railroad Company, in which position he remained until the day of his death. The funeral takes place from his late residence. No. 26 Hudson-street, this (Monday) afternoon at 1 o'clock.

abstract: The remains of President LINCOLN arrived at Jersey City shortly after 10 o'clock yesterday meeting, where they were received by Secretary of State DEPEW, Mayor GUNTHER and the Common Council of New-York, and placed on board [???] ferry boat Jersey City, which conveyed them [???] of Desbrosses-street; thence they [???] [???] by the Seventh Regiment to the City Hall. About 1:30 P.M. the public were admitted to view the body, which was placed beneath a canopy extending from the door of the Governor's room to the top of the stairway. In the Governor's room were assembled Gens. Dix, Hunter, Van Vliet, Peck, Burnside, McCullum and Townsend, and Admirals Paulding, Breese and Davis, with many other distinguished naval and military officers. Immense crowds assembled in the Park and adjoining streets at an early hour in the morning, and many waited patiently until midnight to obtain an opportunity of viewing the remains, the throng increasing rather than diminishing, until an early hour in the morning. The business houses in the lower part of the city were generally closed. The body will remain on view until noon to-day. The procession will move from the Hall at 1 o'clock precisely. The demonstration in Union-square has been postponed from 10 A.M. to 5 o'clock in the afternoon.

abstract: -If all the conditions of a solemn and sober observance of the ceremonial observances of yesterday were not fulfilled, there was at least an overwhelming demonstration of popular interest throughout the entire day and night. The outpouring of the masses was altogether indescribable. The suspension, or we may better say, the neglect of business, was all but universal. The early part of the day witnessed an eager, impatient, but perfectly orderly body of people crowding on the line of the procession and around the City Hall, and if the ingenuity of those who had charge of the arrangements could have devised some method of gratifying the desire of even a tithe o	f the spectators to see the body of the dead President, there would have been a uniformity of quiet demeanor which was wanting after nightfall. We perhaps do well to look rather at the impossibility of maintaining entire propriety of demeanor for fifteen or more consecutive hours, than to animadvert on what in less perplexing and aggravating circumstances might have invited comment. There is no doubt that the first impulse that drew together so vast a multitude of citizens was one of loyal sympathy and of unfeigned respect to the memory of Mr. LINCOLN. And to this we must look in estimating how far the observances thus far have met the end in view, when the city was invited to join formally in the funeral obsequies.

abstract: The last inaugural of President LINCOLN made a strong impression in England. The British Standard speaks of it as "the most remarkable thing of the sort ever pronounced by any President of the United States from the first day until now. Its Alpha and its Omega is Almighty God, the God of justice and the Father of mercies, who is working out the purposes of his love. It is invested with a dignity and pathos, which lift it high above everything of the kind, whether in the Old World or the New. The whole thing puts us in mind of the best men of the English Commonwealth; there is, in fact, much of the old prophet about it."

abstract: New-York Funeral Ceremonies
snippet: New-York Funeral Ceremonies
lead_paragraph: At an early hour yesterday morning, the people began to gather in and about the Park. By 8 o'clock several thousands had assembled, and seemed determined to stand their ground at any inconvenience, so that an early view might be had of the remains. The City Hall was barred and locked; around the front, and guarding every side, stood lines of uniformed police, keeping perfect order, and strictly enforcing the rule that no one should enter. Invitations extended by the courtesy of Alderman J.D. OTTIWELL secured the admission of the press to the rotunda, and subsequently to the Governor's Room, where, in spite of the singular opposition of a man named LEWIS CARPENTER, a mechanic, who seemed to be temporarily in charge, they remained during the exhibition. The sound of hammers mingled with the voice of authority, while the decorations were being completed and arrangements made by the committee. Gen. HALL, with his aids and assistants, were in one room, receiving messages and sending dispatches; Alderman OTTIWELL, and the other members of the committee, were in another room, winding up the ends of their programme for the day; the builder and decorator of the velvet-carpeted resting-room of the Martyr-President were smoothing out wrinkles, adjusting folds and driving the last tack; Col. HAMILTON, of Gen. SANDFORD's staff, and Maj. RATHBUN, of the army, were making arrangements for the accommodation of the many military gentlemen expected; Gen. BURNSIDE, with several elegant ladies, waited for the arrival of the body with floral testimonials of regard; the half-dozen members of the press, after arguing with one door keeper, parleying with another, escaping the machinations of CARPENTER, who followed them like a second old man of the mountain, noted the appearance of the hall and the Governor's Room, and viewed from the balcony the sight of all others, the great massing of the people. All around the pillars in the rotunda and in front of the hall wound graceful folds of cloth and crape, black as night; about the walls hung great masses of sombre bunting; CARPENTER's "Study of Lincoln" rested quietly with sad expression opposite the entrance to the Governor's Room, and the exponents of our city's pomp and power -- her colors -- draped the walls on either side. The hours wore on and the multitude deepened; far up Chatham-street waited thousands of men, women and children, whose impatience burst forth in occasional and periodical pushings, which only the sharp rap of the policemen's clubs could quiet; Printing-house-square was full, the Park was held by very many who hugged close to the line of the police, contenting themselves with the sight of the City Hall and the sound of the tolling bells; boys and men mounted the trees, and WASHINGTON's monstrosity in the park, dark sashed, was the involuntary support of half a score of adventurous youths who neither feared the police nor regarded the Father of his Country.

abstract: The occupation of Macon by Gen. WILSON took place on or before the 20th instant. Among the notable men captured were HOWELL COBB and Gen. GUSTAVUS W. SMITH. These men at once claimed the benefit of the armistice, made by Gen. SHERMAN with JOE JOHNSTON, and Gen. SHERMAN answered Gen. WILSON's inquiry for instructions thus: "To draw out of Macon, and hold his command for further orders, unless he has reason to believe the rebels are changing the status to our prejudice."

abstract: We feel bound to say that the arrangements, yesterday, for admitting the public to view the body of President LISCOLN were just as bad as human ingenuity could make them. Whether the Committees of the Common Council are entitled to the whole discredit, or whether they share it with the military functionaries who assisted on the occasion, we are ...
lead_paragraph: We feel bound to say that the arrangements, yesterday, for admitting the public to view the body of President LISCOLN were just as bad as human ingenuity could make them. Whether the Committees of the Common Council are entitled to the whole discredit, or whether they share it with the military functionaries who assisted on the occasion, we are not aware; but it seems scarcely possible that the unaided incompetence of the city authorities should have achieved so brilliant a failure. The police were well distributed, energetic and efficient, but everybody else seemed to be everywhere except where they were wanted. Inside the City Hall, where there was not the slightest chance of disorder, the members of the Seventh Regiment, fully armed, swarmed along the stairways, creating disorder where all was quiet, and serving only to increase the organized confusion which was kept at as high a point as could be expected from so small a crowd. Outside the building and in the streets where the lines of persons seeking admission were expected to be formed, no military effort was made to preserve order or decorum. The police were left alone to struggle with the vast mass of human beings who crammed the streets as they were never crammed before. During the day a tolerable degree of order was observed; but in the night the crowd increased and relieved the tedium of its fruitless waiting by general tumult and disorder. The management of the whole affair was utterly discreditable to those who had it in charge.

abstract: The light-fingered gentry took occasion to ply their vocation, yesterday, at the various points where dense throngs gathered; but as the detective policemen kept close upon their heels they enjoyed few opportunities to profit by their dexterity of finger. The pickpockets know many of the detective policemen better, perhaps, than the detective officers know them, and when one thief espies an officer he makes the fact known among his confederates, and they scatter.

abstract: The; was Repaired at Melbourne
snippet: The; was Repaired at Melbourne
lead_paragraph: -- The report that the Government of Victoria had refused to allow the pirate Shenandoah to make repairs and take in provisions in Melbourne harbor, is not confirmed. The story was too good to be true. The Shenandoah was merely put under surveillance for a time for attempts by her Commander to enlist British subjects; and the London Times reports with great satisfaction that, as these repairs -- which had been made "actively and quietly" -- were nearly completed on the 23d of February, the craft would soon be afloat again. The end to all this is hastening apace.

abstract: Among the persons whom the police apprehended, yesterday, were THEODORE ALLEN, a noted Eighth Ward politician; JOHN ALLEN, another politician, who lives in the same ward, and JOSEPH COBURN, the the pugilist. THEODORE ALLEN was standing at the intersection of Canal and Mercer streets, when the remains of the late President were approaching, and Officer DYCKMAN requested him to stand back to the sidewalk. ALLLN insultingly refused to comely with the officer's request, add The officer passed on. Seeing this, Capt. MILLS approached, and inquired whether ALLEN had heard DYCKMAN's request, and upon receiving an obscene and grossly insulting reply, he ordered ALLEN's arrest. Subsequently, at Police Headquarters. Capt. MILLS was approached by Ex-Judge STUART and a putative officer of the War Department, and informed that ALLEN had been subpoenaed to Washington as a witness, and that he must be surrendered, and the Captain referred the Ex-Judge to Superintendent KENNEDY, but that official declined for the present to liberate the prisoner, and ALLEN was held, last night, in a cell at the Eighth Ward police-station. A pistol was found in his possession.

abstract: Peace Terms with Johnston
snippet: Peace Terms with Johnston
lead_paragraph: They can hardly be judicious friends of Gen. SHERMAN who seek to show that but for the great calamity under which the whole nation is weighed down, his scheme of pacification would have been justified, or, at least, criticised with tenderness. One open apologist says of the terms which JOHNSTON exacted from his antagonist: "No man in his senses can expect the North to feel as it would if this appalling crime had not been committed. We have passed into a new era." We do not know that a proposition more at variance than this with actual facts could have been advanced. "The North" -- all of it, at least, that has shown a clean and loyal record throughout this war -- feels, in regard to the terms of Gen. SHERMAN's peace plan, precisely "as it would if this appalling crime had not been committed." Nay, we do not see how even those whose loyalty has occasionally been open to question, or who have been all along suspiciously neutral in this war, can honestly hold, that the political situation is in one degree altered by the assassination. For, we are compelled to remember, that since that calamity overtook us, the very organs which now demand consideration for SHERMAN's ignorance of actual events at the seat of government, have been the loudest in their protestations against attaching political significance to the murder of President LINCOLN. Only three days ago, the journal which now teaches us that "we have passed into a new era," ransacked several volumes of ancient and modern history to illustrate the fact that no temporary calamity, however appalling, could shake the faith of the American people in their purpose of maintaining self-government and free institutions. It compared their steadfastness and sell-possession in the extreme crisis of danger to the immovable firmness of NAPOLEON, as pictured by THIERS. -- facing an enemy overpowering in numbers in the heart of a great campaign. So far from holding, then, that by President LINCOLN's death, we had "passed into a new era," it urged the doubting and the timorous to remember, that "neither the fell spirit of slavery nor the revengeful blaze of feelings wrought to madness," had anything to do with the murder; but that it was simply the fruit of a horrid individual ambition. How a crime thus characterized has introduced us to a new era, it will be desirable to learn, at least before we fall back upon its commission as the cause for the all but universal reprobation which SHERMAN's extraordinary project has invoked.

abstract: Obsequies in New-York
snippet: Obsequies in New-York
lead_paragraph: The "Arion Society," well known in our community, will hold a grand funeral celebration in honor of the late President this evening, at Germania Assembly Rooms, Nos. 291 and and 293 Bowery. The exercises will comprise speaking and sacred music, both vocal and instrumental....The attention of teachers is called to a notice among the advertisements requesting their attendance at the Hall of the Board of Education this morning to take part in the obsequies....The anniversary of the Industrial School, connected with the Memorial Church, Hammond-street, will be held in the church to-morrow evening. This evening, Dr. HOLTON will deliver a free lecture at the Forty-second-street Baptist Church, near Seventh-avenue, on "Memorials of Patriotism," appropriate to events in the life and death of ABRAHAM LINCOLN....Attention is called to an advertisement of stolen bonds of the Brooklyn Central and Jamaica Railroad Company....The deputations from the societies and congregations of Israelites of this city are requested to assemble at the Nineteenth-street Synagogue, at 4 o'clock P.M., instead of 9 A.M., as heretofore announced, the hour of the solemnities at Union-square on Tuesday having been changed....The Marine Insurance Companies will be closed to-day at 11 A.M.

abstract: Express N Y on the Presidents Safety
snippet: Express N Y on the Presidents Safety
lead_paragraph: The Express is induced to ridicule our suggestion that proper precautions should be taken to prevent the assassination of President JOHNSON. What special objection it has to the adoption of such precautions it does not say. It says, however, that we should "trust something to God, and to the patriotism and vigilance of the people." This is precisely what we have done hitherto, yet President LINCOLN was assassinated nevertheless; and if we continue to trust solely to these reliances, deeming no special action on our part at all essential, there is very good reason for fearing that President JOHNSON may share the same fate.

abstract: About 1 o'clock the crowds began assembling in the vicinity of the depet of the Hudson River Railroad Company, at Thirtieth-street. But for upward of an hour no great number exhibited themselves, owing to the mass of the sight-seers being drawn off toward Broadway and Fifth-avenue, to see the funeral procession on its transit from the City Hall. Inside the depot no one was to be seen, except a few ordinary officials lounging about expectant and imperturbed. No signs of the special train that was to convey the last remains of our lamented President to Albany were visible. Everything was very quiet.

abstract: Yesterday will be a day long to be remembered as one marked by the most tremendous crowds ever seen in this city, celebrated as it is for its crowds and gatherings. To say that New-York was full of people would convey a very faint idea of the actual state of our streets during the whole of yesterday.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday will be a day long to be remembered as one marked by the most tremendous crowds ever seen in this city, celebrated as it is for its crowds and gatherings. To say that New-York was full of people would convey a very faint idea of the actual state of our streets during the whole of yesterday. New-York is always full of people, too much so for the comfort of the actual inhabitants, but yesterday the city simply overflowed with humanity. There was not room for all the visitors who wished to see the funeral cortege doing honor to our beloved and maryred President. The streets along the route of the procession were filled in most cases with a compact mass of human beings, who were unable to see anything for themselves, nor could they give way for a still more unfortunate class, those who wanted to gain a foothold. In the streets, on the housetops and in the windows the people swarmed and struggled. Everywhere and anywhere the eager citizens endeavored to gain some position that would afford a sight of the ceremonies of the day.

abstract: Even during all the night before yesterday, preliminaries for the great funeral procession had been going forward at many points in the city. Before dawn, the stir increased. Almost as soon as it was light, the vast mass of our great metropolitan ...
lead_paragraph: Even during all the night before yesterday, preliminaries for the great funeral procession had been going forward at many points in the city. Before dawn, the stir increased. Almost as soon as it was light, the vast mass of our great metropolitan population began to move perceptibly toward the sadly magnificent ceremony of the day. At first, solitary soldiers, uniformed and armed, or single civilians, in decent black, were gathering to a thousand rendezvous of regiment, society, club or association, as to centres of crystallization sprinkled over the extensive city map. And while uniform and civic costume varied in their respective many ways, two universal marks, distinguishable, indeed, in almost every citizen, whether to be participant or spectator of the sombre pageant -- the crape badge on the arm, and the countenance serious and often sad -- silently witnessed that the vast city arose in oneness of heart to offer a last testimony of grief and love at the death of the liberator, the patriot, the honest man and the wise ruler.

abstract: Funeral in New-York
snippet: Funeral in New-York
lead_paragraph: The coffin in which was deposited the dead body of our deceased President was kept open from 12 o'clock Monday noon, until 12 o'clock Tuesday noon. From the earliest moment to the latest, every facility compatible with the narrow arrangements of the committees, was offorded the public for viewing the remains. The Guard of Honor, divided into twelve watches, did duty until the lid was fastened on the casket, relieving each other every two hours.

abstract: Southern Plot to Introduce in New-York
snippet: Southern Plot to Introduce in New-York
lead_paragraph: TWENTY-SECOND REGIMENT ARMORY. -- Monday night the company rooms in Fourteenth-street, near Sixth-avenue, were thrown open to public inspection, they were handsomely draped in black, but the centre of attraction seemed to be the room of Company B, and without dispute Sergt. EDWARDS and the members of the committee have tastefully executed the task of putting the room in mourning. The side walls are completely covered with black cloth, relieved only by wreaths of immortelles suspended by white-ribbon, while from the Union altar in the centre of the room, rises a white marble shaft, on which the word Lincoln appears surrounded by a wreath; before the altar, kneeling in an attitude of heart-broken grief, with hair disheveled and face buried in her hands, is Columbia. So solemn and impressive is the whole effect, that one could almost hear her sobs, and fancy that her bosom was heaving with grief. The room will be open for inspection every evening this week.

abstract: and Gen Patterson
snippet: and Gen Patterson
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Philadelphia North American gives the following anecdote of Mr. LINCOLN, which he says is equally creditable to Gen. CAMERON and Hon. THOMAS A. SCOTT. Gen. PATTERSON had sought and obtained an interview with the two gentlemen last named in order to have an investigation of the causes or his failure in his campaign, the result of which effort he thus states. Both admitted that they now viewed the case in a very different light from their previous understanding of it.

abstract: -- It seemed yesterday, on contemplating the long, long procession, that all the nations, and tribes, and tongues, and people under Heaven were touched with a common sorrow for the death of President LINCOLN. The scene was characteristic of New-York, with its multitudinous nationalities, and could be equaled by no other city anywhere, unless perhaps New-Orleans. Shem, Ham and Japhet, all had their representatives -- the sons of Japhet being of course far the most numerous, the children of Shem being also, however, out in great force, and the progeny of Ham being present, we are sorry to say, in but very small number, owing to the unkindness of their treatment by the local authorities. Of the subdivisions of the great races, nearly every one had representatives in the grand funeral procession; and the feeling of all was one of common sorrow for the loss of a man who appeared to each as one of the noblest representatives of the human race.

abstract: Paroled Officers; Statue of; Status of
snippet: Paroled Officers; Statue of; Status of
lead_paragraph: -- Attorney-General SPEED has given an opinion, at the instance of the War Department, as to the status acquired, under LEE's capitulation, by paroled rebel officers, and by persons holding a position in the civil service of the Confederacy. It appears, from Secretary STANTON's statement, that, since the capitulation, rebel officers have appeared in their uniform within the loyal States. And upon this there naturally arises the question, whether such conduct is not an act of hostility, subjecting those guilty of it to be dealt with as enemies of the United States. The Attorney-General reaches a conclusion on the subject without much apparent hesitancy. Starting with the decision of the Supreme Court, that the rebellion was an organized insurrection with a defined territory, and that Gen. GRANT, in giving certain terms to LEE, spoke and acted simply as a soldier. Mr. SPEED is of opinion that the rebel officers who surrendered to GRANT have no homes within the loyal States, and have no right to come to places which were their homes before the rebellion. The Attorney-General is also of opinion that the stipulation made betwixt Gens. GRANT and LEE only embrace the officers and soldiers of LEE's army. Civilian officers of the Confederacy, therefore, have no protection under that instrument, if found within the territory of the loyal States. The wearing of a rebel uniform is held by the Attorney-General to be in itself an act of hostility.

abstract: Respect to be Commanded from the South; North Subservience to the South to End
snippet: Respect to be Commanded from the South; North Subservience to the South to End
lead_paragraph: In arms, the North has obtained the respect of the South; the next thing is to obtain it in civil affairs. The same resolution and firm ness which have humbled Southern assumption in this four years' war must be continued in the civil policy which is to succeed it. This is an indispensable condition of future concord. It is not in human nature for two equal parties to any combination, or conjunction of any sort, to live and act together harmoniously without mutual respect. If one party despises the other, he will surely seek to control him, or assume some bearing toward him which sooner or later will produce an open quarrel.

abstract: Our genial and patriotic German fellow-citizens of the Arion Society gathered, last evening, at the Germania Assembly Rooms, in the Bowery near Houston-street, to commorate the death of ABRAHAM LINCOLN. The hall was tastefully draped. Over the rostrum was the legend, in German, "LINCOLN has finished what was begun by WASHINGTON;" in front of the orchestra appeared a full length portrait of the late President, beneath which was a quotation from the speech which he made on raising the flag over Independence Hall, when on his way to Washington, four years ago: "Rather than sacrifice the liberties of the country, I would suffer assassination," and and the side of the hall a voluminous quotation from SCHILLER's "Glocke." The proceedings of the evening opened with the Funeral March from Saul, by the band. Mr. C.F. TRIACCA, President of the Society, briefly informed the assemblage of the object of the meeting which was, he said to make manifest the Arlon Society's profound admiration of the character of ABRAHAM LINCOLN, the liberator, Mr. C.F. BADER, Secretary of the Society, read a series of resolutions, in which high eulogy is paid the late President, and the resolutions having been adopted without a dissenting voice, members of the Society sang the grand chorus. "Inter Vitae." Dr. KESSMAN then addressed the audience at some length, congratulating them upon the perfect unity of sentiment which the assassination of the late President had wrought in the North, and thanking heaven that ours was now a genuine democracy -- a nation in which no slave could henceforth be recognized. ABRAHAM LINCOLN, who had killed slavery, was a man who understood the people better than any other man; who understood the time and the means; who knew that his immortal Proclamation of Emancipation would have fallen a dead letter if he had uttered it at the time when the Abolitionists were clamorous for it; who knew when the people had ripened for it, and who only awaited that hour to give it to the world. ABRAHAM LINCOLN, whose great fault was his goodness of heart, died at the right time -- the time when reconstruction questions were about to arise, and when, had it not been for his assassination by the red-handed genius of slavery, concessions might have been made which would have encouraged unborn traitors to make war upon the nation. Other speakers followed with sentiments not unlike those of Dr. KESSMAN, and every one gracefully eulogized the illustrious martyred President.

abstract: The Last Tribute to
snippet: The Last Tribute to
lead_paragraph: The partial loss of decorum which attended the overcrowding of the spectators at night in the first day's observances, was amply atoned for in the marked order and seemliness of the unparalleled funeral demonstration yesterday. As a mere pageant, the vast outpouring of the people, the superb military display, the solemn grandeur and variety thrown into the procession by the numberless national, friendly, trade and other civic societies; the grand accompaniment of music; and, above all, the subdued demeanor of the countless multitude of onlookers, made the day memorable beyond the experience of the living generation. The first thought with those who found the occasion one favorable to quiet contemplation, must have taken form in a reflection upon the continuity of those feelings of anguish, sorrow and poignant regret (among the vast body of the people,) which had their first sudden impulsive outburst twelve days ago. Twelve days of human sorrowing -- even when the affliction, or bereavement comes closely home to the household affections, represent a longer period than many would at first be ready to admit. Twelve days, voluntarily devoted to the expression of a grief which arises from a public loss, measured by comparison with all our past experience, or even with all our historical acquaintance, seem to expand almost into an age. And when these days of relaxation from secular thought and occupation are measured by the value of time in a vast industrial community, we stand almost amazed at the self-sacrifice of the people.
headline: {'main': 'The Last Tribute of the Metropolis to the Dead President.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Last Tribute of the Metropolis to the Dead President.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Along the route of the procession the decorations had generally been readjusted and improved. Some few new ones had been added, and among these one of the most tasteful was that of the Messrs. BRADY's photographic gallery. In the centre of the building was a large portrait of President LINCOLN, the frame tastefully draped with black. Above the picture was a laurel wreath in silver and a large American shield, covered with crape. Lying diagonally across the shield were two large flags, furled, and entwined with black crape, and above these another laurel wreath. These decorations covered the whole facadk, and attracted much attention.

abstract: Must be protected from assassins; Presidents, Danger from Impossible; Era of Assassination Begun
snippet: Must be protected from assassins; Presidents, Danger from Impossible; Era of Assassination Begun
lead_paragraph: We had a rumor in town yesterday that Gen. GRANT had been assassinated. The only noteworthy feature of the case was that nobody deemed it impossible, or even unlikely. While every one shuddered at the terrible consequences of such an occurrence, no one could feel that it was not quite as likely to happen as many things which have happened already.

abstract: On Tuesday evening the monthly meeting of the City Mission was held in the Central Presbyterian Church, A.R. WETMORE, presiding. Several missionaries were introduced, who told of policemen enlisted in the war, and now returned sick, receiving sympathy and aid; of a soldier who received from the mission a Testament, in which were several marked passages, and who wrote from the battle-field that one of these verses led him to Jesus; of a German tailor reclaimed from Sabbath desecration; of a profane cartman taught to pray; of sailors, immigrants, and many others appreciating timely counsel and kindness in the hour of need, and now becoming sober, industrious and devout, and loving to do good to others. Rev. JAMES B. DUNN spoke of the earlier history of his church, and its connection with the beginning of the tract effort, and said that the church was still true to the cause of the poor, and welcomed all to its doors. He had just met one of our brave boys who left an arm at Malvern Hill, being taken by the rebels, lay for ten months in Libby den, who told him that a tract given him in New-York, was blessed to his soul, and also to that of a comrade, who had lost both legs in the service of his country. We need missionaries to go everywhere, distributing the truth, speaking words of love, performing acts of charity. We need missionaries more than churches. We ought to have 400 at once. The statistics embrace the following figures: 4,521 missionary visits, 398 meetings, 817 persons to church, 169 children to Sabbath-school, 69 Bibles and Testaments given, and 73,810 tracts distributed.

abstract: and Breckinridge at Negotiation
snippet: and Breckinridge at Negotiation
lead_paragraph: -- The manner in which BRECKINRIDGE brought about the SHERMAN surrender seems to have been altogether perfect. One of the rebel's best devices was to put our commander entirely off his guard on the question of slavery. "The discussion of slavery is at an end," said this arch-traitor. "The amendment to the Constitution abolishing slavery will be accepted by the people of the South." Yet the wily outlaw brought his victim to the humiliating point of signing an instrument designed to make the institution of slavery perpetual.

abstract: David Wallenstein and David Kunst vs. The Columbian Insurance Co. -- On the 12th of December, 1862, the ship Mortimer Livingston sailed from Havre, France, bound for the port of New-York heavily laden with coffee and wool. On the 24th of the following January the ship was wrecked off Cape May. The plaintiffs had from the defendants, what is technically termed an open policy whereby the cargo was insured for $20,000. It was a condition in the policy given by the defendants that they were to be held liable in case of total loss only. After the storm which occasioned the loss of the vessel had subsided, a body of wreckers went down, secured a portion of the wool, but they refused to go after the coffee, considering it worthless. The defendants, however, after much effort, succeeded in getting up a very small part of the coffee, which they put in bags, and subsequently tendered to the plaintiffs, who refused to accept, choosing rather to bring their suit for the full amount of the coffee lost, $20,000. The defendants claim that inasmuch as they were not liable on the policy except for a total loss, and the coffee not being a total loss, they can not be held liable. The trial was not concluded when the court adjourned.
lead_paragraph: David Wallenstein and David Kunst vs. The Columbian Insurance Co. -- On the 12th of December, 1862, the ship Mortimer Livingston sailed from Havre, France, bound for the port of New-York heavily laden with coffee and wool. abstract: Subscriptions to the fund for erecting a monument to Mr. LINCOLN are being received with encouraging rapidity. The treasurer is Mr. T.G. CHURCHILL, President of the Columbia Fire Insurance Company, No. 161 Broadway, and the committee comprises Capt. MARSHALL and Mr. JOHN C. HAMILTON. Subscriptions are limited to one dollar. Numerous offers of larger sums have been received and refused, as the committee desire to have all classes represented in the movement. Subscription papers have been distributed among the insurance companies; banks, hotels and newspaper offices, which are being rapidly filled up. On the list sent to the Fifth-avenue hotel, one hundred and fifty names were entered in a very short time. Many prominent citizens or all political parties are cooperating with the committee.

abstract: The steamship Africa, with Queenstown advices to the 16th inst., arrived at Halifax last evening. The news of the fall of Richmond created intense excitement in England, but it arrived too late to admit of the papers generally commenting on it. As most of the markets had closed from the 13th to the 17th, the full effect of the news was not developed when the Africa sailed. The rebel loan, however, declined about six per cent., closing at 23@25; while Five-Twenties were quoted at 64 1/2@65 1/2. The news from the Continent is generally unimportant.

abstract: This court opened yesterday morning after an adjournment of ten days. No cases being ready for trial, however, Mr. Henry A. Crane, counsel for Mr. Peter Strong, announced that he should move to quash the indictment against his client, and the argument of the motion was set down for this morning. John Denny, previously convicted of obtaining money under false pretences, was sent to the State Prison for three years. John Wyman, convicted of stealing $200 from a discharged soldier, was sent to the same place for two years. The court adjourned until this morning at 11 o'clock.

abstract: John S. Wright et al. vs. Edwin Parsons and Samuel S. Taylor, Trustees, &c. -- The plaintffs, in the year 1855, entered into a contract with the trustees of some real estate located in the then small town of Cairo, Ill., which, as our readers know, is at the junction of the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers. There were 3,211 shares of all the beneficial interest in the lands sold to the plaintiffs. The par value was $100 per share, but it seems the plaintiffs paid the sum of $20 per share. At the time of the sale the grantees gave to each of the purchasers an agreement to repurchase the shares on certain conditions, and within a certain specified time, and they, the trustees, if they purchased were to pay $25 per share. Afterward the plaintiffs gave up this obligation and accepted inconvertible stock, or, in other words, stock as to which there was no obligation to repurchase. To make up for the difference in value of the two kinds of stock, the plaintiffs accepted also a conveyance of sixty-two lots of land in the City of Cairo. After the arrangements thus made, it was discovered by the plaintiffs, as they allege, that they had been induced to make the original purchase, as well as the subsequent exchange, by reason of false representations, emanating from the trustees. The plaintiffs charge that the quantity of land embraced in the trust property was misrepresented, and also that the value thereof was greatly lessened in consequence of its liability to inundation by the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers. They also say that the strength and sufficiency of the levies had been greatly overstated. The statement as to the natural situation of he land, and the damage necessarily resulting from the works of the Illinois Central Railroad along the two rivers had furthermore misled the plaintiffs. They therefore brought this action against the successors of the original trustees from whom they made the purchase, and seek to recover the sum of $120,000 damages. The trial was not concluded when the court adjourned.

Taylor, Trustees, &c. -- The plaintffs, in the year 1855, entered into a contract with the trustees of some real estate located in the then small town of Cairo, Ill., which, as our readers know, is at the junction of the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers. There were 3,211 shares of all the beneficial interest in the lands sold to the plaintiffs. The par value was $100 per share, but it seems the plaintiffs paid the sum of $20 per share. At the time of the sale the grantees gave to each of the purchasers an agreement to repurchase the shares on certain conditions, and within a certain specified time, and they, the trustees, if they purchased were to pay $25 per share. Afterward the plaintiffs gave up this obligation and accepted inconvertible stock, or, in other words, stock as to which there was no obligation to repurchase. To make up for the difference in value of the two kinds of stock, the plaintiffs accepted also a conveyance of sixty-two lots of land in the City of Cairo. After the arrangements thus made, it was discovered by the plaintiffs, as they allege, that they had been induced to make the original purchase, as well as the subsequent exchange, by reason of false representations, emanating from the trustees. The plaintiffs charge that the quantity of land embraced in the trust property was misrepresented, and also that the value thereof was greatly lessened in consequence of its liability to inundation by the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers. They also say that the strength and sufficiency of the levies had been greatly overstated. The statement as to the natural situation of he land, and the damage necessarily resulting from the works of the Illinois Central Railroad along the two rivers had furthermore misled the plaintiffs. They therefore brought this action against the successors of the original trustees from whom they made the purchase, and seek to recover the sum of $120,000 damages. The trial was not concluded when the court adjourned.

abstract: GERMAN OPERA. -- Mr. GROVER's season of German opera commenced here last evening. The house was comfortably filled by an appreciative audience, our public not having yet recovered from the shock of recent events. MEYERBEER's opera of "Robert il Diavolo" was performed. The orchestra, so important in these works, was larger than that of last year, having been reinforced by many of our best resident musicians. The chorus was effective and precise in a high degree. Among the performers, Messrs. FORMES and HABELMANN, and Mme. FREDERICI, most excelled. FORMES was in better voice than heretofore, and his acting was almost perfect; giving to the character of Bertram a harmonious and logical development which is rarely seen on the lyric stage. Herr HABELMANN sang capitally, and was encored in the duet with Bertram, although his high notes are still defective in delivery. Mme. FREDERICI sang the part of Alice recognizably well. If she did not lay too much stress on her lower notes -- for the purpose of showing them -- she might posbly avoid the harsh intonations which struck the ear too often last evening. Her "Va dit elle" was satisfactory, with the exception of the conclusion. The trio in the second act was not so good. Mme. JOHANNSON being sick, Mme. ROTTER sang the part of Isabella, and acquitted herself very creditably. The sickness of the lady named renders it necessary to give "Faust" on Friday, instead of the "Jewess." To-night "Der Freischutz" will be performed in Brooklyn.

abstract: JOHN O'CONNELL, a youth of 17, was detected in the act of passing to a confederate a gold watch he had stolen while riding on the platform of a Sixth- avenue Railway car on Tuesday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: JOHN O'CONNELL, a youth of 17, was detected in the act of passing to a confederate a gold watch he had stolen while riding on the platform of a Sixth- avenue Railway car on Tuesday afternoon. Several passengers seized O'CONNELL, and his confederate dorpped the watch and leaped from the car. The prisoner was held until Policeman LOGAN reached the spot, and then taken on the way to the Sixteenth Precinct Police Station; but before reaching his destination he was rescued by several of his companions. Subsequently, however, the officer found him in a house in Twentieth-street, and took him thence to the Second District Police Court. The prisoner was there committed in default of $2,000 bail...... LYON MYERS was committed in default of $1,500 bail to answer a charge which was preferred by Mr. WILLIAM BROCKWAY, of No. 93 Goerck-street, alleging that on the afternoon of the obsequies the prisoner stole a watch from the complainant's waistcoat pocket, while he was standing on the "thieves' corner" of Broadway and Houston-street...... Officer JACKSON, of the Eighth Ward, apprehended JAMES WELLS, whom he caught in the act of stealing a gold watch from Mr. ISAAC W. JUDD, of New-Haven, in Broadway, while the funeral column was moving. The prisoner was committed in default of $2,000 bail...... Mr. THOS. M. ANDREWS, of Nos. 71 and 73 Worth-st., made oath that on Tuesday afternoon, while he was standing in front of the Maison Dore, JOHN DUGAN stole his wallet. DUGAN, whom Policeman HELMHOLTZ, of the Fifteeth Ward, arrested, was committed in default of $2,000 bail.

abstract: Spicer, Daniel Sen., Killed by Wagon
snippet: Spicer, Daniel Sen., Killed by Wagon
lead_paragraph: THE JAMES-STREET MURDER. -- Corner GOVER held an inquest, yesterday, at the Fourth Ward Police Station, over the remains of THOMAS CASEY, who was shot by FREDERICK HISLEY, a young Canadian, in JAMES CASEY'S liquor-store, at No. 40 James-street, on Tuesday afternoon. It appears that HISLEY quarreled with JOHN H. COWAN; that COWAN struct HISLEY and knocked him against a counter; that HISLEY attempted to draw a revolver, but was prevented by the interference of bystanders; that the stepped out and returned within a few minutes, with a cocked revolver, and saying to COWAN. "I'll blow your brains out," fired and lodged a ball in CASEY's neck. The wound proved mortal within half an hour. After he had fired, HISLEY was knocked to the floor and terribly beaten by the crowd, but was rescued and taken into custody by Policemen MULLEN and TOWNES, of the Fourth Ward. Deceased was a native of Irland, aged 50 years. The jury found a verdict against HISLER, and he was committed to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: Mott, Dr Valentine
snippet: Mott, Dr Valentine
lead_paragraph: New-York has lost one of her most illustrious sons. The eminent surgeon, the honored, kind, and philanthropic citizen. VALENTINE MOTT, M.D., L.L. D., died last night at his residence, No. 1 Gramercy Park. Dr. MOTT was born in Glencove, L.I, Aug. 20, 1785. His father, Dr. HENRY MOTT, was for many years a practicing physician in this city. The son graduated at Columbia College in 1806, and immediately went to Europe, where he pursued his studies with great zeal and success. Three years later, at the age of 24, he was called to the chair of surgery in Columbia College, remaining there until 1813. In 1826, he, with Drs. HOSACK, MITCHELL, FRANCIS, and others, established the Rutgers Medical College. About 1830 he began to devote his time to lectures and instruction, and his great abilities have ever since been the pride of the profession. His position as a surgeon was second to no living professor, and challenged from the renowned Sir ASTLEY COOPER the remarkable eulogy: "He has performed more of the great operations than any man living, or that ever did live." Dr. MOTT has left several works of great value to science and literature, among them a translation of "Velpeau's Surgery," the "Mott Cliniques," "Travels in Europe and the East," "Transactions of the New-York Academy of Medicine," &c. Like the departure of HOSACK, MITCHELL and FRANCIS, his co-laborers, the death of Dr. MOTT will mark an era in the history of the profession.
headline: {'main': 'Obituary.; DEATH OF DR. VALENTINE MOTT.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Obituary.; DEATH OF DR. VALENTINE MOTT.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: By our correspondence from Richmond we have received such good accounts of a young New-Yorker, that even at this late date we cannot refrain from noticing him, Lieut. JOHNSTON L. DE PEYSTER, of Tivoli, Dutchess County, Aid-de-Camp to Gen. SHEPLEY, (Chief of Staff to Major-General WEITZEL,) formerly Military Governor of New-Orleans, subsequently of Norfolk, and more recently of Richmond, raised the first real American flag, or ensign, over the Capitol of the rebel Confederate Capital, with the assistance of Capt. LANGDON, Chief of Artillery to Gen. WEITZIL. Two cavalry guidons had been previously placed there, but it should be remembered that a small flag attached to a staff could be planted while the halyards were in process of adjustment and attachment to raise a "real flag." All honor to the officers who placed the guidons there; but as a matter of historic fact and interest, they who raised the first real American flag over Richmond, the central point of slavery, should be remembered in the annals of this war emphatically for freedom. The flag raised was the flag of the Twelfth Maine Volunteers, originally commanded by Gen. SHEPLEY, which waved in triumph over the headquarters of Gens. BUTLER and SHEPLEY at New-Orleans, and was sent forward into Richmond, strapped to Lieut. DE PEYSTER's saddle, in order that it might have the historic glory of being the first to wave over a city preeminently the stronghold and seat of life of the rebellion.

abstract: Our, News in Europe
snippet: Our, News in Europe
lead_paragraph: -- The news from Europe, to-day, gives us the first intimation of the effect of the victories at and around Ricmond, on the British public. Our friends -- so long, steadily and faithfully represented in the London Daily News, Star and Manchester Examiner naturally give expression to their satisfaction with the resistless evidences of our crowning triumph. The Daily News pithily says: "DAVIS began the war by declaring he would carry it where food for the torch awaited Southern armies in densely populated cities, but the attempt to burn New-York ended in nothing but an execution, while DAVIS set his borrowed capital in flames and decamped." The full effect of the news, financially, could not be seen by reason of its arrival at the close of Passion Week; Good Friday, the day preceding the sailing of the Africa, being of course a holiday. Still, United States securities are quoted at an advance, while the rebel loan is down to 23. The "leading journal," with its usual expertness in changing it base, has discovered all at once, that it is altogether wrong in the Australian Colonists to show any sort of favor to the pirates of the Shenandoah. It is also fain to quarrel with the Canadian Solon, Justice SMITH, for releasing the St. Albans murderers. At this rate, it will be able to claim before the lapse of another week, that it has all along foreseen the triumph of the Union.

abstract: Danger to Liberty from; Stipulation with Johnston
snippet: Danger to Liberty from; Stipulation with Johnston
lead_paragraph: Some of the Democratic journals justify and applaud Gen. SHERMAN'S stipulations with the rebel JOHNSTON. Others, more chary, do not venture to approve these stipulations outright, yet complain that Gen. SHERMAN is too harshly judged. Their particular plea is that in his military capacity he has rendered great service. This is no reason for exempting him from any censure that he deserves. On the contrary, it is the very reason why the government and the people should pass upon his action with the strictest justice.

abstract: The mourning emblems with which the City Hall is decorated will be allowed to remain until the last honors have been paid to our deceased President at Springfield. The removal of these emblems will probably be the signal for a general displacement of the signs of mourning with which the city is now covered. The interior of the City Hall remains precisely as it was when the body lay in state. The so-called "catafalque" will, however, be removed to-day. The Governor's room was visited yesterday by hundreds who were unable to obtain admission previously, some of whom availed themselves of the opportunity thus afforded them of obtaining mementoes of the occasion by cutting off portions of the silver tassels and fringes of the canopy. As soon as this was discovered a policeman was put in charge, and no one was allowed to stop within the canopy. CARPENTER's sketch of Mr. LINCOLN still hangs in its place beneath the dome. An effort will be made to induce the Common Council to purchase the sketch, or to have a picture finished from it.

abstract: Kean, Mr and Mrs, at New-York; Steinway, Charles
snippet: Kean, Mr and Mrs, at New-York; Steinway, Charles
lead_paragraph: BROADWAY THEATRE. -- Mr. and Mrs. CHARLES KEAN -- old favorites of our public -- reappeared here last evening. They have been honored by the generation that has gone, they come merely to take farewell of that which is going. In England Mr. and Mrs. CHARLES KEAN have played a large and active part in all that has made the drama honorable there. As artists they have been an example to the younger kind. We recall, with no effort, the good words that have been spoken of them many thousand miles beyond their hearance. The great Shakesperian revival which we have all in some sort shared was inaugurated by them, and its best fruits were ripened in the theatre which they managed -- the Princess' in London. No history of Shakespeare can of course be perfect without a reference to the name of KEAN -- but Mr. and Mrs. CHARLES KEAN, who are now here, have assuredly achieved the modern and scenically possible reputation of the great bard.

abstract: Since the receipt of orders from the department at Washington to search all out-going vessels none have been allowed to depart without a thorough examination of all on board. All railroad trains leaving the city are inspected by the authorities, and not a passenger enters them that does not, unconsciously perhaps, pass under the eye of an experienced detective. The Sound steamers were, at first, inspected after their departure from the city, but much time was thus lost, and now officers are present while the steamers are loading and passengers going on board. A sharp eye is also kept on trains arriving from the southward. The heavy reward offered stimulates the police and special detectives to keep up an unfailing watch for the assassin. They are however, of opinion that BOOTH is still concealed in Washington.

abstract: The; Crimes and Retribution of
snippet: The; Crimes and Retribution of
lead_paragraph: Slavery has written its guilt and its folly on the record of history, as no other human crime has ever done. It has insanely sought to overthrow the best structure of government which mankind ever erected; it has deluged this continent with the blood of our noblest and best; it has piled on us mountains of debt, and thrown civil discord into a happy people. In its mad efforts, it has ruined the hopes and desolated the country of its supporters; and now, when just dying under the executioner's stroke, with garments stained with the best blood of the nation, it turns to strike with assassin's blow at the head of the republic, and culminates its long course of iniquities by a crime which, in dishonor, cowardice and atrocity, is almost without a parallel in history. It was not enough that it should die amid the flames of burning cities and with the wails of thousands of widows and orphans whom its crimes had desolated; it adds to all its guilt the stain of private murder and base assassination of the purest public man of the day.
headline: {'main': 'The Nemesis of Slavery.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Nemesis of Slavery.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Peace Agents in Canada in Trouble
snippet: Peace Agents in Canada in Trouble
lead_paragraph: The rebel peace agents in Canada have, at last, become identified with the St. Albans burglars. A grand jury now sitting at Toronto have found an indictment against JACOB THOMPSON, C.C. CLAY, and three others, for a breach of the neutrality laws. SANDERS is beyond the reach of the indictment as long as he remains in Montreal, under the protection of Justices SMITH and COURSOL. His sphere of action, however, is seriously limited by this indictment. He is even denied the privilege of visiting Niagara Falls on another peace mission.

abstract: Disloyalty and Arrest; Disloyal and Locked up
snippet: Disloyalty and Arrest; Disloyal and Locked up
lead_paragraph: About 9 o'clock this morning Mr. EDWARD INGERSOLL, who delivered a strong secession speech few days since in New-York, was waited upon by a committee of citizens on alighting from the railroad, train at Ninth and Green streets, and was required to apologize for the speech. This Mr. INGERSOLL refused to do, and drew a revolver from his pocket, but was unable to fire it before he was knocked down and very badly cut and beaten by the crowd. He was then arrested and held to bail in the sum or $2,000 on the charge of assault and battery and carrying concealed deadly weapons.
