abstract: Fever Nests, >amp;c.
snippet: Fever Nests, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The Sanitary Reports in regard to the "Tenant-houses" of the city, to which we have already alluded, as in process of preparation by the Hygienic Council of the Citizens' Association, have just been presented to the public. They contain an expansive statement of the sanitary statistics of each ward of New-York, and, altogether, form one of the most remarkable monuments of the practical work of this association. In careful detail, they present the number of tenant-houses, the population inhabiting them, the average cubic feet to each person, the nuisances afflicting the district, the sewerage, paving and other similar facts, together with the number of drinking-shops and brothels. The cases of disease and the rate of mortality are also frequently given, and remedial measures are suggested. The volume, numbering some 348 pages, will be an invaluable storehouse of facts and figures bearing on the future sanitary labors for the city, and we trust will prove to our wealthy citizens the pressing need of speedy and powerful remedies. The figures show in numerous wards of the city a frightful overcrowding of population, and the most unhealthy conditions of life for the laboring classes, accompanied often by a shocking death-rate. The instances of are so many, that it is difficult to select from them. Here, for example, we find in the Fifteenth Ward, embracing the region between Bowery and Sixth-avenue, and Fourteenth-street and Houston, a cellar 18 feet square and 7 feet high, where a family of seven persons lived; of these, two died of typhus, two of small-pox and one of erysipelas. There happen to be in this ward many good private residences as well as many tenant-houses, and the opportunity is presented of comparing them. Thus a medium private house, covering a space of 20 feet by 40, contains one family, or eight persons; a tenant-house, on a space of 20 feet by 25, has eight families, or forty persons. The former has an average air-space of 4,000 cubic feet to each person; the latter of 400; the former, a ground area of 100 square feet; the latter, 15; the rooms of the one are light and dry; of the other, dark and damp. When it is remembered that 1,000 cubic feet of air-space is the least which should be allowed to each person, we can see what terrible causes and promoters of pestilence and disease exist in such a quarter, side by side with the favorable conditions of the better class. In this ward there are 4,940 persons who live in tenant-houses, and 234 in cellars.

abstract: City Directory; Improve'ts Suggested
snippet: City Directory; Improve'ts Suggested
lead_paragraph: THE FORTHCOMING DIRECTORY. -- Certain improvements should without fall be made in the "City Register" of the City Directory for the coming year, now in preparation. There is no list of city markets and their places, though there is one of the clerks' names. The list of pastors' residences under the head of "Churches" should be carefully corrected. The address of the United States Dispatch Agent should be inserted. The lists of periodicals and newspapers need careful revision. And the long list of the streets, their crossings and the numbers at their crossings needs a particularly thorough correction. The imperfections indicated are experimentally proved to exist. Probably there are more. We do not doubt the zeal of the conductors of the work, and these hints are to help, not to hinder, since doubtless the whole Register will be reprinted. We shall heedfully note these and other improvements when made.

BARNEY, all rebel officers, and traveling under assumed names. They had fifteen or twenty persons in their train, and were evidently bound for "Cowes and a market."

abstract: Loan, The, in England
snippet: Loan, The, in England
lead_paragraph: It is now greatly to be regretted that the rebel loan put on the market in England two years ago was not greater in amount. Not more than fifteen millions of dollars of it, we believe, has ever been disposed of, and this is hardly sufficient to make the loss of it as widely and as severely felt as could be desired. It was all taken, and is probably most of it now held by the most unscrupulous, unprincipled, cynical and money-worshiping portion of the English business world; and we need hardly say that it would not only cause deep satisfaction to all good men everywhere to feel that this crew had been heavily mulcted, but would help the cause of morality all over Christendom. There is no way in which they can be so severely punished as through their pockets, and there is no kind of punishment so peculiarly appropriate.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the following bills were passed. Incorporating the Greenpoint and Calvary Cemetery Railroad Company; the General Appropriation Bill; relative to fees of Kings County Clerk; changing the bulkhead and pier lines of the late City of Williamsburgh; the bill for the erection of a monument to the late President LINCOLN, in Central Park. The bill to increase the stationery allowance to Senators and Assemblymen to $100 was lost. The Assembly amendments to the bill for the erection of warehouses at quarantine were concurred in. The Assembly amendments to the Manhattan Gaslight Company Bill, with the two years' restriction for charging the increased price, were not concurred in.

abstract: Barnum's, P T, Wagon, Accident to
snippet: Barnum's, P T, Wagon, Accident to
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. P.T. BARNUM came very near having a serious accident on Saturday evening last, As he was driving a skittish horse up Banks-street, the buggy was turned over on the ground and thrown upon its side. As the top of the buggy was up Mr. BARNUM was unable to extricate himself. If his skittish horse had been frightened and run, as ninety-nine out of a hundred would have done, there is every reason to fear that Mr. BARNUM would have been killed. But for a wonder, the horse kept quiet until he extricated himself from his dangerous situation. -- Bridgeport Standard.

abstract: Peithologian Anniversary
snippet: Peithologian Anniversary
lead_paragraph: A large and appreciative audience was gathered in the Academy of Music last night to participate in the fifty-ninth anniversary of this society. Geo. G. KIP, presiding officer, in the opening address sketched the history and origin of peithologia -- to the detriment, we should infer, of its great rival philolexia. He was succeeded by other members of the society, who each and all eloquently discoursed on their several themes. Applause was judiciously and frequently bestowed. Our space will not permit us to give extended notices of individual performances, but the orations of Messrs. DE WITT, MARTINE, SWAIN, VALENTINE, and CORNELL must not be passed over without mention. The music throughout was excellent, and reflects great credit on HELLEMSMULLER, the efficient leader. The "Peithologian Gallop." "Old Friends with New Faces," and "Student's Songs," seemed to delight the audience more especially. On the stage we noticed several members of the faculty, Prof. SPERRY, HUNT, President BARNARD, Profs. PECK, SCHMIDT, Rev. Mr. DUFFIE and others. The whole entertainment reflects great credit on all concerned in it.

abstract: Recently, Dr. FRANZ HEIL, of Detroit, appeared before Justice DOWLING with a warrant for the arrest of his wife, ANN MARGARETT HEIL, and one Rev. JOSEPH WITTMEYER, or WINTER, Pastor of St. Joseph's church, Detroit, fugitives, who had, it is alleged, in away with $300 which had been stolen from Dr. HEIL's dwelling. The Doctor desiring assistance in tracing the accused to their hiding place, which he believed to be in this city. Officer CROKER, of the Tombs Court, was detailed and the fugitives were found at No. 40 City Hall-place, where they were boarding and cohabiting as husband and wife. Officer CROKER apprehended them yesterday, and Justice DOWLING sent them on their way back to Michigan. Mrs. HEIL is an attractive woman of 26, and has been ten years married to the Doctor, who is 50 years of age.... Policemen MULLEN and HORBELT, of the Fourth Ward, apprehended CHARLES ULLMAN for forcibly entering a lager-bier saloon at No. 191 Chatham-street, and stealing therefrom two airguns and other articles, valued at $150. The property having been found in the prisoner's possession, he was committed for trial.

abstract: The End of the Assassin
snippet: The End of the Assassin
lead_paragraph: The official announcement made in the city about noon of yesterday that the assassin of President LINCOLN had at last been hunted down and killed, and that one of his chief confederates had at the same time been captured, produced an excitement not ordinarily surpassed by the announcement of a victory in the field, accompanied by a profound sense of relief, satisfaction and pleasure. The pursuit of the assassin had lasted just eleven days, and had been carried on with a keenness and an intensity unequaled by anything in our criminal history. It had, of course, been particularly vigilant in and around Washington; but the agents of justice were hunting him everywhere. The search reached up to Quebec in the North, and extended far down into the Southern Confederacy. The hiding places in the mountains, forrests and swamps, as well as the hiding places in the great cities of the land, were scoured for him. All outward-bound ships to foreign ports were searched for him; the gunboats and garrisons on the Mississippi River were, and doubtless still are, closely watching for his appearance; on every railroad train, on all the lines of the country, lynx-eyed men were eagerly trying to discover him; detectives, governmental and municipal, regular and voluntary, soldiers, sailors, citizens, rebels, negroes, -- everybody everywhere seemed to be after the accursed outlaw. The large rewards were, undoubtedly, a stimulus to activity; but, beside this, every one felt that he had a duty to perform to himself, to his country and to public justice. Under the circumstances, the attempts of the wretch to escape law and vengeance were as futile and hopeless as his attempts to save himself from the execrations of history by his swaggering assumptions.

abstract: Corbett, Sergt, sketch of
snippet: Corbett, Sergt, sketch of
lead_paragraph: BOSTON CORBETT, who shot the assassin BOOTH, is a native of England. He came to this country when quite a lad, and learning the trade of a hatter, was for some years employed by Mr. ESPENCHEID, of No. 118 Nassau-street. On the 12th of April, 1861, he enlisted in the Twelfth New-York Militia, returned to the seat of war with his regiment three times, and was taken prisoner at Harper's Ferry, when MILES surrendered to Stonewall JACKSON. He was soon afterward exchanged, joined the Sixteenth New-York Cavalry, and was captured by MOSBY at Fairfax Court-house. CORBETT was deserted by his companions when MOSBY's cavalry came down upon them. He refused to surrender, and setting his back against a tree, he used his pistols so well that he kept twenty-six of the rebels at bay for more than hour. His ammunition being expended, he advanced upon them, sword in hand, and MOSBY, admiring his gallantry, ordered his men not to fire upon him but to take him alive. He was sent to Andersonville, where he saw his comrades die around him by thousands, and contracted a disease from which he is even yet suffering.

abstract: Department of; Districts and Commanders of; The, and their Work; Sherman's Negotiation
snippet: Department of; Districts and Commanders of; The, and their Work; Sherman's Negotiation
lead_paragraph: The promptitude with which the armies under MEADE, SHERIDAN, THOMAS, CANBY and SHERMAN, were put in motion on the back of the stipulations of April 18, promises more, than had at first been hoped, for the speedy annihilation of the remnants of the rebel force, if not also for the capture of the rebel leaders. CANBY and THOMAS, it appears from Secretary STANTON's bulletin, were informed, several days ago, of the government's disapproval of TECUMSEH SHERMAN's bargain with Jo. JOHNSTON; and orders were issued that that agreement should be entirely disregarded, and the pursuit of the enemy resumed in every direction. Similar instructions were issued through HALLECK's department to MEADE, SHERIDAN and WRIGHT. The orders in this case were to "pay no regard to any truce or orders of Gen. SHERMAN respecting hostilities, on the ground that Sherman's agreement could bind his own command only, and no other."

abstract: SAD CASE OF DESTITUTION. -- The widow of Sergt. FOLES, residing at No. 1 Clymer-street, E.D., was yesterday discovered to be in a state of starvation, and but for the prompt benevolence of the Hon. S.T. MADDOX and other gentlemen, she would not probably have lived twenty-four hours. It seems that her husband had been in the army since the commencement of the war, had done much active service, and about a year ago was taken prisoner, and confined until recently in the Libby Prison, Richmond, during which time he received no pay. A short time since he was exchanged and brought to Annapolis, Md., but his health was so broken down that he died shortly after reaching that place, and his body was recently brought home to his wife for sepulture. The small savings of her industry were expended in this sad office, and her health having broken down, she was unable to support herself, and scorning to solicit alms, preferred to starve. Several benevolent gentlemen have taken special care of the poor woman, and her life will probably be saved. Further information can be obtained by applying to Capt. WAGLOM, of the Forty-fifth Precinct Station-housse.

abstract: Sciota, S. S. Foundered a Second Time; Kansas, S. S.; Officers of
snippet: Sciota, S. S. Foundered a Second Time; Kansas, S. S.; Officers of
lead_paragraph: The "strike" of the workmen at the yard still continues. The spirit of the meetings of several trades held yesterday was, that they would still demand their old wages, and would not submit to the reduction of 50 cents per diem imposed by the Navy Department. It is expected that workmen will be supplied elsewhere, and it is rumored that many of the government employes at Port Royal and other points in the South, will be brought here and employed in overhauling, the vessels now heeding their labor.

abstract: Under the provisions of the general Bounty Law, passed by the present Legislature, principals, who furnished substitutes credited under the last call for troops, are reimbursed by the State in the amounts paid by them to such substitutes, not to exceed the bounties allowed by that law. Such reimbursement will soon be made by the Paymaster-General of the State, and without cost to the parties making claims. We are requested to state that no agent, attorney or other intermediate is required for the collection of such claims. The Paymaster-General will have an office at No. 544 Broadway, Rooms Nos. 4 and 5, on and after the 4th of May, where proper blanks will be furnished to claimants, and the necessary information given.

abstract: THE NAVY-YARD STRIKE. -- The Shipcarpenters held a meeting at Tammany Hall, in York-street, corner of Pearl-street, yesterday forenoon, at which it was resolved that they would not go to work unless the $4 50 per day, demanded by them, was paid; and it being stated that four quartermen and one carpenter had gone to work, they decided, that if called upon to resume operations, they would not work unless these men were discharged. The sentiment of the meeting appeared to be to stand out until the government desired their services. The committee which returned from Washington some days since, reported that they were very well received. JOE SMITH (the Chief of the Naval Bureau) treated them to mince pies, pumpkin pies, and other sweet things, and then, in effect, told them to go home and mind their business. This did not agree with the sentiment of the meeting, and they resolved not to apply to the Naval Department any more, but to wall until they required their services. The newspapers generally were denounced for not taking their part, and after a few addresses, the meeting adjourned.

The sentiment of the meeting appeared to be to stand out until the government desired their services. The committee which returned from Washington some days since, reported that they were very well received. lead_paragraph: Mr. EDWARD INGERSOLL, who recently delivered an offensive secession speech in this city, on his return to Philadelphia, yesterday morning, was waited on by a committee of citizens and requested to apologize for his speech. He refused, and drew a revolver from his pocket, but was knocked down, before he could fire, and very roughly handled. He was then arrested and held to bail in the sum of $2,000 on the charge of assault and battery and carrying concealed deadly weapons.

abstract: Considerable excitement was manifested in the city yesterday on the receipt of the intelligence that the assassin BOOTH had been captured, together with his accomplice, HARROLD. The meagre details which were first made public, seemed only to whet the people's appetite for more news as to the how, where and when the captures took place, what had been done with the prisoners, how they behaved and what they said. When it became known that BOOTH had been shot, and that the government were only in possession of his dead body, some dissatisfaction was at first expressed, but subsequently public opinion appeared to undergo a change upon this point. The more sensible ones saw that the excitement which has prevailed since the first news of the assassination reached us would only have been increased by BOOTH's trial and execution, and that it was better that he should have been shot dead than that this excitement should continue.

abstract: Rising Star, Havana Steamship; Description
snippet: Rising Star, Havana Steamship; Description
lead_paragraph: THE STEAMER RISING STAR. -- In our account of this vessel published yesterday, were some errors which are corrected in the description given below: The side-wheel steamer Rising Star, when completed, will be put on the route between New-York, New-Orleans and Havana, in connection with the Morning Star and Evening Star. She is built of white oak, hacmetac, , and is securely fastened. Her length is 318 feet: beam, 44 feet: depth, 31 feet 6 inches. She is about 2,800 tons burden, old measurement, and 3,100 tons new measurement, and is fitted with a vertical beam engine, with a surface condenser: cylinder, 100 inches diameter and 12 feet stroke. The hull was built by ROOSEVELT, JOYCE & WATERBURY, and her machinery by the Etna Iron Works. She is owned by the New-York Mail Steamship Company.

snippet: Mott, Dr; New-York Academy of Medicine, Resolutions
lead_paragraph: At a special meeting of the New-York Academy of Medicine, held on Friday evening, April 28, for the purpose of taking action concerning the death of its late President, Dr. VALENTINE MOTT, the following committee was appointed, viz.: Drs. Post, Delafield, Griscom, Buck, Flint, Isaac Wood and J.W. Draper, who reported the following resolutions, which were seconded by Dr. Stevens, and after remarks by Drs. Delafield, Stevens, J.R. Wood, Hamilton, J.M. Smith, Isaac Wood, Griscom, F.T. Elliott and Hewitt, were unanimously adopted:

abstract: Opening
snippet: Opening
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night Messrs. MASON & HAMLIN, the well-known organ builders of Boston, entertained a large and select company of professionals at the opening of a superb suite of rooms at No. 596 Broadway. To tell a tithe of the pleasant happenings of the evening would require columns of the paper: An elegant entertainment, provided by DELMONICO, satisfied the palate of the gathering; witty speeches and humorous, interspersed with Helleric diabolisms, made the hours speed swiftly by; excellent music from the nimble fingers and well-trained voices of accustomed artists cheered and enlivened every conversational lull, and the exceeding courtesy and thoughtful hospitality of the Messrs. MASON, established the heartiest relations of peace and good will among all men present. At an early market hour on Friday morning the happy party dissolved into its original elements, and the splendid rooms with their frescoed ceilings, depositories of magnificent organs, were left reluctantly.

abstract: Late on Thursday night, ANDREW WILLIAMS, an English seaman, and JAMES BARR, of No. 127 Cedar-street, fought in Broadway, near the Astor House, and WILLIAMS slabbed BARR in the left side with a sharp pocket-knife, inflicting a serious wound. WILLIAMS was arrested by policeman O'CONNOR, of the Third Ward, and, after examination, committed for trial.

abstract: -- The Academy of Music never presented a more fairy-like spectacle than on Thursday, at the little play of "Cinderella," when 200 children appeared on the stage, and went through their parts to the immense delight of the audience. The performance is to be given only once more -- next Monday afternoon at 3 o'clock. It will be a beautiful celebration of the first of May for the children that attend it.

abstract: The members of the Veteran Temperance Corps, composed of persons who have abstained for a third of a century or more from the use, manufacture, or sale of intoxicating liquors, met last evening, in the Forty-eighth-street Methodist Church. Rev. Mr. BAKER presided, and introduced Dr. HOLTON, who read the constitution of the society, which was organized on the 16th of April, 1865. Dr. HOLTON made a brief address on the subject of temperance, and said that he had been informed by a member of Congress from Illinois, that if Mr. LINCOLN was living he would be eligible for membership in the society, which was a most cheering fact. The constitution was signed by several persons, and speeches were made by several gentlemen, when the meeting adjourned.
lead_paragraph: The members of the Veteran Temperance Corps, composed of persons who have abstained for a third of a century or more from the use, manufacture, or sale of intoxicating liquors, met last evening, in the Forty-eighth-street Methodist Church. snippet: Highway, of McDonald, in Wmsburgh
lead_paragraph: RUFFIANLY OUTRAGE. -- Mr. ALEXANDER McDONALD, residing in South Fifth-street, near Second, Eastern District, reports that he was attacked by two or three ruffians near his residence, late on Wednesday night, after his return from New-York, and robbed of what money he had in his pockets. His assailants treated him so roughly that he has been confined to his room ever since.

abstract: during Wilderness Battles--Anecdote
snippet: during Wilderness Battles--Anecdote
lead_paragraph: JOHNSTON's surrender of his entire army leaves no rebel force this side of the Mississippi. KIRBY SMITH has a few thousand on the other side; but they have long been in a very disorganized condition, and will now disperse at once. We very safely assume that the last gun of this war has been fired.

lead_paragraph: The following letter, written a few weeks ago by CORBETT to one of his former employers in this city, shows that he was deeply imbued with religious feelings, and that, while battling stoutly for the Union, he was also a good soldier of the church militant. abstract: Yesterday morning, Policeman ABRAHAM SICKLES, of the Eleventh Ward, found in the dock, at the foot of Stanton-street, the body of PHILLIP MURTHA, a boatman, who fell overboard and was drowned three months ago. The body was recognized by Mrs. ROSE MURTHA, of No. 139 Goerck-street, widow of the deceased, and the jury rendered a verdict of "Death by drowning."

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- There is undoubtedly a strong Teutonic flavor about GOUNOD's music -- a local coloring peculiarly adapted to the splendid story which he so happily and powerfully illustrates. "Faust," for this reason, is generally beard to advantage when rendered by a German company, and this in spite of some alterations in the music, necessitated by translation and transposition of accent -- as for instance in Margherita's opening phrase -- prim, modest and demure in the original, but shorn of its fair proportions in the German versions. These, however, are trifles when weighed against the obvious and general adaptability of the music to the idiom of the German language. In some passages, indeed, this is so manifest that the preference must be given to it over either of the other two languages through which the work has been made so widely known. The best characteristics of the German version were certainly brought out last night in an unusually agreeable manner. We have rarely heard the work, in all general respects, better given. The artists were, without exception, in capital voice, and a rare and enjoyable unanimity prevailed -- a desire to be good and conscientious. The cast was mainly the same as last season, when Mr. GROVER played the opera here. We note, however, in his artists a commendable degree of improvement Mme. FREDERICI's voice has become fuller, and is evidently more under her control. Its quality is as heretofore, exceedingly good. We should be glad if the lady would not display so much energy in her acting -- especially in the window scene of the third act. A modest young woman communing with her thoughts in the chaste light of the moon does not fling her arms about so violently. We throw out this hint without desiring to detract from the general merit of Mme. FREDERICI's performance, which indeed was great. Mme. DJIUBA -- a young artist who sang once or twice last season -- gave a very acceptable rendering to the small but charming role of Siebel. Her voice also has notably improved. Signor TAMARO was the "Faust," (singing the words in Italian,) and was good. Of Herr HERMAN's Mephistophcles it is unnecessary to speak. It has been fully accepted as one of the best personations on the stage. We must not forget to add a word of praise for Herr STEINECKE, a reliable and painstaking artist, who is always at his post. The orchestra and chorus were alike admirable. Indeed our recollections of last evening's entertainment are wholly agreeable.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- There is undoubtedly a strong Teutonic flavor about GOUNOD's music -- a local coloring peculiarly adapted to the splendid story which he so happily and powerfully illustrates. "Faust," for this reason, is generally beard to advantage when rendered by a German company, and this in spite of some alterations in the music, necessitated by translation and transposition of accent -- as for instance in Margherita's opening phrase -- prim, modest and demure in the original, but shorn of its fair proportions in the German versions. These, however, are trifles when weighed against the obvious and general adaptability of the music to the idiom of the German language. In some passages, indeed, this is so manifest that the preference must be given to it over either of the other two languages through which the work has been made so widely known. The best characteristics of the German version were certainly brought out last night in an unusually agreeable manner. We have rarely heard the work, in all general respects, better given. The artists were, without exception, in capital voice, and a rare and enjoyable unanimity prevailed -- a desire to be good and conscientious. The cast was mainly the same as last season, when Mr. GROVER played the opera here. We note, however, in his artists a commendable degree of improvement Mme. FREDERICI's voice has become fuller, and is evidently more under her control. Its quality is as heretofore, exceedingly good. abstract: Surrender, The Close of the War; Surrender; Its Extent
snippet: Surrender, The Close of the War; Surrender; Its Extent
lead_paragraph: The dilemma in reference to the rebel army of Gen. JOHNSTON is satisfactorily solved. The Lieutenant-General has sent official information to the War Department from North Carolina that JOHNSTON has surrendered the forces of his command on the basis agreed upon, on the 9th instant, for the surrender of the army of Gen. LEE. We need not say that this will be perfectly satisfactory to the country, as it assuredly is to the government.

abstract: Rev. C.L. BRACE, of this city, leaves for London, to-day, in the steamship City of Baltimore, to attend an international convention of reformatories, and to examine the institutions of charity and methods of reform of Great Britain, and all their movements affecting the condition of the lower class. Mr. BRACE's long and very successful labors in this city in connection with the "Children's Aid Society," are familiar to the public, here and elsewhere. They entitle him to a rank among the foremost practical social reformers of the day. Our great cities, and especially the City of New-York, have now come to furnish a very extensive field for those who would labor for the elevation of the degraded class; and the intelligent inquiries of Mr. BRACE as to the ways and means of reform adopted in the great cities of Europe, will, undoubtedly, prove of value here in the future.

abstract: Day altered to June 1
snippet: Day altered to June 1
lead_paragraph: Whereas, by my proclamation of the 25th inst., Thursday, the 25th day of next month, was recommended as a day for special humiliation and prayer, in consequence of the assassination of ABRAHAM LINCOLN, late President of the United States; but whereas, my attention has been called to the fact that the day aforesaid is sacred to large numbers of Christians as one of rejoicing for the ascension of the Savior; now, therefore, be it known that I, ANDREW JOHNSON, President of the United States, do hereby suggest that the religious services recommended as aforesaid should be postponed until Thursday, the 1st day of June next.

abstract: Underground R. R. Bill Passed
snippet: Underground R. R. Bill Passed
lead_paragraph: -- The Legislature has rather unexpectedly done one good thing in passing the bill for an underground railroad in this city. It is the only railroad bill which promises substantial relief for our overcrowded streets. There is not room enough on the surface to accommodate all who want to ride. A railroad in every street would not do it. Besides, the loss of time incurred in going the whole length of the city by horse-power is very great. Steam engines can be used below ground, and passengers can be carried from Fiftieth-street to Wall-street in fifteen minutes. We hope this road may be constructed as speedily as possible.

abstract: Slaveholding must be destroyed; On Slave Aristocrats and the People; Pres Johnson's Views
snippet: Slaveholding must be destroyed; On Slave Aristocrats and the People; Pres Johnson's Views
lead_paragraph: Our readers will bear in mind that we have from the beginning of the war urged that this struggle was essentially a struggle between a class -- the slave aristocracy and the people. We have always maintained that only as this feature is considered both in legislation and executive action, can we hope for a permanently successful issue. It is a matter of hope and congratulation to us, and to all who take the deeper views of the contest, that President JOHNSON has from the beginning felt and acted on this idea. If his course be examined while he was upholding the government against tremendous odds in Tennessee, and his speeches at the time of his nomination as Vice-President, it will be seen that the prominent thought in his mind was that a base aristocracy, founded on slavery, who had long weighed on the poor and middle classes of the South, were now striving to overthrow all the franchises of the people on this continent, and were striking a blow at universal democracy.

abstract: Small-Pox Propagation; Facts on; Health Committee's Report
snippet: Small-Pox Propagation; Facts on; Health Committee's Report
lead_paragraph: From the report lately presented to the Legislature by the Committee on Public Health, on the subject of small-pox, and the legislation requisite for its prevention, it appears that the disease certainly exists in this city, and that there is no adequate legal power to prevent its spreading. The report shows that persons taken with this disease are allowed to travel in the cars and stages which are constantly running in the principal thoroughfares; that strangers taken sick at the hotels or boarding-houses are removed to the Small-pox Hospital in covered carriages, which perhaps the next hour are occupied by the wives and families of citizens; and that at some of the hotels strangers are put into rooms and beds occupied the night before by small-pox patients.

abstract: The movement to raise one hundred thousand dollars for the widow of Mr. LINCOLN is highly proper and deserves universal aid and cooperation. MARSHAL O. ROBERTS, of this city, has given $10,000 toward it, and there are many others who ought to follow his example. The family of President LINCOLN, who has fallen a martyr to his principles, and who died for his country as truly as did ever a soldier on the battle-field, is now under the guardianship of the nation. The country owes it to itself to provide for them amply and generously. We doubt not that the movement to receive donations for this purpose, if well organized, will be highly successful, though it would be eminently proper and becoming in Congress to vote each surviving member of Mr. LINCOLN's family a liberal, though not extravagant, pension for life. No soldier ever earned a pension better.

abstract: Veto of Central Railroad Bill; Central Railroad Bill Vetoed by Governor
snippet: Veto of Central Railroad Bill; Central Railroad Bill Vetoed by Governor
lead_paragraph: -- Gov. FENTON has vetoed the bill permitting the New-York Central Railroad Company to increase the rates of fare on their road to two cents and a half a mile. We cannot help thinking that in this he has not consulted the substantial interests of the State. The bill was very carefully guarded, -- the time during which this increase of fare was permitted being limited to two years, and the dividends restricted to seven per cent. It is perfectly well known to all familiar with railroad matters, that this road, in common with nearly every other in the State, needs very extensive repairs; and it is equally well known that, at the present price of iron and everything else which enters into either the construction or the working of a railroad, it is quite impossible for this company to make the repairs and improvements required. The slight increase in fares which the bill proposed would have aided them materially in this matter, without imposing any sensible burden on the traveling public.

abstract: Cabinet Changes not to be made at Once
snippet: Cabinet Changes not to be made at Once
lead_paragraph: -- A letter from the intelligent Washington correspondent of the Boston Advertiser, which we copy in another column, will reward perusal. It confirms what we had previously understood to be the fact, that the ill-timed demonstration made upon President JOHNSON for a reconstruction of his Cabinet, immediately after the murder of Mr. LINCOLN, did not succeed. The whole country was tranquilized and reassured by the semi-official announcement, made in our columns some days since, that no change whatever would be made in the Cabinet at once. It was generally felt that the nation had been sufficiently shocked by the assassination of the President, and that it would be unwise to add to the public excitement and apprehension by hasty revolutions in the political administration. President JOHNSON naturally and wisely preferred to postpone action upon so important a matter, and we have no doubt that, whenever the time shall come for such action, it will commend itself to prudent and sagacious men throughout the country.
headline: {'main': 'CABINET CHANGES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'CABINET CHANGES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Secretary
snippet: Secretary
lead_paragraph: There is no one member of the Cabinet about whom public opinion has been so surely, though gradually changing, as in regard to the Secretary of War. The faults which appeared in the beginning of his administration -- his impulsiveness in public action, and his sometimes harsh treatment of individuals -- are being forgotten in the splendor of his successes and the integrity of his administration. If Mr. STANTON is impulsive now, it is always on the side of liberty against oppression, or it is against some gigantic crime, or in his eagerness to throw his own tremendous force of character and mind into military movements which seem to him sluggish or hesitating. His acts of revolutionary energy and arbitrary power are not confined to punishing petty traitors, but to the arrest and punishment of more conspicuous criminals in peculiar crises of affairs. His prompt removal of Gen. BUTLER and his immediate renewal of the attack on Wilmington were grand and successful instances of his "revolutionary energy." The recent prompt, but most trenchant statement of the grounds of disapproval of Gen. SHERMAN's negotiations, show Mr. STANTON's intellectual force and his deep earnestness in the national cause in the best light. We believe the whole country felt a certain sense of relief and security, when that manifesto appeared at the thought of two such vigorous hands at the helm as Mr. STANTON's and Mr. JOHNSON's.

abstract: Rights of; Farewell Order, Lying and Bad Taste of, >amp;c.; The First of May
snippet: Rights of; Farewell Order, Lying and Bad Taste of, >amp;c.; The First of May
lead_paragraph: Whether paroled rebel officers should be allowed to continue to wear the livery of JEFF. DAVIS, whether they should be permitted to strut at large in one county, while refused the right of entering another county, would seem to be questions -- superficially viewed -- of altogether minor importance. It needs an inquest into the use or the abuse which has followed the parolement of LEE's men, to enable us properly to estimate the expediency of subjecting the habits and movements of this exceptional class to strict military surveillance. Their bearing, thus far, certainly shows little to justify any measure of toleration toward them, which is not absolutely guaranteed in the terms of LEE's capitulation.

abstract: -- We fail to see any reform in the reckless habit of driving the city railroad cars along the overcrowded and angular piece of road from Printinghouse-square to Broadway. The Dry Dock line, which runs partly on the sidewalk for a considerable distance, is especially culpable in not seeing that its servants are more careful. Six miles an hour is no uncommon rate of travel at the very worst parts of the road. Why do the police take no cognizance of this disgraceful and perilous state of things? Why do the company lay themselves open to a charge of negligence amounting almost to criminality? The thing should be reformed altogether, and reformed speedily. Crossing from Park-row to the City Hall has become an adventure, at almost any hour of the day.

abstract: The President's Widow
snippet: The President's Widow
lead_paragraph: Washington that is the purpose of Mrs. LINCOLN to make this city her future home. More than a year ago the deceased President declared to some of his intimate personal friends here, that alter he had laid aside the cares of his great office and retired to private life, it was his intention to spend the remainder of his days in Chicago. He had commissioned one of our citizens to look about the city, and before the close of his present term of office, to secure the refusal of a comfortable residence on some pleasant and suitable street. He felt a warm attachment for the people of Chicago, for what they had done for him before he became President, and for their unwavering and powerful support through the dark days of his first term. If the matter had been left to the choice of the stricken widow of the fallen chief, she would have directed that his ashes should repose on old Michigan's shore, near those of his great compeer and friend, STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS. -- Chicago Tribune, April 26.
headline: {'main': "THE PRESIDENT'S WIDOW.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "THE PRESIDENT'S WIDOW.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Every citizen of New-York who does not own his domicile appears to think that, on or about the 1st May, he is bound by some mysterious influence to change his residence, and especially does this seem to be the case this year. He may feel sufficiently well satisfied with what he has; his time may be too valuable to him to be spent in house-hunting; his furniture may be choice and peculiarly liable to damage; his nerves may be irritable, and he may have a dislike to be put out of his way; he may be aware, by bitter experience, of the truth of the saying, that "three removes are as bad as a fire;" and yet, no sooner does the 1st of May come round than he feels bound to seek another habitation. It is not unlikely that a good deal of this 1st of May migration is due to the attempts of landlords to raise the irrents at every new letting, but there is a restless desire in the people themselves for change. In the old countries it is no uncommon thing for tenants to occupy the same house for twenty years; here such a thing is unheard of. The amount of furniture damaged or destroyed in these periodical movings is incalculable. The amount of money the luxury costs, every housekeeper knows to his deep dissatisfaction. The carpets that just fitted the old house won't do for the new one. The curtains are too long or too broad, or not longer broad enough. The table that just fitted into that little nook by the fireplace is too large for the new rooms, and it must be exchanged. The stair carpet won't do for the stairs in the new house, in fact, the man who moves never knows how often be will have to put his hand in his pocket before he gets fairly settled. In place of $100, he finds, perhaps,, that it costs him $500, and yet the very next year he is ready to go through the same experience again.

The stair carpet won't do for the stairs in the new house, in fact, the man who moves never knows how often be will have to put his hand in his pocket before he gets fairly settled. In place of $100, he finds, perhaps,, that it costs him $500, and yet the very next year he is ready to go through the same experience again.

abstract: The heavy rain which commenced before noon to-day continues, and we leave this beautiful and hospitable city with the remains which have been so touchingly and generally honored. Notwithstanding the inclement weather, crowds have assembled at the railroad station to take their last look at the coffin containing all that is mortal of ABRAHAM LINCOLN. We pass in succession Columbia, Gafton, Wilmington, Greenwich, Crestline and other stations. Shrouded national flags and badges of mourning are seen at each. The rain storm continues, but this has not prevented the assembling of groups on the way Many of them bear lanterns in their hands in order that the funeral train may be plainly seen.

abstract: Monroe-street; Saw Mill--$30,000
snippet: Monroe-street; Saw Mill--$30,000
lead_paragraph: Messrs. BATTISON, STRINGHAM & BISHOP's Union Mahogany steam saw-mill and lumber-yard, at Nos. 287, 289 and 291 Monroe-street, and Mr. J.J. POST's large, four-story brick building, in the rear of Nos. 342 and 344 Madison-street, occupied by Mr. CHARLES GLOSE, cabinet-maker, and Mr. C.W. HOUGHTON, veneer cutter, were consumed last evening, and the tenement-house Nos. 283 and 285 Monroe-street, was seriously damaged by fire and water. Thirteen families were turned into the street, but their effects were mainly saved, with little damage by water. The fire at one time threatened to envelope the entire block, which consists of frame buildings, but was, happily, confined to the structures above-mentioned. Mr. GLOSE loses $3,000 on stock and machinery, and is insured for $1,000 on his machinery; Mr. HOUGHTON's loss is $5,000, and his insurance $3,000, in the People's office; Mr. POST's loss is $6,000, and Messrs. BATTISON, STRINGHAM & BISHOP's $20,000. The latter are not insured. The origin of the fire does not appear.

abstract: The statement which has gained currency in Washington correspondence, that Mr. EDWIN BOOTH had gone to Washington to endeavor to obtain possession of the body of his brother, is entirely incorrect. lead_paragraph: The Detroit Free Press, of a late date, says that from careful estimates made by merchants, millers and others, who have means of knowing, it is believed full halt of last year's wheat crop is still in the hands of farmers in that State. The large crops of say from 1,000 to 2,000 bushels, is generally unsold, and there is no disposition to sell at the present reduced prices. The paper say, we have advices from Illinois, which state the same facts, only to a greater degree, apply to that State.

abstract: Sec. Stanton's Order to Reduce; Order for
snippet: Sec. Stanton's Order to Reduce; Order for
lead_paragraph: The order for the reduction of military expenses, of which Secretary STANTON gave notice after LEE's surrender, has been officially promulgated. It is exceedingly comprehensive, and, regarded in its general bearing, it constitutes the best practical assurance the country could have that the great business of the war is over, and that whatever provision it may be found necessary henceforth to make for maintaining the supreme authority of the Government in the districts recently occupied by the rebel armies, may be found in a greatly reduced military establishment.

abstract: Report of Northwest (Chicago) Conspiracy; Chicago; Gen. Sweet's Report
snippet: Report of Northwest (Chicago) Conspiracy; Chicago; Gen. Sweet's Report
lead_paragraph: Gen. B. SWEET has made his official report of the investigation into the conspiracy to release the rebel prisoners confined at Camp Chase, near Chicago.He save it is proved that JACOB THOMPSON, of Mississippi, Secretary of the Interior during the administration of Mr. BUCHANAN, went to Windsor, Canada, some time in May or June last, under the assumed name of Capt. CARSON, and having been supplied by the rebel government with large sums of money for the purpose, commenced operations to organize in Canada an expedition to release rebel prisoners of war at different camps in the Northwest, and aid the "Sons of Liberty." with money and arms, to raise an insurrection, especially in the States of Illinois and Indiana, against the Government of the United States.

abstract: Agitation Against Commenced in Spain; Anti-Slavery Agitation Commencedin
snippet: Agitation Against Commenced in Spain; Anti-Slavery Agitation Commencedin
lead_paragraph: An agitation for the abolition of slavery in the colonies has begun in Spain. The first meeting of the Spanish Abolitionist Society was held on Sunday, April 2, in the Academy of Jurisprudence at Madrid. It was presided over by Don ANTONIO MARIA SEGOVIA, a member of the Lower Chamber of the Cortes and one of the founders of the society. The report of the meeting describes it as having been very full and enthusiastic; and resolutions were passed laudatory of the objects of the society, and appointing Don SEBASTIANO OLOZAGA its President, one of the leaders of the Progresista party; and a committee was elected composed of persons of very high social standing, as well as of great political influence.

abstract: Mr Caulkins' Report; Report on Public Schools; Caulkins' Report
snippet: Mr Caulkins' Report; Report on Public Schools; Caulkins' Report
lead_paragraph: There has long been an impression abroad that New-York, though distinguished for the liberality of its merchants, its philanthropy, and its immense energy and enterprise, is by no means so remarkable for its advanced system of education. The improvements which the progress of the age has introduced into education were thought not to have reached our New-York Schools -- especially those of the primary department. Many of our school trustees have apparently believed that any kind of teacher would do for a school of young children, and the public have had the pain of witnessing hundreds of little children put through a purely mechanical drill of instruction, without the least invention, or any calling forth of the faculties of the individual child. Few teachers seem to have thought that the teaching of language to a child is one of the most difficult branches of instruction, and that the utmost skill and invention might be applied in it to good purpose.

abstract: We gave some days ago an intimation that the government was about to make an important reduction in the materials and expense of the War Department. The official order was issued on Friday. It directs that the chiefs of the several bureaus shall ascertain at once what retrenchments can be made without prejudice to the publicwelfare. Ocean transports and river steamers are to be discharged as far as possible. Purchases of horses, mules, wagons, and other land transportation, will be stopped; also purchases of forage, except what is required for immediate consumption. All purchases for railroad construction and transportation will also be stopped.

abstract: Osten Sacken, Baron, omits ball, on President Lincoln's death
snippet: Osten Sacken, Baron, omits ball, on President Lincoln's death
lead_paragraph: THE INSTITUTE OF REWARD FOR ORPHANS OF PATRIOTS. -- At a meeting held at the Free Academy on Friday, at which HORACE WEBSTER. Esq., presided, and Dr. DAVID P. HOLTON acted as Secretary, resolutions were adopted on behalf of the Executive Committee of the Institute of Reward for Orphans of Patriots, deploring the death of Dr. MOTT, and expressing gratitude that a kind Providence has so long spared him to alleviate, by his remarkable skill so much of human suffering, and in many ways to bless his country and the race. It was also resolved that the society would attend his funeral in a body. The same committee also adopted resolutions in regard to the death of President LINCOLN, mourning his loss, and pledging the Institute to labor with renewed energy for the perfection of its plans, sanctioned and sustained as they were by President LINCOLN, as memorials most appropriate to events in his life and death.

abstract: Party Changes; Party Changes in
snippet: Party Changes; Party Changes in
lead_paragraph: The present is the last session of the existing British Parliament. And although there are no important measures put upon the ministerial programme, to tickle the liberal electors and the great unenfranchised multitude, there is a greater amount of party engineering in progress, than has been witnessed for many years. Everybody seems to take it for granted -- we know not why -- that Lord PALMERSTON must, perforce, retire at the end of the present Parliamentary term. And everybody seems to be agreed that the fight for the first ministerial position will be as keen and as bitter between certain rivals that now hold office under FALMERSTON as between the "ins" and the "outs." The Liberals that now give a general support to the present ministry -- solely in order to keep the Tories out of office -- will unquestionably unite upon Mr. GLADSTONE as their leader, in the event of Lord PALMERSTON's retirement. They feel naturally drawn to him as one of the most advanced of the party of Commercial Reformers. They also regard his recent speech on Parliamentary reform as placing him far in advance of the Whig leaders on that fundamental question.
headline: {'main': 'Preparing for Party Changes in England.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Preparing for Party Changes in England.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A destructive fire occurred last evening, at Nos. 283 to 291 Monroe-street and in the rear of Nos. 312 and 344 Madison-street, and loss to the amount of about $20,000 was sustained by Messrs. BATTISON, STRINGHAM  BISHOP, proprietors of the Union Mahogany Steam Saw-mill and Lumber-yard; $6,000 by Mr. J.J. POST; $5,000 by Mr. C.W. HOUGHTON, veneer cutter, and $3,000 by CHARLES GLOSE, cabinetmaker. These is but little insurance.

abstract: Banks, Gen. Speech on
snippet: Banks, Gen. Speech on
lead_paragraph: The New-Orleans papers, by this arrival, are filled with accounts of demonstrations made out of respect to the memory of Mr. LINCOLN. A meeting of the officers of the army and navy was held at Liberty Hall, April 21, when speeches were made by Gens. HURLBUT, BANKS and BRAYMAN, the first of whom presided. Gen. BANKS said in the course of his remarks:

abstract: -- In the Catholic Church, the entire month of May [???] devoted to religious services in honor of the Virgi[???] Mary. Tomorrow, a pontifical high mass will be celebrated in the cathedral, and solemn masses in all other churches. The altars of the Virgin in all the churches will be beautifully dressed with Spring flowers. Public devotion will take place every evening during the month except Saturday. Monday will be the anniversary of the martyrdom of S[???] Philip and St. James, and special services will be held in all the Episcopal and Catholic Churches. A mission by the Paulest Fathers will commence this evening in St. Peter's Church, Barclay-street, and will continue during tho month,
